description:
Get the fried chicken!

Restaurant is small and slightly cramped but the fried chicken is delicious.  Can't go wrong with the usual Korean foods - bibimbap, tofu soup, bulgogi.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
You won't regret ordering the friend chicken! It comes to your table piled high, piping hot and crispy. 

When I go I can't help ordering a ton even though the fried chicken is enough for 4 people or 2 of me. The service has been good and they usually give me something extra on the house - from a tofu soup to a fried fish fillet - seems to be dependent on how much I order :)

The place itself could use a facelift, they definitely aren't focused on decor or ambiance, but it is conveniently on a muni stop.
author: Angelito R.

description:
I definitely feel a bit taken advantage of after eating here tonight.  One server for the entire restaurant.  I felt captive trying to pay for my bill.  The food was mediocre.  
Probably just should have ordered the fried chicken since that's hard to make bad.  I ordered soondubu jigae which was bland.  The fishcake was tough/leathery.  Really starting to get tired of crappy service. 
 
So far I like Manna, My Tofu House, Korean Kitchen, Jang Soo, Han il Kwan.  Ohgane in Oakland is good, too.  All these are much better choices than Shin Toe Bul yi.
author: Paul G.

description: I went here for dinner with a group of 12 people. I got the seafood pancake. The pancake tasted good, but then I found a few pieces of human hair inside of it. So unappetizing! I might give this place another chance someday, but I definitely won't get the seafood pancake again. Maybe I'll try their fried chicken next time since a lot of reviews said it's good AND no hair can be stuck inside of it!
author: Elaine N.

description:
Coming back from Seoul I wanted Bimibap and was missing that complex flavor found in many places from airport restaurant to Seoul.  When I saw the numerous favorites here, had to give it a try.

Bibimap gere wasn't even close, bland flavorless and mediocre.  Fried chicken wasn't like the Korean spicy chicken found in Seoul.  Just lots of batter without meat.

Was thoroughly disappointed as I love small mom and pop places like this but I can't lie that I won't be coming back here regardless of other reviews. 

To go they even just give me boxes and don't even provide basic wrapping.  Typical of Chinese style places or lack of service.  Not even a checkin to see how I liked my food.
author: David H.

description:
Dang their fried chicken is good.

Really, I would like to leave my review to just that.

TL;DR: Get their fried chicken.
author: Greg G.

description:
What a fun, local, neighborhood find. After years of passing by, the BF and i finally decided to give this korean, almost hole i the wall, joint a try. We went there, on a late friday night and had to wait a quick 15 mins for our table of two. The decor is simple here, no frills, surprisingly well ventilated,  good for parties of 4 and small (IMO), though they can accommodate more. 

Shin Toe Bul Yi had an assortment of korean dishes included lots of soup options, the standard bbq meats, seafood pancake, and a variety of stews. From observation, almost every party ordered the fried chicken, so we decided to go with an order of that and the seafood "casserole" soup. Like any good korean restaurant, there was an assortment of ban chan that came alongside the meal. We were really happy with the options (broccoli, kimchee, bean sprouts, etc). 

The star of the show was the fried chicken. Unlike some other korean "bar food" restaurants, their fried chicken was tender, with lots of batter, and not spicy. It was perfectly crispy on the outside and super moist on the inside. Surprisingly, not too oily either.  The portion was huge. That alongside the seafood soup was the perfect amount for two people. The soup had a nice variety of actual crap, mussels, squid, with noodles. It was the perfect balance to tone down the heaviness of fried chicken. 

Overall, a great meal with good portions, great services, and good prices. More and more, it's harder to find restaurants with a mom-pop feel in the city. Nice that this place is still standing and thriving.
author: Diane T.

description:
I came here last week for dinner on a Saturday.  We came around 6pm and were super lucky to be seated right away,  the restaurant is small and doesn't seat many people. 

The menu has plenty of options but since my friends came frequently they ordered for us.  We got an order of the famous fried chicken, an order of pork belly / sliced brisket, and an order of japchae. They serve complimentary soondubu!!!!! 

The fried chicken here, has a nice crispy non flaky breading.  It is super tender inside and the portion was very large.  The japchae was steaming hot and enjoyable as well.  I wish they provided more banchan such as the rice paper. 

Super friendly and the waitresses dont speak much english.  Soondubu tasted similar to the one i had in korea.  Total was $100 including a bottle of soju and large bottle of beer!! Not bad for 4 ppl.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I saw a lot of locals and figured that could only be a good sign. Everyone had a plate of fried chicken and i needed one too! It had a crispy and light batter (sometimes a little to much) and was still moist inside. Pretty good K.F.C. The dumpling and egg soup was my favorite dish. Plenty of dumplings and glass noodles made this a simple but tasty soup. The seafood pancake was HUGE. Dense and chewy. Tasted a bit on the oily side though it didn't skimp on the seafood. There were pieces of squid in every bite. 

They could use more ventilation. Walked out as if i had korean bbq.
author: Samantha L.

description: My go to place for Korean food! Loving the hole the wall atmosphere, this place is a gem in the sunset! Their seafood pancake is to die for, a must get!
author: Margo C.

description: KFC here is above the rest in the area.  KFC is Korean Fried Chicken by the way and is not greasy and has lots of flavor.  I will come here just for this but the other items are good too.  I've been fan for a long time.  The usual suspects are fine - kalbi,  mackerel,  tofu soup, and more.   Everything is good but that chicken!  Booming!
author: Jeff W.

description: Only one server. Slow and Not friendly. Does not speak, does not smile and seemengly does not understand and does not care what you want. The beef is impossible to chew. They must pick animals who died a natural death to make soup. Watch for human hair In everything you order. Food C-.  You have to be really hungry to eat there. Service horrible.
author: Fatima S.

description: Definitely not one of my favorite Korean spots in SF. It didn't even come close. The quality of the food was subpar compared to their competitors. Our party of five ordered the kalbi, beef tofu soup, bulgogi, and the seafood tteokbokki. But first we were served a platter of appetizers (banchans) that was only enough to serve at most two people. Banchans are complimentary but I always appreciate it when servers give you a large enough portion so you don't have to keep calling them back to refill your empty dishes. We were a bit puzzled when our meat dishes came because they looked generic, pale, and unappetizing. We had mistaken the bulgogi (beef) for pork because of its light color and feeble texture. The garnish was lacking and quite sad on the eyes. The kalbi, although generous in portion, was tough and unflavorful. I highly DO NOT recommend ordering the protein here. If you happen to stumble across this restaurant and want to give it a shot, order the beef tofu soup. It was delightful and flavorful. It will for sure keep you warm on a chilly day in the city.
author: Amy T.

description: Spicy Tofu soup with egg was delicious. I also enjoyed the crunchy Korean Fried Chicken which was so yummy.
author: Juan V.

description:
Shin Toe Bul Yi is no longer as good as I remembered, 15 years ago.   It used to be my favorite Korean place.  The parking situation is almost impossible so I stopped coming here.  We had to circle several times tonight to finally get a parking spot a block and a half away from the restaurant.  

The seafood pancake is still solid delicious although I would like it to be a bit more crispy.  The quality of the fried chicken did not seem to be fresh as I could smell the chicken.  The beef bibimbap rice cooked in the stoneware was ok. Bulgogi, beef ribeye was ok.  The sof tofu soup was nothing special.  

The place was jammed packed at 630pm.  The service was a bit slow as only two waiters work super hard to serve everyone.  The best thing tonight was having a decent  meal on the table served by a pleasant waiter.  

Probably won't return again anytime soon.
author: Ivory B.

description:
This place is a total hole in the wall, but the food is solid!

We always get the tofu bowl, bibimbop, and the fried chicken. The fried chicken is delicious--crispy and juicy. 

The gals that work, including the owner, are all super friendly. Great neighborhood spot!
author: Mimi T.

description:
The only thing I love was the fried chicken. Everything else is okay. Husband loves this place tho. Everyone there was nice, good price, and good portion.

I would definitely come back but not on top of the list.
author: Vonny W.

description:
I came here about an hr and a half before closing and I was alittle disappointed. The side dishes were mediocre with 5 sides and usually I'm used to eating silver chopsticks instead of wooden ones. 

I ordered the fried chicken which was a bit salty but the best dish on the table. The soondubu needed more flavor and spicyness. And the cold spicy noodle is was relatively okay. 

Overall, I had an okay experience. Probably wouldn't come back though.
author: Crystal H.

description:
Wow, I can't believe I've never been to this Korean restaurant!

Came here on a Wednesday night, street parking is scarce at this time since it's located in a residential area. 

It was pretty busy and there were only a couple of nice ladies waiting on the tables. Service was fairly prompt. Food was pretty good. 

Seafood pancake (4 stars) - VERY chewy! This is the first time I've had pajeon with a thicker dough. Usually, I see the pancake cut like a pie but they cut the pancake into more pieces (vertically and horizontally) here.

Seafood Tofu Stew (3.5 stars) - CLEAR broth! This is the second place that I've been to with such clear broth, I do wish that it had more anchovy taste. My sister actually thought the soup was bland. 

The above dishes were accompanied with two bowls of rice (we were surprised we got two) and a pack of salted seaweed (this was another surprise).

Side dishes (3 stars): cucumbers, bean sprouts, yellow spicy pickled radishes, fish cake, broccoli, kimchi
  -- Pickled dishes needed a bit more vinegar. Veggies needed more salt.

Come to this Korean restaurant for a feeling of satisfaction and comfort. The food is tasty and the tab was only around $30 for two.
author: Amy T.

description: Authentic. Small family owned. Many Koreans here eating so you know it's the real deal.
author: Hector Y.

description: Great fried chicken! Everytime we go to Shin Toe Bul Yi we get the fried chicken. If you look around, all the other tables order the fried chicken as well. Authentic Korean home style cooking.
author: Toney W.

description:
This restaurant is an amazing hole-in-the-wall in the Outer Sunset, and you won't regret going. (Unless you struggle to find parking - this is a residential neighborhood after all). The best way to describe Shin Toe Bul Yi is to think of a Korean grandmother that you visit once in a while. She'll cook really great food for you - it won't be Michelin-star worthy, nor will she feed you unlimited portions until you drop. But it will be super authentic, the portions will be sizable, and everything will be tasty.

Quick things to note: on the lunch specials, they are TAKEOUT ONLY. Previous reviews have said that you can eat on the tables there - this is no longer the case. For lunch, if you can imagine those transparent clamshell containers that you get in a cafeteria? They use those here - one compartment has meat, the other rice, and the other two are banchan (sprouts, fish cake, house made cucumbers, and kimchi). It's definitely a large portion and will fill you up, for less than $10. You'll be served really quickly, and then can go outside and enjoy the weather and the nearby parks.

Final note - if you're transiting, the L Taraval (and 66 Quintara, but no one really rides that except locals) stops right in front of the restaurant.
author: Bobby W.

description:
As with many of the restaurants on Taraval, I've passed this one many times without thinking much of it. I finally dropped by today because a friend wanted to try it. The bar for Korean food in SF has been set pretty low for me, and this place slightly exceeded expectations. Here's the break down:

Service: alright - relatively fast

Banchan: there wasn't that much of it

Food: I had yeukejang, which was pretty standard. It could have used more spice. Friends both ordered soondubu, which they also said was middle of the road. 

Price: reasonable for SF. Cheaper than Han Il Kwan for sure. 

Overall: pretty standard SF Korean food experience. Not great, not terrible. I'll probably be back on a rainy day when I'm craving jjigae. 

For next time: everyone was ordering their fried chicken and dang. It looked GOOD. I'll try it next time and might bump up my rating a star if it's as tasty as it looks. 

UPDATE: Went back and tried the fried chicken and squid ddukboki - was good enough to warrant raising my rating to four stars. Way to go Shin Toe Bul Yi. You're #1 on my SF Korean food list now~
author: Lauren C.

description:
Great food! I suggest the, kal bi, fried chicken, jap chae, and bul go gi!

Great service and fast. Would recommend anyone else to come try this place!
author: James K.

description:
Don't judge a book by its cover would be a perfect phrase to describe Shin Toe Bul Yi. To be honest, this place does not look good from the outside to the inside. Super outdated, questionable interior design and the stuffiness of the air... I wasn't sure but I gave it a shot, and I was glad I wasn't being too picky.

They have a very unique and authentic menu. Food you wouldn't normally find in other Korean restaurants: Gopchang jungol, grilled mackerel, aguchim, kalgooksoo, fried chicken and so on. The menu has a serious Ahjussi vibe so is the place itself (and even the name), and that's what makes Shin Toe Bul Yi different from other restaurants. They don't try hard, but always consistent with their food and style. 

The food is good. I've been going there for years and it's been always good. I wouldn't say the food is amazing, but rather on a humble side - the kind of food Korean mom would make. It's comforting. I love how they serve packed gim as banchan and barley tea. These two things were essential of my family dinner table growing up, and it brings back the memory. Now when I go to Shin Toe Bul Yi, everything I questioned about this place, now feels cozy and warm.
author: Nana K.

description: 5 star! Yes! I love the soft tofu with beef spicy flavor.. and theif authentic fried chicken! Yummm!! The price was cheap! I ll keep coming back there! Love it!
author: Vanessa D.

description: Great place. Hole in the wall type neighborhood Korean restaurant. Food is excellent. The Fried chicken is the best. Have ordered food to go and is ready when I get there.
author: Eric S.

description:
Another amazing gem, hidden away in the sunset.  I would say Shin Toe  Bul Yi and Han Il Kwan are my favorite places to bring friends for great Korean and for different experiences.

S.T.B.Y. is not cook it yourself, looks like a cozy cafeteria with a small kitchen, and specializes in stone pot and seafood pancakes.  It's quiet and delicious and easy to get to from the L.  The only hang up is their hours since lunch is only take away and they're closed one day during the week, which I always forget.
author: Andrea B.

description:
I am convinced that Shin Toe Bul Yi is a worthy rival to the top Korean restaurants in SF such as Han Il Kwan and Manna. Being in a more quiet neighborhood means it's lesser known among foodies but you will often get a table without having to wait.

The prices are usually above $10 per dish but the portion size is very generous, plus we had a free soft tofu soup on the house. Our group of four ordered the fan favorite's fried chicken, spicy BBQ pork, and spicy cold noodle and we still have leftover food to bring home. On a different occasion, I also quite liked the seafood pancake. Even banchan was no scrappy stuff -- the kimchi and the radish were some of the best I've had.
author: Chii L.

description: Food was good. A small restaurant. Had to wait a while. Go early if you hangry. Couldn't bring our own drink from outside.
author: Kimberly K.

description: The place was okay compared to la Korean restaurants. It is small and tight. It had good service. We got the fried chicken, seafood pancake, tofu soup, and jap chae. The fried chicken was okay. The really seafood pancake. It was unique and had lots of seafood. It was a little soft in the middle tho. The jap chae tasted great but the noodles were clumpy and sticking to each other. The tofu soup was a little bit watered down. Altogether I think it is a decent place if you happen to be in the area.
author: Teresa V.

description: As someone who is spoiled by literally growing up in Murray Hill, Queens, NY (queen's koreatown), san francisco's korean food scene has always left me slightly disappointed. The Korean food in SF has always felt OK, but not LA or NYC quality. This restaurant, however, has excellent food and banchan, that does rival places in nyc. They have a menu with all types of hanshik you might be used to, and also a much larger variety of jigaes than I normally see in a restaurant in sf. This place isnt trying to cater to the standard american palate, it tries to be real. My friend wanted to stick to classics so we got the soondubu (tofu soup) and seafood bibimbap. The former had a good flavor, but was much more of a soup rather than stew like rendition of this dish. The latter was to die for, very clearly uses fresh, not frozen seafood. Must try!
author: Crystal Y.

description:
Well..
I've heard this place is good and I decided to give it a try.
Well, from its cleanliness, the table is sticky.
I ordered number 12, the chewy noodle and my friend ordered the bulgogi and tofu.
Uh. my noodle was not good, and the bulgogi was too sweet.
After we almost done with our dinner, we couldn't finish it because the taste of the food was just too... uh. IDK. Maybe I'm just weird, but I felt like throwing up afterwards.
author: Candice L.

description:
Very mediocre. Bumping the review to 3 stars because of the 5-star service. 

I ordered the seafood soft tofu soup, and it was one of the most disappointing tofu soups I've had. The broth itself was bland, and the ingredients were skimpy. Could barely see the seafood (sea what I did there?) Overall, not satisfying at all. 

Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing, but my friends' foods didn't seem to be much better. 

The banchan was okay. The portions are tiny (granted you can get refills, but still). The kimchi was average. Not bad, but not memorable.
author: Samantha C.

description: I've been here many many times, food is always good and they have pretty good crowd, but I never checked the bill until today, I came in by myself, ordered a sondubu $9.99 and a yellow croaker $14.99 and the bill came with a total of $37.94, I checked the price on the menu again and counted with my phone, the waitress apologized and changed it to $27.94 after I questioned her about my bill, I believe she wrote the wrong number but still $27.94 shouldn't be right neither, didn't ask her to check again cuz it's only 80cents difference plus she's busy but do pay attention on your bills guys.
author: Lulu W.

description: This spot is a San Francisco classic and has been in the neighborhood since the earliest I could remember. The Korean food is authentic and reminds me of my mom and grandma's cooking. Service is great since seating is limited. I highly recommend getting the Korean fried chicken with some Korean beer. It's a rainy day norm to eat this combo whenever it is raining or hot or cold. Pretty much everyday.
author: Ryan K.

description: I have to say I was a bit disappointed. Had high hopes but overall the food was just mediocre. They refill the sides though. They do have an A for health score of 90+.
author: Gerry P.

description:
DA. BOMB. 
This place hasn't let me down every time that I've eaten here. Their fried chicken is a must.
author: Austen C.

description:
Shin Toe (STBY) has all the standard korean fare- meat on sizzling plates, bibimbap, soondobu, other soups, jap chae, banchan, and even fried chicken. While they do have a nice variety, I found most items I sampled to be average. Apparently they specialize in pork bone broth soup, but I didn't try it and opted for soondobu on a somewhat chilly day.

The soup was just ok, not super flavorful, but standard. I tried the chicken, which was also lacking in flavor. The jap chae and banchan were pretty good. If you have a small group all craving different Korean items, I would go here. This is kind of like the Denny's of Korean food, pretty much serve everything you are expecting, but not great quality.
author: Steven V.

description:
Came here with a big group of friends, and my experience was pretty good! The lady servers that helped us were so friendly and helpful. I split an order of their fried chicken and a dumpling soup/mandu guk. 

Contrary to the chili icon right next to the fried chicken. It was not spicy at all and was quite delicious! It wasn't too oily but I think our order with something soupy helped balance that out for me. We also had a grilled fish side dish, and that was good. So many dumplings in the soup but we cleared it. 

I also like how it's decorated and the furniture. It has a homey feel, and I'm already craving that chicken again.
author: Sara T.

description:
Two things that SoCal trumps SF food wise from most reliable sources are Korean and Mexican food.
Since I mostly feast on Taiwanese food in SoCal, I am not a great judge in terms of authenticity.
The best way to describe this corner eatery is "that is how my Korean auntie made it".  The layout is unusual with the kitchen and cashier counter to the right as you enter and the dining area to the spacious area to the left.
My first dining experience here was in the late '80's or early '90's.  Most popular Korean restaurants are in the Richmond district of the city, but this one is a neighborhood staple.  My friend had a craving for their KFC (Korean fried chicken - not Colonel Sanders' version), so I placed a takeout order on a recent Saturday afternoon.  Parking can be difficult especially during dinner hours with a couple of popular Chinese dumpling places and Taraval Okazuya just up the block from here.  I illegally double parked around the corner, ran in, paid, and drove home.  The order (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LodVIa3Vgy_lTqxJPjVUsQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) was around $17.00 after tax for a pretty generous portion.  While driving home with the box half open (done by the restaurant so that the steam would not ruin the crispiness), the aroma made my stomach growl.  By the time I got home, I was fighting the Herman's Head debate... eat one?  or not?  eat one?  or not?   
Well, the devil won so I grabbed a small thigh and bit into that still warm tender piece of goodness.  Please do not expect any heavy seasoning or sauce as this is a bare bones preparation of battered chicken.  The best part was that the meat was still moist after the fifteen minute drive home.
This was a nice reminder that I should probably stop by here one of these weeknight evenings to try some of their other offerings.  However, judging by most other reviews, the KFC is probably the only must order here.
author: Mike C.

description:
Hands down my favorite Korean restaurant in SF! Such a hidden gem. 

The place is pretty small so the wait will be long if you have a large party (over 4). The hubby and I try to go outside of peak dinner hours and that usually works out really well for us.

We usually order the fried chicken, seafood bibimbap, and 2 "house" pancakes. The pancakes are not technically on the house but I believe they used to be; the term is just now used to refer to the plain pancakes (no meat or seafood, just onions).

My main love of this place is the pancake sauce. I have no idea how they make it but I LOVE LOVE LOVE it. It's an awesome mixture of tangy spice that just hits the spot. I use it with the pancake and the fried chicken. 

Oh and the banchan is pretty good too. Thumbs up for the fish cake and bean sprouts.
author: Gina H.

description:
I enjoyed this place. 3.5 stars rounding up to 4. Good food, service, and atmosphere.

Came here on a rainy day right when it opened and was craving soup because it was so cold out. For two, we ordered the rice cake, dumpling, and egg soup (#17), kalbi, and the seafood pancake. I wanted to get the chicken too, but figured this was too much food.

The seafood pancake was really good!! Super big and tasty. Although it did start feeling doughy after eating more than one piece. Without the dipping sauce it is a bit bland. But enjoyed it and would definitely get it again.

The kalbi was a bit small in portion for the price ($25). We thought it would come with a soft tofu soup but it didn't. Maybe because we already ordered a big soup? The meat was good and fatty tasting. 

The soup was nice and broth was flavorful. Next time I would skip the rice cakes. They also started to feel doughy.
author: Christina G.

description:
By the look of the storefront, you wouldn't think this inconscpicuous place would have such great Korean food. Tried this place with friends on a Thursday evening at 6:15 pm and there was no wait. Cozy tables and chairs inside make you feel like you're inside someone's living room. We got the seafood pancake, a soup (I forgot what), and the infamous fried chicken wings.

- Seafood pancake = yum and they didn't skimp on the seafood! Wish they had oyster sauce or Hoisin sauce on the side, it would have been perfect
- Soup: Got it mild, great with the rice
- Fried chicken wings = amazing crunch!

Would definitely hit up this spot again.
author: Wendy L.

description:
The best tasting fried chicken is known to be found here at this Korean restaurant. I have to say that it is a good place to be here with your friends grabbing some good Korean food.

The look of the restaurant outside seems to look big, but actually it really isn't cause it is small and tight. When I came here to eat with a big group.. it felt very tight and it felt as we were hugging each other.

I recommend for you to hit this place up and to give it a try!
author: Brittany L.

description: Great tasting authentic Korean food. So far my go to place for Korean food in the Sunset District. Had the seafood pancake, japchae, fried chicken, and tofu soup. Everything was flavorful and had just enough spice to keep you eating. This is a very popular local Korean restaurant and for good reason.  Most of their dishes are fairly priced and tasty.
author: Moore G.

description: So far my go to place for Korean food in the Sunset District. Had the seafood pancake, japchae, fried chicken, and tofu soup. Everything was flavorful and had just enough spice to keep you eating. Staff was friendly and checked up on us.
author: Allen L.

description:
I love it here!! They always give FREE fried chicken :) I always see people waiting outside during dinner time on Friday nights so be careful. 

My typical order is the spicy tofu soup that comes with rice and an order of broiled fish. You have to try the broiled fish (I believe it's mackerel) with lemon squeezed on top. It's delicious and a HUGE piece but be careful there are some bones! 

The service is okay, they weren't super attentive when we needed a water or side dish refill. However, they weren't stingy in giving us side dishes because we kept asking for more :).

There was one time I remember requesting a to-go order but they pretty much turned me away by saying there are too many people and it'll take too long. I guess they were being considerate but they just turned down business! 

All and all, great place! I would give it a try!
author: Sabrina L.

description: Overpriced and for no reason. Ordered Bulgogi and japchae. The $22.50 bulgogi was dry, bland and tasted burnt. The japchae was also bland, the vegetables undercooked, and had poorly chosen cuts of meat. Had high hopes since it has a 4 star rating, but was thoroughly disappointed.
author: Nikko V.

description:
this is definitely one of the best Korean restaurants in the city.  

it's a small place so the wait can be a bit long on the weekends..

everything is in take-out containers for lunch..

generally friendly staff..

must try the fry chicken and kalbi.  perfection!
author: Shanny Q.

description:
I really like SPICY food, which is why I like Korean food.  However, I suppose this is a very rare Korean restaurant where nothing is spicy.

I wanted to really like this place because of it's proximity to where we live.  Instead of driving to Richmond to go to my favorite Korean restaurant, Jang Soo BBQ.  Unfortunately, I'm not even sure this passes as Korean food?  I ordered 3 dishes: seafood pancake, squid tteokbokki and beef bulgogi.  They gave us a tofu soup on the house, which was very nice, however, I can't even bring myself to like that.  For two people, we spent $60, which I felt like we were robbed especially since the quality of food was not even close to what I would expect from a decent Korean restaurant.  

Let's start with the banchan.  There was kimchi, mung bean sprout, pickled radish, cucumber, fish cake and braised black soy beans.  The kimchi was not even remotely spicy.  It's red like it is suppose to, but I'm not sure where the heat has gone? The pickled radish was tough to chew, which leads me to think it was expired or perhaps left out for too long? I've never had pickled radish like this before.  The fish cake and cucumber were decent, so I gobbled these up since I was famished before I arrived.  

The seafood pancake came out and it was huge!  I took one bite and the texture was bizarre.  It was gummy and felt like I was eating a paste, so I thought it was undercooked.  In order to test my theory, I was taking bites out of the corners of the pancake, where it *should* be the most cooked, however, I think this is just the texture their pancake is suppose to be.  The only thing that was good was the vinegar dipping sauce that was paired. 

The squid tteokbokki (rice cake) was a mess.  It wasn't even cooked with gochujang (chili paste), which is the fundamental ingredient in most Korean dishes.  Instead, it was drenched with chili oil and chili pepper flakes and it wasn't spicy.  I had to literally wipe off the chili oil with each rice cake. 

The beef bulgogi and tofu soup was fine and decent in comparison to the other two dishes we ordered. 

Perhaps this place is a haven for those who cannot eat spicy?
author: Colleen L.

description: as a korean, this was an okay restaurant. the wait was long and the food was just decent, but considering that there are barely any korean restaurants in sf, this is okay. i know im saying "okay" a lot, but i dont think the food was the best; as some of the dishes have an MSG-y taste.
author: Rebecca B.

description: We are visiting from Hawaii. We know Korean food and this is really good. The place was jammed with local patrons. We had a great time with table mates that we met there. Portions are generous and the food fresh. They even gave us a great hot pot soup on the house. Loved it.
author: Beautiful F.

description: Love this place. Small hole in the wall, but service is great. Waitress, though by herself was able to take care of everyone well...WITH A BEAUTIFUL SMILE. Food is good, price reasonable. Especially love the fried chicken.
author: Zarah L.

description:
This place is a little hole in the wall restaurant, just the type of place I like!  Upon walking in I could tell this place was authentic.  I don't even like kimchi, and their kimchi was the best.  I would go back for that alone.  We also ordered the kalbi; it was very tender.  The fried mackerel was similar in taste and texture to a really good hamachi kama.  The complimentary tofu soup was awesome.  The fried chicken last but definitely not least.  It was a huge portion, looked like a whole chicken.  My only complaint with the chicken is it tasted a tad flat, could have used some salt and or a sauce.
The waitress was very nice.  She gave us really good recommendations and an extra helping of all the yummy little side dishes.
author: Krystal R.

description: I love this place. My favorite Korean restaurant EVER. And I live in LA where there's a plethora of Korean eats! I always have to come here whenever I'm back in town visiting my folks. My friends and I pretty much order the same thing every time. Beef bulgogi, pork bulgogi, chicken teriyaki, and the green onion pancake. Sometimes we'll add the fried chicken or the jap chae.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I got the bulgogi lunch take out which is $10, comes with rice and a bunch of Korean side dishes. The bulgogi meat was top notch and cooked properly. The sides were typical.

The only negative thing was that the bulgogi sauce was a bit tasteless which is probably healthier. I wish they had the side dishes I liked though!
author: Alfonso C.

description: This resturant isn't so bad but I know why it's only 3 and a half stars. It is a little pricy I saw the regular price for kalbi (Korean bbq beef short ribs) it was $25 but if you come during lunch they have a special which only cost $9.95. There lunch special is from 12:00pm-2:30pm. It came with veggies and rice and the meat it's self. It wasn't a lot but it's more like a little snack because I'm still hungry. The kalbi was pretty good too since they already cut the meat up and serve it to you.
author: Kayla W.

description:
This is a very small and homely restaurant, something I'd expect to eat if I ever went to my imaginary Korean aunt's house. The portions are large and the flavors are not trying to knock my tastebuds out of the park - I normally drink multiple glasses of water when dining out, but I didn't even need a sip until the end of my meal, so it seems like it's a lot less sodium-laden than restaurants these days!

Unfortunately a couple of the items did need a little more flavor. This place seems to be known for their yangnyem tongdak, the "deep fried chicken with house special sauce", which excessively confuses me unless "house special sauce" meant "no sauce". The chicken tasted like robust fried chicken (only crunchy in a few spots, and tougher skin) with no seasoning, and although it was a bit tender and okay to eat, just seems confusing or lackluster with no taste. On the bright side, there was a buttload of chicken - pretty much a full silver platter full of it - and it was very filling, so yay leftovers!

The soft tofu stew had plentiful nice, soft, silky tofu, but was bland. However, it came on the house and was a nice gesture and well appreciated and enjoyed. I thought the banchan was tasty and seemed fresh and juicy - they had a total of seven which included bean sprouts, cucumber, fishcake, Japanese pickled daikon with some chili powder, some type of shriveled black beans, kimchi, and the white Korean pickled radish. The haemul pajeon came with a yummy red-hued dipping sauce, with a lot more scallions and chili powder in it than I'm used to being served - although it wasn't spicy. The seafood pancake itself was very thick and large while still maintaining a good cooked consistency, as sometimes it gets too doughy, and had decent seafood amount. It also had a lot more egginess to it than usual which I thought was a good thing, and it just tasted really good with the sauce. The dolsot bibimbap was colorful and had a lot of veggies; my only complaints would be for the carrots that were cut too long and thick, and for the bowl that was not hot enough to make the rice as crispy as it could have been. Finally, we had the japchae which uses skinnier noodles but had good flavor, was not too sticky and not too wet, and had delicious chewy warm texture.

This place would get a solid three and a half stars from me, mostly rounded down due to the blandness of some items. This would be a good place for lunch as their lunch menu is very well priced and is observed even on Saturdays, however it is only for takeout. I really enjoyed dining here and would revisit for the quantity and wholesomeness of the food!
author: Amy Y.

description: Seafood pancake from this place is my favorite! Been coming here about twice a month. Good food.
author: Jayce T.

description: I like everything about this place! It's reasonably priced, the portion is big, the appertizers are tasty. It's one of the best restaurants I have found. Would definitely be coming back. So sad I don't live in the neighboorhood, otherwise I would have been here more often : (
author: Hazel B.

description: Great Korean Cuisine. It is at a great location, and the food is outstanding. The price is very reasonable, and the quality of the food is consistent. The portions are very generous. If you are looking for a good Korean Restaurant in the City, this is a great choice!
author: Justin C.

description: My favorites were the Sogogi Sundobu ( Soft tofu with beef stew) and the fried chicken. Don't be scared by the color of the stew. It looks spicy but it really isn't. It has fantastic flavor.
author: Jena L.

description:
It's time to update my review. Really like this place. Though I moved out of the neighborhood, I come back often not for the food but also for the atmosphere.  Nice authentic Korean food as always. (Though I believe the owner probably Americanizes the menu a bit).  The classic rice noodle could have been spicier lol 

The staff are all very friendly.(I believe it's a family business). I like the owner a lot. She is super nice and hard working. Everyone I come by, I would try to say hi.  Anyway, if you ever come visit sf, you definitely try this place out!
author: Alanda B.

description:
What they said.  Get here early, or come late.  Wait can be long as it's not a very big place.

Also, be prepared to smell like what you're eating.

Ordered the Korean Fried Chicken.  Huge portion.  Not dry and not too greasy for something fried.

Tofu Soup.  Recommended.
author: Margaret W.

description:
Honestly, I was actually trying to eat at Toyose, especially since it's been a few years since I've eaten out of the garage, but the wait was long and with a long drive back to my parents' house, we had to compromise.  My friend recommended Shin Toe Bui Yi, which is also in the Outer Sunset, and quite the hidden gem.  It's definitely busy but it's nice to stumble upon a restaurant that doesn't have a long wait or too many issues with parking AND has good food.  

We got there around 8, and we didn't have a wait.  The side dishes were solid and plentiful, and they gave us a hefty piece of broiled fish on the house.  We ordered the fried chicken, a tofu soup, and a rice cake and vegetable dish.  I didn't really think the fried chicken was anything special, but it was comparable to other Korean fried chicken I've had.  I felt like it was missing something, but it was still good.  The tofu soup was good and not too spicy.  I always like rice cake and I thought it was well done here; it was chewy and served with glass noodles and some vegetables.  The place is great and it's now on my list of places to recommend.
author: Debra C.

description:
One of my favorite Korean restaurants in the city! I love their spicy squid, fried chicken and bulgogi. I usually get their lunch specials, and the lady working during lunch time is really nice. I would say the price is reasonable compared to other Korean restaurants in the city. 

The service is a hit and miss. One time I went, there was a really nice server. Another time, the server misheard us and gave us the wrong food and didn't refill our tea and banchan. :( 

But overall, I love this place!
author: Rebecca L.

description: If you want fried chicken, this is the place to go!  If you want other items, best to go somewhere else.  I also love the complimentary spicy tofu soup
author: Samorn S.

description:
TL;DR: it's the first Korean restaurant I've been to where nothing tasted good. Don't come. Pricey esp considering its quality.

My roommate and I ordered beef short ribs, seafood pancake, spicy stir fry rice cake and beef dumpling and egg soup and the bill came out to a whopping 78$ after tips. 

The small dishes managed to be bland yet salty. Seafood pancake was all batter, overshadowing the seafood to a point where we really wondered if we mistakenly ordered plain pancakes. Rice cake, short ribs and soup all tasted off to me - perhaps it's their uniqueness. Grease is a big theme of this place if that's what you are into. You can still taste dishwashing detergent on their cups.

I think this place survives because it's one of the few Korean restaurants in the neighborhood. That said, my roommate told me she knows a few friends that like this place. Maybe my taste buds were off because I had a really bad headache when I came here, but I won't give this place another try since it managed to become the worst Korean food dining experience I've ever had by far.

(Service was fine and fast, and we got a few pieces of grilled cod on the house)
author: James A.

description:
Do SFSU volleyball players still have that t-shirt saying "We'll run a train on that _____ !"? Ask them when you go here. Turns out I'd visited before with a crew of Gators, after some dance practice or BBQ sale or karaoke or something. Today's quest for lunch led me back.

The lunch menu (from 12-2:30 pm) is by to-go box only and is a reduced selection of 17 items. That might sound small, but there were at least three things on it that I need to try. I got minmuljangeo deopbap ("Janguh Dupbap: broiled fresh water eel and vegetables over rice"). Maybe I'll wind up here again for the other boxes sometime.
author: Dan B.

description:
Some dishes are really good like 53 (calamari with veg and something that seemed rice cakey) on the menu, but others are mehh. We ordered soup and made sure to request "extra spicy" but we didn't get extra spicy and the soup had no flavor. 

The service was ok they were nice, but bc the place is so busy you can tell they're a bit flustered. That's all okay! I will deff come back in future.
author: Kaitlin V.

description: They have be best korean fried chicken  . Love their sautéed spicy  calamari rice cake  .
author: Wilma C.

description:
The elusive 5th star... Not sure why I can't give Shin Toe Bul Yi 5 stars... I love the place. But something is lacking... can't figure it out though...

Love their fried chicken. Bib Bim Bop is great! All the meats are good too... nothing to exciting I guess... maybe that's the 5th star... no wow factor. 

Quick tip: go early or late... expect a wait during peak dinner times.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Get here early if you don't want to wait!! I came here last night with my parents around 5:30 and found a few tables still empty, but by the time we got our food there were already a bunch people waiting outside for a table. I drive by this place almost everyday and ALWAYS see a crowd of people waiting.   

We weren't that hungry so we just ordered the Korean fried chicken like everyone suggests, jap chae, and a beef soft tofu soup and to our surprise the helpings were very generous! They also give you a bunch of little side dishes.

Korean fried chicken- looked like a whole chicken cut up into smaller pieces and then deep fried. Just ok, moist, but it comes plain without any seasoning or sauce. 

Jap chae- flavorful and the noodles had a good chewy texture. CAUTION: lots of green onions!! 

Beef tofu soup- probably one of the best I've ever had! It had A LOT of meat as well as mushrooms, onions, and zucchini, and had the perfect amount of spice.

Overall we enjoyed it very much, especially the b

Can't wait to come back and try the seafood pancake and bibimbap!
author: Linz C.

description:
Okay so I want to update my review because my first review was not based on a whole lot. I came here for the first time and for two people though the food was decent the tab was too high. 

Now after coming here two more times I can gladly say this is now my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. Every time I come here I'm greeted with a pleasantly beautiful and sweet waitress(s). Each time I came back here I ordered the Haemul Pajeon (seafood pancake) and Spicy calamari with spicy rice cakes. The taste has been superb where the portions feel plentiful. If the size of the entrees were not enough they spoil you with a variety of banchan side dishes, free rice, and the best part......free Soon du bu jjigae!! On the house!   

So the first time I came here I realize the bill was so high because we ordered two soju bottles. lols. Yes Soju at korean restaurants in the US are way out of scale compare to Korea where its like $1 for a bottle instead of $10.

The 2nd time I came here was with just one other friend. We ordered Haemul Pajeon and Bibimbap and beer. Total came to $33+tax  and we couldn't finish all the food and banchan so we had to take leftovers to go.

The third time just this past friday I took two other friends who are native koreans and they also agree the kimichi rocks and the portions is plentiful. Despite our large appetites we still could not finish all the food and had to unfortunately leave some of the korean goodness to waste. 

In retrospect this is favorite Korean restaurant in SF. I don't know if the service and quality has always been this great but I'm luvin it. Esp since this place is located so conveniently in the sunset.
author: Jude N.

description: I came here with a couple of friends, so of course we tried the fried chicken. It was delicious! And I'm glad they put the sauce on the side. I prefer not putting it on so the chicken can stay nice and crispy. It was perfectly cooked. In addition to the fried chicken, I had the dolsot bibimbap. That was pretty tasty, as well.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I must have passed by here a million times on the train but never thought to stop by even when I had a Korean craving. Well, I did have a craving and it was time to pay them a visit.

We started off with the traditional side dishes, of which there were many. It was hard to pick a favorite because they were all good, but I would have to go with the tofu and the pickled radishes. There are a few items that you simply have to get when you come here, such as the fried chicken and seafood pancake. Just about every table had those two items and naturally we ordered them as well. Both were so good! The spiced chicken was piping hot and not oily at all and the giant pancake was crispy on the edges, just as I like. This restaurant is known for giving you a free dish depending on what you ordered, and we got the free spicy tofu soup. This was the only dish we could finish and was absolutely delicious. The tofu was so soft and fresh!

The portions here are extremely generous and this meal could easily have fed 4 people. The service is really spotty since there's only one person running the front of the house so expect a pretty long dinner. I loved this place and will definitely be back, but with more friends this time.

Food: 9/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
I called to place a rake out order. The lady told me it's too busy and will not take orders. What?! It's 5pm only. And when I asked if I can order and pick up later on she hung up on me. How rude.

By the way. Don't get the beef short ribs. It's not edible. You will chew forever.

Do get the spicy pork, and the deep fried chicken wings (they are known for). I tend to ask for more dark meat, as the white meat taste dry. Their jap chae is decent as well.
author: David H.

description:
I've been here a handful of times but never for dinner, so this is reviewed for lunch only.

The thing about this place is that they only do takeout for lunches. Once in the past I've been able to order something for "takeout" but eat it in the restaurant out of the takeout box, and I've seen other people do that. It was probably their way of not having to clean plates and utensils for their short lunch hours. But recently it doesn't seem like people dine in here at all for lunch, so maybe now they just straight up don't want people eating here until dinner.

They have a lunch special menu which is a lot cheaper than their regular dinner menu. I believe everything on it is just under $10, whereas prices for food for dinner start getting into the double digits, typical of what you would see at other places. The food I've tried here is decent, but not something you'd rave about. Just recently I had the kalbi lunch special, where the meat didn't taste like it was marinated well. But it wasn't as chewy or difficult to eat as I've had at other local places, so at least that was good. Also, because of the takeout policy, the banchan they give is limited to whatever they can fit into the smaller sections of the takeout box. Don't expect a lot of variety here.

It's hard to gauge how busy this place actually is during lunch because it's takeout only so the only people around are just people waiting for their food to be ready. And I always get really thrown off by the size of this place when I walk in because the way the mirror is situated, it makes the restaurant look twice as big as it actually is.
author: Allen C.

description:
Despite the tattered store front, don't let the exterior deter you. Shin Toe Bul Yi is among one of the hidden gems in the outer sunset area.

Some of the noteworthy house specials to try would be:
* Fried Chicken- breaded and fried to perfection, crispy layers while maintaining all that juiciness on the inside with every bite. We ordered it because we saw it practically on everyone else's table. Aside from the usual drumstick and thighs, this dish also consisted of what seemed to be a whole chicken. 

*Seafood pancake- usually NOT one of my favorite Korean dishes, but this was surprisingly well executed. Crispy in texture, not too doughy, and was loaded with seafood. The house sauce served with it really complemented it as well.

* Broiled mackerel - complimentary- a WHOLE mackerel super moist and soft in texture, seasoned to perfection. Plus, it's FREE. Deal- sealed.

This was definitely a carb -loaded feast for my friends and I. In the midst of gluttony, the 3 of us also had jap chae, spicy rice cakes, spicy seafood tofu stew,  and I'm sure there's a couple more items I don't recall or rather not disclose, but I have nothing, but praises to sing for each of those dish.SF isn't limited in its Korean restaurants, but I must admit Shin Toe Bul Yi is one of the top ones on my list.
author: Ada C.

description:
This place is definitely a authentic Korean joint. 

I love the tofu soups, bulgogi beef plates, and bimimbap.

The quality of this place is good, fresh, and tasty. The prices range from $10-20 and comes with many of your favorite sides. 

I highly recommend getting the lunch combos. Everything is less than $10 for a box of meat, veggies, and rice and it's PACKED with goodies. Long lines too during lunch.
author: Adam J.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night and the line wasn't too bad.  We arrived around 7 and there were 4 parties ahead of us.  Now... about the food.  It was good BUT not the best thing ever.  I'd skip the spicy pork next time because it was soooo fatty and thin.  You could literally see the grease dripping off. Meep.  Also, it wasn't that spicy, pretty sweet.  Kalbi and bulgogi were good though. We also ordered the Korean fried chicken since everyone else got it and our server recommended it as well.  It was fried well, but super plain. It said it came with a special spicy sauce, but that wasn't accurate.  It was just salty, plain, fried chicken.  Quite disappointing so I'd definitely skip that.

Portions are pretty good, but it's pricey.
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
I love the soft tofu stew and seafood pancake.
It is really delicious.
I have eaten many times.^^
author: Kelly C.

description:
We had one of the worst meal in our lives here. 
Beef broth was gamey. I know it's "beef broth" but even the Safeway beef broth tastes better. 
Steamed monk fish was disgusting. You cant really tell you're being served monk fish because it's buried under mountains of bean sprouts. It also comes with mystery fish parts that taste like soap. 
The only good thing ( thank God) we had was bbq ribeye. 
They worst part of our awful meal was the wait. There was only one girl serving 20+ people. She was doing one hundred things at once.  We got served but that's it. Nothing got refilled. We couldn't ask her what was that mystery awful thing in our monk fish. We got a cup with lipstick on it and had a hard time to get her to gives a new cup cause she was serving 20 other people.  She was very quick to bring the bill though. 
If you see people waiting outside, it's not because this place has great food. People are waiting outside because there is only one server serving other 20+people and doing one hundred things at once. 
We are not coming back here!
author: W C.

description:
Pretty standard prices for a Korean restaurant. Just dont come here when it's rush hour; saw the line when we left and there was a crowd in the cold... lol Thankfully, I came in with a friend and there was a space conveniently for 2! If the price is high at this place, expect a large portion (except for soups and bibimbap 'cause portions for those are fixed). This place is super cramped because they maximized the space for more people to fit which is fine by me. Rush hour must be a pain in the butt. The waitress is really sweet and I was teaching my friend some Korean phrases which included 'hello' and she came over because she thought we were calling her over OTL. so embarrassing.
The bathroom is pretty grimey but it doesnt phase me; as long as it works. Just wish they had a hook so I can hang my bag or jacket.

On a different note, isnt this place called Shin Toe Bul Gi or naw? It's been 2 months since I've been so idk.
author: Victoria H.

description: I love the fried chicken -- such a large plate and so delicious. But the short ribs are just okay.
author: SJ L.

description: Neighborhood restaurant nothing special. Not up to par like most Korean spots. I found the fried chicken to be bland and not that good. The spicy pork is ok and the seafood pancake tasted like there was too much flour or dough. Ok spot if you want Korean food but I probably will go elsewhere.
author: Larry L.

description:
REKINDLED MY FEELINGS WITH AUTHENTIC KOREAN (Food)
(4.5)

Its been awhile since i've dashed my way to the sunset for the best korean food i've had. I've introduced this spot to more people and its been the hit. 

Please do not be discouraged when the owners confuse you when they say "to go box for lunchie". What they really mean "we will not server you real plates during lunch on weekends, you can still eat at the restaurant your food will just be served in to go boxes". I see people in and out confused they they can only order to go and not sit at the restaurant.

ORDER (family Style)
- Soup (i forgot which one) - delicious. not spicy. had pot stickers, noodles, and green onion. 
- Plate of fried chicken - YES definately a plate to order. 
- Plate of bolgogi - everyone loved it and was amazed how it was prepared. aint nothing like it, ANYWHERE
- Broiled Mackrel - delicious. and they served a side of pickled-radish. goes well with the mackrel.
- Free Korean sides - i think i can eat the side dishes forever in a day.

I found some dislikes...
The to-go boxes were just a turn-off. not sure if the owners want to wash dishes or what. we had to rip parts of the to-go boxes and make plates out of them (and eating in the restaurant). kind of pathetic but it is what it is.

You have to pay when you order. she doesnt come to you, you go to the resgister and order AND PAY. we get confused where and when to leave the tip? why tip out early, we dont know if the service is good. just saying.

Will i be back? especially for the bulgogi AND fried chicken

Until the next review......
author: Jane A.

description:
Decent Korean food, not the best I've had...nor the worst. My friend and I were the only people the entire hour we went. 

I opted for #11 on the lunch special menu - marinated short ribs with egg over rice. I wish I knew that it would end up more like fried rice. It literally was egg fried rice with the kalbi meat, carrots, and onions mixed in. Lunch is "to go" only but you can opt to dine in and have it served on metal lunch trays. Each lunch special comes with its own set of banchan - kimchi, daikon, fish cake, bean sprouts, and cucumber. 

The interior of the restaurant is dated, has very mixed decor like an Aztec piece on one side and potted plants/nautical pictures on the other. It's also pretty dark inside...all in all, the food's not bad, but I might just have to give it another go on another day.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Environment: Medium sized, don't be thrown off by the mirror walls! Smells good when one is starving, but smells bad when you are not. 

Food: decently good, fresh and quick Korean food! However, the fried chicken that everyone is raving about at this place was really dry.  

Price: Not too expensive; about ~$10 for Bibimbap bowls, ~$15 for beef plates like Bulgolgi, Ribs, and complementary Spicy Tofu Soup! 

Service: On par! Because of the size of the restaurant, it was easy to see people who needed a refill on Korean side dishes or refill on water! 

In conclusion, I would come back when craving for Korean food!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
One of thee best Korean food I've ever had!
Definitely can not compare to a lot of places I've been to. (no offense)
I've been craving Dok Bok Ki for HELLA LONG, and totally needed it.
Girls and I really craved some and decided to order it to go since they are normally PACKED. But once we got there, there was a couple tables open! Probably because it was a Monday night haha.
We were greeted by a nice Korean lady that was confused about us asking her if we can have a table even though we ordered to go: either way, she was nice!
Sat down and we got the usual yummy appetizers :) ordered Dok Bok Ki, Bim Bim Bop, and Seafood Pancake, and they gave us Spicy Tofu Soup on the house! AWESOME!
The bill came out to be $39.40 and we left her a $5 tip so we paid $15 each. Not bad for a bloated meal! We were all dying with our food babies and still had some left over!
author: Linda K.

description:
Had to wait and is not the cleanest place.
The food though is worth the wait.
The Kalbi was delicious and so was the spicy tofu soup......but the fried chicken is a must if you go!
Crispy, delicious, amazingness is what they're making in that kitchen.
author: Shelby S.

description: I love their marinated pork and chicken. This is by far my favorite korean restaurant in san francisco.
author: Zachary H.

description:
Slow service during lunch hour. DO NOT come here if you are hungry or in a rush 

Price leans toward the pricey side for Korean food...a seafood pancake plus a tofu bowl plus a rice place neared 40 bucks.

The tofu soup and bulgogi was only okay...the seafood pancake though was pretty good
author: Long C.

description:
I consider this Parkside restaurant a gem.  There is nearly always a line, which i believe speaks more to the quality of the food than the speed of service which, admittedly, could be slow at times.  In any case, the food is well worth the wait.  My wife and I have introduced family and friends to the place, and they have quickly become regulars.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the Korean-style fried chicken is a must order.  The crust is perfectly crisp with just the right amount of salt and spice, and the meat tender and juicy without being greasy.  The mackerel is outstanding - grilled to a slight crisp on the outside, but tender, moist and flavorful inside.  Best of all, it comes with a free side of mild-to-spicy tofu soup, which our kids love.  I am less enthused by the japchae, Korean-style glass noodles, which are a bit too oily for my liking.  An added plus is they will give you a pitcher of water so you can refill your own cup whenever you'd like.

So, go expecting a line and go expecting great food.  But just go.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I like it.

I've been wanting to come here for a while. I've passed by it many times, but never had the chance. I finally had the chance today.

It was rather confusing when I saw the sign...it said something like lunch orders in boxes, so I didn't know if I could eat in or not. It actually meant they give you plastic lunch containers and you can eat inside if you like. The inside looks much smaller than I imagined. Real Korean workers & real Korean customers, which is pretty authentic in my book.

For 2 of us, we ordered:
- $8 bulgogi lunch special http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Dy4FqsShb-I6uSiLEOibBw?select=EXDrhVXx83qhynImRGQoBg
- $10.99 seafood pancake http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Dy4FqsShb-I6uSiLEOibBw?select=-d42x9QTwoj33TZf6zlpqA

The bulgogi was good, can't complain.
Seafood pancake came with sauce that tasted like hot cheetos, weird but good. The pancake was also much larger than I expected.
All of the food wasn't too spicy, I liked it. 

The portions are a lot larger than I expected, good thing I didn't order more. I was starving when I came in, but still managed to not eat all of it....strange. Lots of leftovers, so we brought it home and ate for dinner. Seafood pancake isn't that good as a leftover, much better when it's fresh.
author: Kylie L.

description:
Didn't seat us until the whole party was present. Service was friendly. Seats were attacked by grease, but oddly enough, it doesn't wipe off... a lil more dirty feeling than i would like. Price is very fair!

Food:
Fried whole chicken- super delish flavor and super juicy.
tofu soup- good
kalbi- It was good, but wasn't feeling like eating too much red meat that day. 
jap jae- very good. has a good unique taste, maybe it's cause i'm comparing it with the ones you buy at a korean market. (& it definitely does not compare).
pork knuckles (small order)- LOVED & fun to eat. Small order was HUGE! came with some bean paste, lettuce and orange sauce with lil mini shrimplings (baby shrimp [?] idk what its called) in there. 
Ban chan (complimentary)- loved the yellow pickled something and the regular pickled daikon and the lil anchovies.
author: Tina S.

description: We are 2 people and want to order special roasted meat but the waitress Do Not let us do that! Why? Just need an answer but she refused. I hope everyone can enjoy their business attitude! Simple and quick. This is my review!
author: Young L.

description:
Went there for takeout on the weekend close to their opening time for dinner. I was turned away because it was "too busy". I have never been turned away from ordering takeout from a restaurant, let alone because it was "too busy". Typically, at restaurants for takeout (regardless of being busy or not), they will just shutupandtakemymoney.jpeg, however Shin Toe Bul Yi did not this time? It looked like most chairs were full in the restaurant, however there weren't people outside waiting, which sometimes there would be.

Unfortunately, since I live further away from the city now, I will no longer come here as I have for the past 3 to 4 years because it's now in my head that I can be turned away in the event that it's "too busy". All it takes is that one time. This is truly unfortunate since the food is pretty good, however the one star reflects the fact that I won't come here anymore.

I rarely write reviews, but thought people should know that if they're "too busy", you may just get turned away.

Yes, you could totally just call ahead of time, however if you're like me and you don't plan for things, such as heading home and passing a place you typically like to eat at, you don't think about calling first. 

Yes, you could just sit and dine in, that's if they're not "too busy" to take your money, however for me, I prefer taking my food home and enjoying it there along with my home entertainment.

TL;DR you may not get served here if they're "too busy" and you're there for takeout.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Maybe I'm being sensitive but I'm removing half a star and rounding downward based on an action by tonight's waitress at the end of meal. She put the check on my table, but then later she seemingly on purpose moved it more in front of me. Just because I was on my iPhone and hadn't yet attended to it. There wasn't even anybody waiting for a table at the time. It could be there was no intent to it but I felt pissed off.

I'll probably end up still going here just because its close to home. However, I hope someone at the restaurant reads this, understands what I'm saying, and see to it that she doesn't do this again.

Oh. and I did give less tip than I normally would have, and had thought about giving even less than what I did.
author: H K.

description:
I've been there many times (dinner only, curious about their lunches though..) and the food is pretty decent. Last time I had kimchee bibimbap (wish it had more beef though but it had lots of kimchee) and fried Korean fish was delicious too. always good and fast service!

update: korean pancake and bulgogi is very delicious


2016 Update: this place is so far the best Korean food and most authentic.
author: Dimi N.

description:
Love this place.  Always seem to end up getting the fried chicken.  Waiter usually brings an extra dish to the table "on the house".  Tofu soup is also good.  

I've never been able to get a table at Toyose on Noriega, so Shin Toe Bul Yi is my stand in.
author: Gopal R.

description:
Although this Korean restaurant offers several types of dishes, the only reason to come here is for their signature fried chicken with the special house sauce.  Everything else is cooked mediocre or better at other Korean restaurants.  The  pageon (seafood pancake) is thick with little seafood and no sauce.  The deonjang tzigae (tofu soup) is flavorful, but thin with high sodium instead of hearty with vegetables.  The kalbi is fatty, thick and chewy even when on the bone instead of being lean, thin and tender.  

Service is fast and friendly.  You'll likely get a complimentary dish of mackerel or something on the house for large orders.  Parking on the street can be tough, but is doable.  The ambiance is a simple, small  and clean Korean shop on the corner with no frills.
author: Jenny L.

description: We came for a Saturday lunch. Little did we know, they don't let you sit in for lunch from 12-3pm. So we ordered take out and ate in our car. The food has a lot of flavors. I love the kimchee and glass noodles. We would come back again as the price is reasonable for big lunch portion.
author: Elaine C.

description:
A friend brought us here for dinner before an event. Since there are plenty of Korean places here, I was expecting the food to be your usual fare but I was pleasantly surprised to find that I really enjoyed the food. The place is teeny, there were two large-ish groups seated but were getting ready to go so the wait wasn't terribly long.

We got the fried chicken, tofu soup, and the seafood pancake. Everything was delicious, the chicken was crispy and not too oily, the seafood pancake was thick and tasty, and the tofu soup was flavorful and had real chunks of meat! Most places give you these sad little bits of meat in the tofu soup, but not here. We also got the side dishes and they even give you a fried fish. Obviously this was too much food for 3 people, but I'm not complaining since that means leftovers! 

I enjoyed the food here, only wish that I lived closer to dine here more often.
author: Cat H.

description: Spicy beef stew and the soondubu with seafood are great soups when you're hung over. The fried chicken was crunchy but nothing amazing and could use some sauce. Portion sizes here can easily be two person a dish. Very small family own shop that I would definitely come back to. The wait service was easy and food came out pretty quickly. The prices are fitting given the size of the dishes.
author: Thomas L.

description: Great spot, loved it! I've never had Korean food this good, definitely made me realize I just wasn't having the best Korean food.
author: Nick F.

description: We love this place! A great neighborhood spot that is a little cheaper then what you might find on Geary, but just as good. They have the best fried chicken I have had in SF!!!
author: dub g.

description:
Had the lunch special, Galbi Dupbap. Lunch is served differently from dinner. During lunch time, you order your food at the register and the little lady brings it out to you. They do serve the usual corn tea. This was my first time having korean in California, I was hoping it'd be comparable to NYC. Sadly it wasn't..the food was really mediocre. It came with 3 side dishes. The galbi was tossed with rice. It wasn't very flavorful. It was just bits of beef. At least there's no need to tip??

EDIT
Dinner time!!
My friend and I were craving for fried chicken so we vowed to give Shin Toe Bul Yi another shot since all you yelpers have been raving about it.

Big mistake again.. damn it you guys, why do you steer us wrong?!

Dinner is a different set up than lunch. Tip is required since the server takes your order aside from serving you tea and your entrees. Extra plus is the sundubu is free with your korean side dishes of kim chi, bean sprouts, cucumbers, etc. It also comes with a bowl of rice for each person in your party! I ordered the fried chicken and the octopus bok - um. Honestly, the fried chicken was mediocre. There was no taste or flavor, it was just texture. The skin was fried nicely, it wasn't oily or greasy. It was really crunchy. The chicken meat was moist and juicy, in fact water dripped off the chicken while I ate it. But it was lacking taste and flavor... The texture's there but where's the taste? Also the bok um was too greasy and oily. My friend mentioned that the side dishes were more flavorful than the fried chicken.. 

Honestly, I don't know what you San Franciscans are claiming about this place. Best korean food in town? Seriously??! This place is so average and mediocre..
author: Virginia Y.

description:
This place is always perfect for the cold weather in SF. They give you a piece of yummy fish along with the side dishes. They also give hot tea instead of water, but it's up to your request. I love the sauce that comes with the seafood pancake here! Their fried chicken is also hella BOMB! Try it with the sauce. 

I came here on Valentine's Day before and they didn't have enough chicken wings for an order and I was so sad that we couldn't get it because I was craving the wings. A moment later, the server comes out with some chicken wings for us on the house because it wasn't a full order! Thank you!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Talk about a tough restaurant name to remember!! 

Food: 
1) BiBimBap with kim chee and beef: Very good! Kim chee was a little more acidic/sour than I'm normally used to, but the beef and the rice was PERFECT. Very tasty and when mixed together with the red spicy sauce it was OH SO YUMMY! They lined the stone bowl with a little bit too much oil, which mostly got soaked into the rice, but that's probably why it made the dish so tasty..haha. 
2) Seafood casserole: DELICIOUS! Great blend of all the seafood ingredients! They really packed in tons of seafood and didn't skimp on the works! The broth was calibrated very well! 
3) Beef and Calamari sauteed: A little on the oily side, but very tasty. The beef was very tender and the calamari was very rubbery (like it's suppose to be). Just wish portions of this dish were a little bigger. 
4) Side dishes: nothing too notable. The kim chee was pretty good but everything else was ok. 

Service: 
Aside from taking our orders and bringing us our food, I really can't say she came around much to check on us to see if we needed any more tea or side dishes...so I'd say the service is a little below standards. 

Ambiance: 
Doesn't seat many, it's a very cozy and humble semi-hole in the wall. I think it had nice decor and good use of space. I think they did the best with what little space they had to work with and it came together pretty nicely. 

Price: 
I think it was a little more expensive than a typical korean place, the bill came out to be a little more than $50. Since my friend and I was able to finish all the dishes, I'd say it was a little smaller on portion size. But given how good the food was, I think this price is pretty reasonable. 

Overall: 
I'd love to come back to try a korean pancake! I love those things, I honestly don't know why I didn't order one today, but since I was pretty happy with the meal, I would be willing to come back and dine here again!
author: Amiee H.

description:
The food smells better than it really is.  It's just decent Korean food, a bit pricey.  I've had more memorable Korean food elsewhere.  
There's always a bit of a wait if you're not here early enough.
author: Karen L.

description: My family and I have had dinner here twice on a Friday night.  The first time ordered either the Dolsot or Kongnamul Bibimbap and it was a major disappointment.  I took two bites and packed it to go, hoping to revise it at home.  There was no flavor and very bland.  However, other dishes made up for it.  The fried chicken, ban chan dishes, and house soup have been consistently delicious!  Just writing this review makes me want to visit them again this Friday night.  One more thing, this is the ONLY place that I can actually eat and enjoy kimchi.  It does not have that bad and sour taste when biting into it.
author: Mie Mie M.

description: My gosh. Korean BBQ at its finest. I think this is my go to spot for sit down dinner when someone ask, "What do you want to eat?" Fair warning though, this place is small, so you are bound to wait outside the door :( Once you get in and seated, my gosh do they stockpile your order whether its the sides pancakes, the mouth-watering chicken, or soft-tofu soup.  I miss it already and can't wait to go back haha
author: Robert H.

description: My favorite dish to order is the Japchae - sauteed noodles with vegetables and beef and the Haemul Pageon - Korean style pancake with scallions and mixed seafood. The Japchae has this sweet and salty taste to it that I love! One of the reasons why I love kettle corn. There wasn't a lot of beef in it. I don't remember even eating any. The silver noodles were really good. Korean seafood pancake was hot, crispy and filled with calamari and shrimp! Its served with their special spicy sauce, I wish they gave us more of it because it was enough for only half the pancake. Other things we ordered was he fried chicken and soft tofu soup with seafood. The fried chicken was not so good because it tasted dry and bland. The tofu soup was not piping hot like what I'm used to. My family and I came on a Thursday night for dinner and there was only 1 waitress taking orders, serving, and busing the tables. Though the place is small, it can get really busy! I think this place serves more traditional Korean food and has a lot to offer on their menu. I think maybe lack of staffing can cause the quality to go down. Also, the ventilation is poor so you will smell like Korean BBQ when you leave! So keep the nice clothes at home!
author: Janny S.

description: This place is not cheap and given the variable quality of the dishes, we will likely not return. The one good dish was the fried chicken; but they also threw in pieces that were mostly bones. The seafood pancake was the worst. Very gluey, and burnt on one side. The bibimbap had only a few pieces of beef and the vegetables had no seasoning. The non-Kim chee panchan also lacked flavor.
author: Karen L.

description: Best fried chicken I've had so far anywhere. I've read some of the reviews about service but this is a mom n pop place so what do you expect? Do your due diligence and call ahead if you want more of a sure thing like I do since i have to drive our of my way to get here. Leaving very happy with my 3 orders of friesd chicken Korean style....
author: Collin L.

description: Be sure to write your name and party size on the pad of paper located on the counter on the right just past the front door. Try their fried chicken, herrrrrrra good!
author: Roger E.

description:
It's kind of strange...in a few different ways, Shin Toe Bul Yi probably isn't the most amazing Korean restaurant in the city.  The outside sign is a bit tattered, the ambiance is just okay, and a few of the dishes won't appear to be mind blowing.  And yet, despite whatever shortcomings they may seem to have, the place is still so good!

I'm not sure what exactly it is that makes them so lovable, but their fried chicken dish might have something to do with it.  Whenever I'm there, I see it show up on people's tables more often than not.   It's not something unique to their menu, but they do theirs a little differently.  Instead of just the usual wings and drumsticks, they also include chopped up pieces from the breast and thigh.  Though it makes for some awkward looking pieces, the taste is spot on!  The batter can be a little thick, but it's got some flavor, the portion is generous, and the meat is moist (for the most part).

Beyond the fried chicken, the rest of their food is not too shabby, though nothing stands out as a star.  If anything, the haemul pajun (seafood pancake) would be the closest - loaded with a good amount of seafood, it wasn't too doughy and had a nice bit of crispiness.  Their broiled fish dishes are good, and the bulgogi is my favorite of their meats, but it's served as slices rather than chunks (it still tastes good though).  Sadly, I was disappointed with their kimchi jiggae (kimchi and pork stew) as it was too thin for my liking.

In addition to the usual array of banchan, I love that they hook you up with a free dish as well.  Depending on what you've already ordered, they'll usually give you a small pot of basic soon doobu, or a few pieces of mackarel(?).  Free food definitely goes a long way!  The fact that their food is consistent, the service is friendly, and the prices are pretty fair certainly don't hurt either.
author: Mike L.

description:
Noms! Second favorite Korean place in sf. 

I love this place. Its soooo good. Get the fried chick, of course. Galbi is yummy, much better than the bulgogi here. I normally like bulgogi but meh. The pancake is good, but it's a little too thick in my opinion, I still like it though!

Place gets packed since it's small so prepare for that!
author: Bianca W.

description:
Ambiance: very casual, well lit during the day.

Service: it's okay.
