Food: Most of my authentic Asian cuisine enthusiast friends rave about this place, so it is probably legitimately good. As a vegetarian, I am not great at rating Korean food, though the veg/rice/egg/sauce bowl I had was overly salty.
author: Lana L.

description:
When I first moved here I thought that only your Mexican food sucked, now I know it's Mexican AND Korean.  If this place was in LA I'd give it 1 star, but a little is forgiven since the bar is not that high in SF for Korean food.
Everything was bland - even the kim chi.
The seafood pancake was the only thing that saved the day but it was greasier than I like.
I also tried the fried chicken that everyone talks about - nothing special - it's just battered, fried and served with a dipping sauce.  No seasoning in the batter or anything.
Yukejang was just average and the Kimchi Bimbimbap was missing something .... oh yeah, flavor!
I don't know what the deal is with this place being so crowded on a Wednesday night - there was only one server for the whole restaurant!  Poor lady.
author: Michele S.

description:
So I finally tried the infamous fried chicken...

Dear god, I seriously think this is the best fried chicken I've had in SF.  And yes, it's from the random Korean restaurant in the Outer Sunset.  They give you a lot of chicken!  It's extremely juicy and hot, when it's delivered to your table.  AND it's battered perfectly.  My goodness, I have found the ultimate fried chicken.

Again, the hamul pajeon is DELICIOUS.  And being greeted by the massive ban chan of little plates of delectible goodies along with the free tofu soup just makes me so happy!

Sorry Wayfare Tavern and KFC, you gotta run for your money with the fried chicken that's here at Shin Toe Bul Yi!
author: Christine K.

description:
Hmmm...

We ordered quite a lot of food, and only about half of it was good.

Even the banchan was okay.

The daeji bulgogi (spicy marinated pork) was simmered in sauce and then steamed as opposed to being grilled...no grill marks, no grilled taste, and very strange steamed-meat texture.

The kimchee was lacking a lot of flavor, as if it was made then and there and given to us right away without waiting at least a few hours of fermentation.  My family makes 10 pounds of kimchi'd cabbage a week, believe me I know what delicious kimchi tastes like and the day we ate here, there was some bland ass kimchi.  It also lacked spice

The jok bal (simmered pork shanks) was very good.  The bean dip they gave, the funky sauce, the garlic cloves, the lettuce, everything was just delicious for this dish and was the saving grace for our dinner besides the friendly service and generous portions they gave (our leftovers last several more meals)

I will try this place again just to make sure it wasn't a fluke.... if it doesn't beat Toyose, My Tofu House or the Spot in terms of taste, can't say I'd come back
author: Christopher N.

description:
came here a while ago with my sister. Everyone here literally orders the fried chicken. so we decided to give it a try. There is nothing special about it at all. its battered, fried and crispy. the chicken is not marinated or seasoned or drenched in an kind of sauce like other korean fried chicken i have seen or tried.  the seafood bibimbap is pretty good, its very spicy with tons of seafood in it. the soft tofu soup comes for free when you hae dinner. the tofu as always is silky and delicious, absorbs the soup and tastes so good. 

If you give me the choice to come back here willingly, i probably wouldn't because of the fried chicken and the incredibly long wait.
author: Stella J.

description:
Year of 1999, I was fresh off the boat from South East Asian, lived with my sister on 32nd Taraval Avenue. She took me for dinner @ Shin Toe Bul Yi. It was the 1st time I tried Korean food and fell in love with it. (The best korean food in my own opinion in the Bay Areas)

Moving Forward, year 2015 have my own family. Going to Shin Toe Bul Yi always a treat for us. We love and enjoy the food so much, my older one (3 Years old) Love the fried chicken.

Food : 5 stars in my opinion (our favorite battered fried chicken, japchae( Korean clear noodle), Bulgogi (spicy pork), Plain Korean Pancake (Damn it, I am drooling now), Spicy tofu soup (Its on the house WOOHOO), Korean spicy ricestick with octopus, and the Mackerel fish.

Parking : Little bit hard (Street Parking)

Service : The waiter is friendly and she will notify you that most of the foods are extremely hot. (she would remind people with the kids be cautious with the hot foods), She's fast worker and really responsive) 5 stars with the service.

This place is always pack, expect waiting for at least 20 minutes during weekend especially dinner time. (But trust me it's worth the wait). 

 My Tips : Beat the crowd by come during early lunch or early dinner.
author: Agustino B.

description:
Nice family atmosphere and the service is friendly and usually efficient. Awesome soft tofu soup and bulgogi, mackerel and fried chicken are also tasty. Some of the more esoteric Korean entrees weren't to my palate but since I love the other stuff I stick with them. Side dishes are ample and tasty, as is the tea.

With few straightforward Korean restaurants around here easily accessible I rate this one among the best we have. Fair prices, tasty with good portions, and really nice servers that make you feel welcome and tended to.
author: T J.

description:
Not sure why this place is not rated higher but I've frequented this location and have never had a bad meal. The portions are outrageous. if you are only ordering for 2, would suggest limiting yourselves to 2 things.
We ordered kalbi, a scallion pancake, and fried chicken. The fried chicken alone is enough for 2. The kalbi is well seasoned and the scallion pancake is huge!!! Thicker than what I am normally used to but still good. The fried chicken comes with these sweet daikon! Only place where I have found these (no the usual yellow ones). 
The banchan (side dishes) are fresh and delicious. Comes with soonduboo!
author: Janice A.

description:
The food here taste like how the place looks. 

I've past by this place multiple times because my best friend actually lives a block away, but the exterior always disgusted me to ever want to venture into trying their food. The exhaust fan is covered in oil and gunk, and the windows and blinds are super dirty. Obviously they do not do any upkeep. 

So ok, since this place has a 4 star review with over 400 people, I'll give this place the benefit of a doubt. It has to good right? WRONG! This was the very first time Yelp reviews disappointed me. I'm sorry for all the ones who love this place, but this place serves disgusting food and possibly day(s) old food.

The day that I came in, it was fairly busy so my party and I had to wait about 20 or so minutes for a seat. I didn't mind the wait since I was anticipating that the food would be really good. We got seated at the corner table by the window and were surrounded by dead plants and an aloe vera that poked me in the head when i leaned back. There's also an almost dried up cactus in the corner. 

Services was alright, however they did forget our water, but the hugest disappointment was the food. Everything tasted old, and bland. All the banchan was tasteless and tasted old. Kimchi was dry and not spicy at all. And why is the oil for the anchovies banchan so jelly-like? It sits in a bright red liquid and I thought it maybe be spicy, but there was no spice. 

For our main course, we had the Kalbi, BBQ Chicken and Cod Roe tofu soup. EVERYTHING was all tasteless and under seasoned. The tofus soup was the worst. The roe was super dry and very hard and rubbery. The soup was super watered down and had no flavor. It is suppose to be spicy but there was no heat whatsoever. They used firm tofu versus soft which is what usually helps thicken the consistency of the soup. They also tossed in a whole sprig of cilantro or some herb but I couldn't tell because whatever green they tossed in had absolutely no flavor. There was no raw egg which usually tops this off. And it did not come boiling hot which is how tofu soups usually comes out. It was so unappetizing that I could not finish the food.

Everyone in my group was disappointed and it cost as much as really good Korean food at other places. 

This may be the harshest review I've had written, and whomever reads this may or may not think I'm crazy because there are at least 400 people who believe this place is good eats. But hey, give it a try and you be the judge. I did try to warned you though.
author: Vivian K.

description:
Sides are awesome!
Japchae had a lot of vegetables. But I wished it had more noodles too. 
Bulgogi was very render and the flavors are mild but very satisfying.
More expensive that the Korean food we normally order but I don't mind because the food is really top notch!
author: Kathryn H.

description:
Food = okay.  Everything is good in flavor but it's nothing spectacular to write home about.   

Short ribs = on the dry side.  
Daeji bulgolgi = okay.   
Seafood pajeon = good but it's missing the crispiness.
Korean Fried Chicken = lots of chicken.  Careful, lots of meat with fragments of bone!

Service = super friendly and helpful.

Prices = moderate.  

The portions are very generous!  I just wished that they did better in the flavor department.
author: Fannie S.

description:
This is the kind of unpretentious, incredibly delicious neighborhood restaurant that I save up my appetite to fully enjoy on weekend nights. 

Everything we've had there (Jap Chae, Seafood Pancake, Fried Chicken) have been fantastic, and come with a generous and interesting selection of ban chans, rice, and complimentary tofu soup for dinner. 

Service is always warm, and the decor is actually quite nice and welcoming inside, even though it's pretty non-descript from the exterior. Go there, go now!
author: julia k.

description: Great little hole in the wall sort of restaurant. Lunch time is only in a take out box format but you can still eat on the table there. Tasty and quality Korean food.
author: William L.

description: They have the best lunch specials for a decent price. I recommend the spicy pork which includes rice and some sides such as kimchi and cucumbers.
author: Edmond L.

description:
I still remember the night I ate here almost a year ago.

It was a cold, December night. Two of my friends and I went on a mini exploration/sight-seeing in San Francisco. A few hours later, all three of us were craving for glutinous rice cakes also known as dukbokki. I have never eaten at Shin Toe Bul Yi but both of my friends raved about their food. I'm always down to try new food so I agreed to call in and place an order of dubokki to-go. When we drove there to pick up the food, we thought better. Why are we ordering only one thing to-go when none of us had dinner? We changed our mind and decided to dine-in.

We ordered a hot tofu soup and a stone-pot bimbimbap with kimchi and beef. Everything was delicious! The banchan was good too. I don't know if there's refills on the banchan but my favorite was the fish cakes. Soft, sweet, and chewy. Yum. On a side note, because we initially ordered the dukbokki to-go, they served us the dukbokki in the to-go plastic box.  I was kind of turned off by that. I thought the taste would make up for it but it didn't. It was slightly under-cooked and it wasn't as spicy as I would've liked it. Overall, this place is above average and I would come again. Maybe the second time will be better!
author: Annie S.

description:
If you're not a local or if you've never visited, Shin Toe Bul Yi is pretty easy to miss. Even when I was pointed towards the direction of the shop across the street, it took me some time to notice the four Korean words of the shop's sign.

The place was full of customers when we walked in. We signed our names and were seated after a short wait. During our wait, I quickly scanned the tables to see what people had ordered. Almost every table had a huge order of fried chicken, so I decided that it was a safe bet to order that too.

After looking at the menu, we decided on the fried chicken, tofu soup with beef and bulgogi. We were served some side dishes, and fried mackerel that was on the house. The food was definitely not bad, but nothing special either. The bill came down to $55 with tips for two. Overall, typical Korean food that was good by all means, and decent portions, but don't think I'm in any rush to come back to the place.
author: Helen Y.

description:
If you were a native son of Korea, you would find my resume of korean dining truly credible.  They include:
1.  oz 
2.  sarang bang
3.  john snack and deli (which is a hybrid of korean and mexican)

Gleaning on my experience,it is easy to see how I am a connoisseur of the masters of marinated meats.  Doing KDer an xmas service and knocking down a restaurant off her endless bookmarks, we arrived at Shin To Bul Yi's door.  It was a monday night yet it was packed.  It is a very small restaurant and seems like it was converted from a residential house.  I advise going in groups to eat Korean food as it allows you to order more and sample each others plates.  We put our name on the list and huddled inside for warmth, staring at patron eating their food with doe eyes until we were shoo'd outside to wait in the cold.  Once seated, we ordered:

1.  bulgogi: By far the best dish.  It was perfectly marinated, tender and juicy.  The portions were generous where all 5 of us had our way with the dish.  If i had it my way, i would have taken this dish all for myself.

2.  kalbi: The kalbi was very flavorful.  There was a mention of how authentic this place was in terms of not being too Americanized.  The kalbi i love from john's snack and deli which comes in form of a kalbi burrito is very sweet.  Shin Toe Bul Yi's kalbi was subdued in sweetness and was also very good.  I preferred the bulgogi but there are no complaints about their kalbi.

3.  tofu soup: The tofu soup was given to us on the house.  It was good for a cold night and not spicy at all.  There were generous portions of tofu and a good complement to pour over the rice.

4.  fried chicken: The fried chicken was a house specialty and many yelpers have raved about it.  It is certainly good, but in controlled portions.  It is very fatty and rich and taste similar to KFC.  I could eat one or two pieces but after that, it was a little too much.

5.  seafood pancake: I didn't touch this as I don't really eat seafood outside of fish.  This dish came at the tail end of our dinner so everyone else was much too stuffed to really put a dent in it.  

6.  bimbimbap: My gf got the bimbimbap bowl for herself.  It is a rice bowl with kimchee, bulgogi, various vegetables and egg.  I am not a big fan of kimchee thus, wasn't as fond of this dish as she was.  However, she enjoyed it immensely.  

Because of my lack of experience in Korean cuisine, I relied more on my tastebuds.  The food was certainly very good but not the "zomg" level that all tastebuds recognize.  The service is okay here; there was one waitress for the whole place so it is only natural that things might take longer.  The restaurant itself was definition of mom and pops.  It certainly wasn't aesthetically pleasing, but exuded an aura of comfort, much like a Korean mother's kitchen.  The price is very reasonable if you go in a group...ours was tabulated to $20 per person.
author: Brian V.

description:
This place either super pack or they are closed. Last weekend, finally got to try it.  My bf and I got there around 7pm. It was a perfect timing, no wait got seated right away. We ordered the fried chickens, kal bi and calamari bok-um. Also, we had a complimentary soft tofu soup. 

We really enjoyed our meal. The kal bi was perfectly cooked, they were juicy and tender. The fried chickens looked dry but they were actually very moist. The calamari bok um, which was Sauteed calamari and vegetables in spicy sauce served with udon. First bite, on the udon all I tasted was sweetness but as continued eating it got spicy. But the dish was oily and the calamaris were chewy.  The tofu soup was nice and the soup base was different compared to the other restaurants.
author: Stacy L.

description: We stumbled upon a very good hole-in-the-wall Korean restaurant during a recent evening in the outer Sunset/Parkside area. No surprise, it was a cool foggy night. The comfort food in the form of bibimbap, tofu soup, and banchan really hit the spot. The wait is a bit long (maybe 45 minutes) since the place itself is fairly small. But you won't be disappointed!
author: Randy M.

description: Decent Korean food. Not impressed by their seafood tofu soup. Their mackerel is pretty good. Not a big place. Make sure you write your name on the list.
author: Cindy C.

description:
This place ROCKS.  The portions are generous.  The prices are more than fair.  And the food . . . well, is simply delicious.

This restaurant introduced me to Korean Fried Chicken, Chilean Sea Bass, and OB.  It's close to the house.  And it has not disappointed.

Sign it's a good place:
It's hard to get over the number of people waiting outside when I pass by.  Now, I know there' s nowhere to wait inside, but it should tell you something when people are willing to bear the elements of the Sunset to eat somewhere.

Try having lunch out there if you can.  And don't forget to have an OB or two or three or . . . 

to err is human, to yelp divine
author: Dan B.

description:
2 attempts here and 2 times that they have run out of chicken :(. The first time we waited an hour while smelling delicious fried chicken before they told us they ran out. Tonight we got seated and were ordering when they told us try ran out.  They get 1 extra star because our waitress  did go back to the kitchen to check if we did miss the order. 

We considered getting up and leaving, but hunger won. We ordered the following:
-pancake- wont order again. Wasn't very crispy. They did dry it in egg which made it interesting, but it was thick and slightly gummy. The sauce was more vinegar than delicious. 
-tofu beef stew- standard. Not super spicy, but I think seafood broth is more delicious. The beef was still tender. 
-steamed dumplings- nothing special
-mackerel- free and delicious but too salty
-bulgolgi- winner of the night. Delicious and tender, but maybe not worth $20+?
-bibimbop- standard. Not especially good. Rice wasn't very crunchy at the bottom and there's wasn't very many toppings.
author: Mas M.

description: It is a mom and pop kind of restaurant but it is big and have ample seating. This place never disappoints. We got the spicy fried chicken, pork and kimchee stew, and the number 6 kimchee bibimbap. It was delicious. They also gave us a small dish of the grilled mackerel for free. They service is always great, I wish we lived in SF so we can come more often. The portions are very generous. My husband and I barely put a dent in our food but we are happy to take home left overs and eat it again tomorrow.
author: Mei C.

description: As a Korean, everytime my friends ask me to bring them to Korean restaurant, I couldn't find better place than this. Kind and nice waitress, reasonable price and most of all delicious! I personally think it deserves better grade than this. Must visit place.
author: Chanhyuk L.

description:
I would suggest that you arrive early as the restaurant will fill to capacity quickly. 
There is a sign posted on the door that they can only accommodate take out during lunch.
They are unable to do take out during dinner due to the sheer number of patrons.

Make sure you come with your appetite and prepared to be satisfied. Be far warned that some of the condiments provided are spicy. The spicy tofu soup are very tasty but should be taken in measured quantity. 

We ordered the Jap Chae, Beef Short Ribs, Fried Chicken, Regular Pancake, and Grilled Mackerel. The Jap Chae was sweet and tasty through and through. The Beef Short Ribs was succulent and well marinated. Fried Chicken was deep fried to golden perfection with the meat moist and juicy. The Regular Pancake tasted just like it was homemade. The Grilled Mackerel was surprisingly good. All the dishes came in ample portions as there were left overs to take home.

So if you want Korean Food but don't want to put a major crease in your wallet. I would eat here!

Another thing is parking can be difficult. I would park on the adjacent streets and not on Taraval Street.
author: LM K.

description:
This place looks live a dirty dive, but it's actually very good. The bimimbop is scrumptious and enough for two people. Avoid the "pancakes" if you don't want to gain 10 lbs.... they are so good, but basically egg & dough. And the complementary barley tea is addicting... tastes like rice crispies. 

We usually go around 5:30 because the place is small and gets very crowded after 6 pm. There tends to be a bit of a language barrier every time we go, but it's always worked out fine. They DO take credit cards. Street parking only.
author: Kate B.

description:
Got here a bit early on a monday after class, 4:00PM and just chilled outside for about an hour.  After watching the muni run by and stop, run by and stop, I got to be starvingggggg.  

A couple minutes before open, I popped in and kindly asked if we could be seated, party of 3.  They gladly seated us and checked out the menu.  Our friend recommend the rice cakes (which turned out to be the best dish).  I also ordered the bibimbap, fried chicken, and bbq chicken.  

The side dishes are pretty standard, nothing crazy or fancy. They are standard and taste accordingly.  

The fried chicken was really crispy, well fried but lacked flavor. If they added some salt & pepper, that would have taken it to the top.  I started adding their "hot sauce" which happened to be not even spicy one bit.  Note: I'm not a big spicy eater.  

The portions for the bibimbap were pretty huge.  I would recommend just ordering one for two people to share. 

BBQ chicken was pretty standard.  Wish they had spicy bbq chicken but this place is not for that. 

The service was pretty decent.  The ladies there are nice and helpful.  

They even threw in some free tofu soup just cause we are coolin like that.  

You can't lose, but you also can't win with this place.
author: Dennis C.

description:
It's probably been at least 2 years since I've been here. I remember it being super crowded and the wait was made worse cz you had to stand outside in the freezing cold with fog, intensive mist, and ridiculously strong wind. But it all became worth it when our name was called to take our seats. 

The dubbokki with squid was always one of my favorites along with their kimchi bibimbap. SO GOOD. And they always give you soup/fish on the house for dinner. Their kimchi pajeon(pancakes) are real good too! 

One of their most hyped about food is their chicken wings! Honestly, it wasn't for me. The order was extremely hefty and we never was able to finish it and left to take it home with over half left. I just felt it was a little dry? Everything else I have ordered from the menu was pretty delicious and portions are always great here! 

4/5 - nostalgia, delicious food, rustic korean environment, free food and good service? Down.
author: Carmen L.

description:
I visited Shin Toe Bui Yi for lunch one weekend based on a recommendation for Korean fried chicken.  I'll admit right away that I'm not Korean fried chicken expert.  In fact, I'm not sure I've even had Korean fried chicken before coming here.  So it may be good for what is is, but I think I prefer my fried chicken just plain American style better.  The sauce that comes with the fried chicken isn't as spicy as it looks so don't be afraid.  For lunch we also ordered the scallion pancake - very good - and the beef glass noodles - okay, a little bland.  I also really liked the kimchee dishes that came with lunch.  But again, I'm no judge because I like all kimchee - yes, even the fried fish and other odd things.  

I'm not sure we got the experience the restaurant in all it's glory as I made the unfortunate decision to come here with a spicy hot adverse friend so we had to limit our orders.  IMHO the best Korean food is the really hot stuff.

Conclusion - nice place but not worth the trek out unless you live nearby.  I like the places around Japantown better (and I know that doesn't even compare to Koreatown in LA).

Lunch is "take-away" but basically you order and it comes in boxes to your table. Except that the lady there will bring you kimchee in real dishes and tea too.
author: Jean K.

description:
I came here at around 6 PM with 7 other people. One of us didn't arrive yet, but they still gave us a table.. At first the waitress was kind of annoyed that one of us was late because usually they have to wait until EVERYONE is here so they can seat us, and there were other people waiting.  Luckily she gave us the table and the people after us had to wait for a while.

The waitress was kind of impatient with us because we took a long time to order.  But whatever.

We ordered, Korean Pancake, Fried Chicken, Calamari and Beef, Jap Chae, Tofu Soup(came with the meal ), Rice Cakes, and Spicy Pork.  People said that the fried chicken was really good, but i thought it wasn't that great. I like Toyose's better.  But everything else was Perfect!!!!  It wasn't tooo spicy,just right for those who couldn't handle spicyness.  

Our total came to be $14 per person!! So worth it to come here with a group because you can get a bigger variety.

I love this place and i would come back!!
author: Emi K.

description: This place is great! Delicious food, complimentary tofu soup, yummy side dishes, and nice folks. Sad they are only open for dinner - lunch is take-out only.
author: Siobhan B.

description:
This place reminds me of my favorite all around Korean restaurant in Joisy Spring restaurant. Came here with my sister, prego cousin and prego's husband. Limited seating = long wait. But, I didn't mind.

The suduboo, seafood pancake was just ok. I really enjoyed the free fish. The fried chicken was exceptional. My cousin said they never are able to finish the a chicken order when she comes her with friends.
author: Chris L.

description: Pretty good neighborhood Korean restaurant that will satisfy your cravings. The bibimbap was good and my only regret was not ordering the fried chicken that everyone seemed to be eating.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Small hole in the wall; located deep in the Sunset district.

For years, hubby has been wanting to take me here to try their infamous  fried chicken.  Well, we finally did...FRIED CHICKEN was a bust. Nicely fried but there was no flavor to it and no sauce.  Stone Korean Kitchen is still the winner winner...chicken dinner!

The rest of the food was average. No different than any other Korean restaurant I've been to.
author: Diana M.

description: This is a great little resturant in the neighborhood.  The fried chicken, galbi, and bulgogi is always on point. The owners usually give something like tofu soup on the house when you dine in and when I've asked for extra kimchi during take out, I am never charged extra.  Get the lunch plates, they are amazing for the price point.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Soft tofu soup is to die for. Consistently good, spicy with tofu that just holds up long enough for you to get it on your spoon then awaits consumption. 

Fried chicken is good and plenty, like it when in the mood but try sticking to healthier stuff. Don't care for their noodles but the beef bulgogi is awesome. Seems like a family business, ladies are usually very friendly and efficient, side dishes very good. For the area it is 5 stars, taking away a star for the fact that takeout ends up being another few dollars over sitting down and eating there!
author: Bob M.

description:
This Korean restaurant out in the Avenues is one of the hidden treasures.  It's really out there but good food always travel far.   There is usually a wait during dinner, no matter what day it is.  Make sure you sign up on the wait list because the waitress goes purely by the list and nothing else.  

They give you free garlic pancake and fried mackerel with each meal in addition to the little Banchan dishes that other Korean restaurants give you.   Prices are decent.   Among the most popular: Fried Chicken, Tofu soup, and Bulgogi.  I was not impressed with the Bibimbap.  It was rather bland -- I've tasted better.    

Air ventilation is bad here, so your clothes will probably end up smelling like the food.  Hence, don't wear your fancy clothes there.
author: Jannie Q.

description: I love coming to this place. the fried chicken, broiled mackerel and the 'chicken and potato' broth, pancake with scallion and seafood .. delish.
author: Lop H.

description:
What we ordered:
-Kimchi Rice in stone pot
-Bulgogi
-Fried Chicken
*complimentary tofu soup (extra star for taste/qualtiy!)

After reading the reviews on this place about the hype on the fried chicken (and me being the FRIED CHICKEN MONSTER), we had to try this place out... 

Atmosphere: 
Typical hole-in-the-wall SF restaurant where you would see families eating a dinner on a weekday.

The Food: 
Maybe I was expecting more from the chicken... I mean, how can you go wrong with fried chicken? Especially, with me. When it arrived to the table, I quickly grabbed the flapper portion of the wing. Upon first bite, I was disappointed. Disappointed with the flavor, the 'crunch' or lack there of.. It was bland to me. The special sauce wasn't very enticing... It seemed like some kind of Sriracha/Cocktail sauce concoction that couldn't even rescue my craving for fried chicken. I have had other KFC's (Korean Fried Chicken) before and this made it to the bottom of my list. 

The Kimchi rice arrived to the table and my eyes glazed over as I saw the mounds of vegetables on top that was covering the egg. The Kimchi in it was not cut up too small and neither was the beef. After a quick mix of the pot, I took a bite and the taste was just right.  This was actually good. 

The Bulgogi was deceiving. It didn't look appetizing compared to what I have had in the past but it was good. The meat was tender and it had the right amount of fatty pieces. The marinade was flavorful and it had the right amount of sweet and savory on my palette. 

Now on to the tofu soup. It arrived at the table and I didn't want to touch it first because I didn't order it. So I had to confirm with the waitress that the soup was actually for our table. The taste was incredible. I can say that this was the best tofu soup I have ever had. The broth had the right amount of spice. It had a generous portion of tofu. I wish it had more veggies though.

Although the tofu soup was amazing, I don't think the KFC nor the Kimchi rice would have me back here anytime soon for dinner.
author: BYRON D.

description: This place good me like this place too much. Sorry to sound Neanderthal but when you get big ass pieces of fried chicken my inner Chris Rock comes out and says gimme the big piece of Chickennnnnnn! The pan chan was abundant and good and to think the metaphor never judge a book by its cover holds true for this place. The fan vent is dusty and grody and the tables and chairs look discountish if that's a word but the hell with the aesthetics the food is damn good. Love the bibimbap and the complimentary fried fish. There's just not enough words except food good
author: graham c.

description: I wish i could give them no star... BAD COSTUMER SERVICE EVER.. We had to wait around an hour for 2 dishes... And the food is not good too... Moreover, it is so expensive ... I never come back to this place again...
author: Mickey N.

description: Fried chicken is a must have. The tdeobukki is pretty good too. I wasn't a big fan of the pancake as it was a bit too mushy for me. The tofu soup is average. Service is decent. I always come here for my korean cravings. I recommend this place.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Solid Korean food with yummy banchans (spicy anchovies, spicy fish cake, pickled daikon, kimchi, etc). 

If you come here during lunch, you're limited to a page of choices, but they come at great value! They give it to you in a to go box, but you're welcome to eat it at the restaurant. It may not seem like a lot of food, but you will be stuffed after finishing the last bite. It comes with rice banchan, and sometimes tofu soup on the side! Though I must say, before the change to to go boxes, customers had more options of dishes, and also bigger variety of banchans (my favorite part of the meal). 

If you come here for dinner, the portions are huge, which justifies the price. If you're not too hungry or cringe when you see a lot of meat (like me), you should definitely share it with someone! A plate of meat probably feed 2 semi-hungry peeps. 

My favorite dishes: fried chicken, spicy pork, kalbi, spicy rice cake! Yum :)
author: Michelle L.

description:
It's a small place in the Sunset...a place I would call a convenience location for people who live nearby.  But I would not eat here by choice.  There are other Korean restaurants which are better near J-town.

The kalbi didn't have that barbeque'd freshness about it.  The seafood dolsot bibimbap was bland.  The spicy odaeng panchan was hard like it was old.  The kimchi jjigae was watery and tasteless.  If you know Korean food, then you may not enjoy this place.  SF does NOT have a plethora of good Korean food and this one of those places.
author: Cary L.

description:
I've lived in the Sunset pretty much my whole life and for some reason I can't explain I had never been here until earlier tonight.  We walked in almost exactly at 6pm thinking they opened at 6pm but we were mistaken, it's 5pm!  More than half the restaurant was already full!  We watched the line form as we ate our dinner.

We were immediately welcomed by smiling servers and a cloud of delicious smoke that lingered in our hair and clothes for the rest of the evening.

Korean fried chicken:  huge plate of various chicken wings and legs(?) coated in batter and fried to perfection.  I do prefer the ones with sauce better though but don't get me wrong, these were delicious!
Beef Bulgolgi:  My bf insists that they make the best ones here but I'm pretty sure I've had better.  The pieces were cut too big for not having a knife on hand.  Pulling pieces apart with my teeth and chopstick looked somewhat comical but also frustrating on my part.
Chap chae noodles:  I've had this a few times, mostly purchased at a Korean market.  But the most memorable one was when my Korean friend's mom made me some.  This dish didn't compare at all the either examples.
Complimentary dishes:  I love their little apps, whatever you call them, LOVE THEM!  And the tofu soup was also very good.  Good enough that I packed it to go with the fried chicken when we left.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
They have strict seating policies. They will not seat parties of larger than 6 together, which for us caused 2 people from our group to find dinner elsewhere. The food is standard. I think the fried chicken here is completely overrated; dry and overly battered. The staples: bulgolgi, kalbi, chapchae, seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice, and banchan are all as good as what you'd find on the other side of the park in the Richmond.

Probably won't return because the gruff service left a bad impression, even though it's pretty close to my house.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Went here a little while back and it was one of the first times I had an authentic Korean feast, and I fell in love! This place gives me the feeling of a little family owned restaurant. I felt like i was eating at a friends house for their mom's delicious cooking! 

The workers are very nice and the service is quick after you order. But my tip would be to get there kinda early if you're going for dinner, because it gets crowded.

Now on to the good stuff, the food! 
It's all delicious! I love how you get all the side orders (Banchan) with your meal. All sorts of pickled veggies, kimchi, and fish are so yummy! 

I went with a couple friends and we ordered a bunch of dishes to try. We got Soondubo (spicy tofu soup), Tteokboki (rice cakes with spicy sauce), Bulgogi (grilled marinated beef), Pajeon (green onion pancake), and House Fried Chicken with sauce. All of the food was to die for, and all worth trying! My favorites were definitely the Bulgogi and Tteokboki. 

I'm definitely coming back!
author: Sharon L.

description: This place is small and cozy, but always crowded. Had good tofu and seafood soup but a bit on the salty side.  Saw the korean fried chicken on also every table, so we ordered it.  Quite tasty and not greasy.  Korean seafood pancake  was great!  Server came out with complimentary  delicious grilled mackerel and many more side dishes.  Lots of food on our small table.  The check was little expensive for such a casual crowded place.
author: Frank C.

description: There was no wait on a Saturday night which was great and had a great deal of influence seeing as it was the coldest I've felt in sf to date and I just wanted something hot as that very instant. With that said, the food was rather disappointing. The banchan did not taste crisp and fresh as it should and they do not have the requisite kimchee pancakes. The spicy dishes arent spicy at all. Its safe korean eating at best.
author: M C.

description:
Oil... that's what I smelled when I walked in the doors.  That didn't deter me however.  I was excited because the place was packed (15min wait), everything looked delicious and my guy had nothing but good to say about the chicken.  

We ordered the chicken and squid with rice cakes in spicy sauce (my favorite).  The squid dish was delish but the sauce was very oily.  The chicken... while it wasn't greasy, I could still taste the oil in the batter.  It was like a tempura chicken... weird.  I wasn't a fan.  Other dishes looked nice though, maybe if I go again I'll get the bibimbap.  No oil and the table next to us said it was good.

All-in-all, my dish was a hit but too greasy.  I wasn't impressed with the chicken.  This place left me feeling... comfortably greasy.  LoL  Good thing there are many other places that do a good oh jing oh duk bok ki for me!

Parking is a train wreck.

Probably won't see ya there.
author: Susan D.

description:
YES!
I am basically friends with the waitresses, we're like best buds.
Their free tofu sondubu is off the chainzzz & I love their pork.
It's so fun taking my friends and family here, they all love it!

Only thing, sometimes the banchan can be sort of a miss, but all of the main
dishes are yummy!

Close to quickly's for desert boba milk tea!!
author: Sophia W.

description:
My One Word: Full.

Fact #1: The deep fried chicken is not as great as some Yelpers make it sound. It was tough and dry to be blunt.

Fact #2: Super duper small restaurant and slow service. Waiting during dinner time is inevitable.

Fact #3: Food was super average but you get your money's worth out of the large portions.

Fact #4: Parking sucks.
author: Calvin T.

description: We parked about a block away and could smell the delicious food. We had the bulgolgi, seafood pancake, fried chicken, and the japchae. Probably way too much food for 3 adults and a toddler, but everything looked so good, we couldn't decide. We had plenty of food to take home. They even comped us a free soup. I'd recommended getting here early as the place is small and fills up. Friendly wait staff.
author: T T.

description:
Wow!

Everything from my experience here was great. From the food to the service to the ambiance. The ingredients are really fresh and the service is fast. The beef and calamari is sooooo good and the tofu soup, which was on the house, was just amazing. The BBQ ribs are on point and I hear the fried chicken is the best plate. I'll be the judge of that as I have yet to try it. 

The prices are very reasonable and the place really has a homey feel to it which I really liked. It does get crowded here from time to time but it's nothing to extreme. This of course is a good thing because this the truth.  There is parking around and the L stops right in front which is convenient. Been here a couple of times and will for come here plenty more.
author: Javier G.

description:
Usually I would assume that most places which I've never heard of would be kind of dead on a Monday night past 7pm.  But not STBY (Oh yes I did and abbreviated it).  

They were cracking it off on a cold Monday night at 8pm.  Therefore, I'm sold, it must be solid.

And to our expectations, it was.  The food smelled amazing even when the place was filled with a fine scented aroma of deliciousness.

Between the 3 of us, our eyes ordered for our tiny stomachs, and so we gorged.....and gorged.....until we had to call it quits and send those leftovers home.  We had the following:

-Steamed Skate Wings with vegetables - great flavor with texture and consistency
-Fried Chicken - really tasty but could use a sauce to coat it as it was sort of bland
-Rice Rolls with Seafood - it's something you normally can order at any korean spot, but at the time it was very tasty with enough flavor in the sauce
-FREE tofu soup - so apparently your meal comes with one of these which is just pure awesome!

Not a lot of places serve skate and I like their menu as its somewhat different with a little bit of extra variety compared to those offered in the Richmond.  I'll be back, STBY!
author: Vincent K.

description:
Overrated. I tried all the stapled Korean food (fried chicken, seafood pancake, tofu soup, kalbi) and they were all just ok. Even the side dishes were whatever. Nothing stood out to me as memorable.

Mediocre food + small restaurant + difficult parking = I won't be coming back.
author: Tina S.

description: Based in Sunset, SF this Korean restaurant is unbelievably busy and well known in the area. To our surprise we managed to get a table quite easily. Mind you, it was only 5pm. By 6/7pm the queues were up to 20-25mins. It's a small shop with about 10 tables comfortably seating up to 40 customers inside. Unlike the usual Korean restaurant in town, this one is actually run by Koreans. More importantly this particular shop is filled with Korean people! Without going in you already know this place is authentic. The food isn't presented amazingly well and nor do they pride themselves with their smart design and creative combinations. This place is all about flavour. For those who can't stand food too spicy, their soups are not that spicy. In fact I'd consider them mild compared to their English counterpart that I'm used to. We had to try their fried chicken as every other Korean customer had ordered a plate. I would describe it as a tasteless version of KFC but would definitely suit the more pro-healthy patrons with its abnormally low level of oil and salt. It was a disappointment, but perhaps that is how it is served in Korea. I would have expected at least a minimal amount of marinade in the meat. Moving on: their pre-starters (little pickle dishes) were prepared well and tasted above average, generous in size too. Their pajon (or pacheon) is similar to many found in the states but European versions seem to be thinner and lighter but smaller in size. Beef, I forget the name, probably the beef ribs on flat iron was amazing. The marinate was well prepared and it was cooked perfectly: not overdone! The bill came to $97 for a table of 6 and we ate a lot! I would recommend (even though I only gave three stars) simply because I believe this is genuine Korean food and its a taste of Korea. Do try it out, but it may not be your cup of tea.
author: C G S.

description:
I so wanted to give this Korean rest. in Parkside a 4 or higher rating for their dinner service; I just can't do it. 

Last night there was a party of 4 who frequented this place for the first time, having made the decision based from the former yelp reviews. Honestly, nothing worked well with this dinner; strong nod from the Korean friend from Pusan who said that she would not come back for a repeat visit. Sadly, I must agree with her. 

Panchan was perfunctory; nothing exceptionally tasty, crunchy, pickled, or peppered. My heart was already sinking once those little appetizer plates were brought out. 

We ordered:
 tofu stew shepherd's purse/miso soup
dol sot bibimbap
seafood udon noodle soup
Bulgogi (beef)
broiled mackerel was on the house

The tofu soup was just ok. the tofu wasn't the silken variety, which was fine. but the soup was altogether more like 'add miso paste, then add water'. My heart sank

The bibimbap: the black stoneware pot was not heated up hot enough to brown and 'crunchify' the rice beneath. In fact, the egg that sat in the middle didn't 'cook' properly when mixed together, because nothing inside was hot enough to cook it to keep from getting wet and gummy. Another dud!

Sizzling iron plate that held the bulgogi also did not get hot enough (either that, or the meat was too wet). That grilled flavor was just in absentio and we all looked at one another, silently, kind of like "How can every dish be so 'meh' after the yelp reviews?"

The lady server was so polite and kind. She was generous in gifting us with the fish (no matter how many times i eat mackerel, I deem it too fishy of a fish)... I honestly did want to rate them higher than I can actually do...

Frankly, I wouldn't recommend anyone driving specifically to Parkside (Taraval) for Korean here.... if you did, you'd get a much more satisfying experience at Kingdom Dumpling just east, up the street, or perhaps Korean on Noriega?
author: Jana C.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday dinner. The restaurant's a bit on the smaller side, so the  group was awkwardly split in half in two tables. 

The food was great, no doubt about it. When they messed up on of our orders, they gave us a complimentary spicy tofu soup which was very considerate of them. 

Be warned though, this place gets crowded and people aren't shy about waiting closely to your table. I felt horrible eating in front of a large crowd of hungry and cold people, but what can you do. 

All in all a solid Korean restaurant, still second to Toyose though in my opinion when it comes to food and ambiance.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
Shin Toe Bul Yi has bumped itself up to one of my top places for korean cuisine! I initially came across this place when I saw all the good reviews. Like everyone else, I passed by this place dozens of times thinking it was shut down and abandoned. Luckily for me, it wasn't out of reach and is still open!

UNLIKE everyone else, I don't come here for the chicken wings, in fact, I don't even get why everyone loves it so much. I tried it with my boyfriend and it is heavy with batter. I usually like my fried chicken thin with batter and crispy on the outside. The chicken here is like a soggy stale crispy, if that even makes sense. 

What I do like here is the seafood pancake and the ddeok mandu guh (dumpling and rice cake soup). My best girlfriend introduced the soup to me and I fell in dumpling heaven! It has rice cakes that are nice and chewy, clear noodles, and dumplings that are oh so yummy. 

I also love that they give patrons a complimentary dish, we got the fried mackerel. Most places actually offer something free aside from the ban chaan, but we still greatly appreciate it!
author: Connie C.

description: Horrible service. The staff is the rudest I've ever experienced. The food is average and is way overpriced. On top of that they don't allowed take out. WHY NOT?!?! You're still making money and I'm not taking up seating space. I would have given them a zero rating if there's any.
author: Allison P.

description:
My very first review!! Anyways, I come here a lot with my brother and I'm always overly stuffed by the end of our meal which basically means I love the food and we ordered too much for just two people. 

Usually we come on a Friday or Saturday around 6PM, and by the time we get there, it's full of people already considering it's not a big place and it's the end of the week. If you get there and it's full, you can place your name down right by the door, which has happened to me once or twice when I go there later than 6:30.

The banchan is standard and average, not the best I've had, but it's not disgusting or anything. The complimentary fish is alright, but since it's free, I've always saved it for last to eat, but I'm never able to eat it unless I bring it home since I'm too full. 

My brother and I always order the same thing, seafood soft tofu soup, kimchi bibimbap, and the dakgui which is a broiled chicken dish marinated with sauce. They give you one bowl of white rice, but we always ask for another because my brother is a gluttonous pig. The tofu soup is pretty good, but the seafood wasn't THE BEST, but they give you a fair amount. The kimchi bibimbap is my favorite because it's a pretty large amount of food and the kimchi is very good. I like my food spicy so I usually put a generous amount of hot pepper paste into it. The chicken is good too, not overly cooked, and it has just the right amount of flavor. These three dishes are plenty enough for two people. We usually never finish it all and always bring home the left over chicken. Can't waste it, that's crazy talk! 

The service is pretty fast when it's not crazy busy. There's actually only one or two waitresses working. They're pretty quick with coming around to see if everything's going fine and if we needed anything else. 

I never learn from my mistakes of ordering too much and continue to do so because I can't help but be greedy and order my usual faves at this place :)
author: Shirley L.

description:
FULL... obnoxiously stuffed... roll me out of the restaurant in a wheelbarrow full.  Great banchan... SoonDuBu... galbi ... jap jae...  and OMG... FRIED CHICKEN.

Cannot repeat this experience too often...or will be morbidly obese in no time at all.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
A solid 3 stars.  It's good eats but I needed a Korean food wow factor to add a star.

The exterior is kinda run-down and the interior is dated which causes a bit of skepticism in terms of food.  From personal experience, crappy looking places tend to have delicious food.  This joint is a prime example.

I've been here for dinner a few times and it's usually packed.  If you need to wait, it'll most likely be for 15-30 minutes.  The waitresses are friendly and are on top of things, even with a packed house.  

The food...
Kal bi (beef short ribs) - Nicely grilled big pieces of meat that were juicy and tender.

Kim chee bibimbap - Served in a large stoneware pot and went well with the kal bi.  It had a very mild flavor of kim chee.  I liked how the hot pot made some of the rice a bit crunchy, which provided a contrast in texture of the rice.

Fried chicken - I know a lot of people like this dish but I've had it a few times and it doesn't impress me.  There's too much batter and the chicken is on the dry side.  I'd pass on this next time around.  

Soups/stews - I tried a couple but can't remember the names.  All I remember is that it was served in a big pot, had lots of spicy flavors, and it was good on a cold day.

Eating at a restaurant like this is hard because you want to try a lot of things but the portions are big and you don't want to order too much.  If anything, you can take home leftovers (which is always the case) and you'll have lunch for the next day (or two).
author: Suzi K.

description: Very Friendly. Great Food, Reasonable Prices!!! This place has amazing Korean-Side dishes, and their soft tofu soup is a must get. Also, an off-menu item is the green-onion pancake or called "House Pancake" which is around $3.00 if you can spare the seafood. The Fried Chicken is also a must get. It is crispy, juicy, and tasty!
author: Paul L.

description:
I have a hard time trying new Korean restos, but the boyfriend seemed really excited about this place, so we went and ordered three items:  1. fried chicken, 2. soon tofu chege, and 3. the seafood pancake.

Their side dishes were minimal compared to other korean joints, but all were delicious.  Plus, they gave us so much food, there really was no need for all the other sides that I'm used to.

The fried chicken had a light and crunchy batter, served with their house sauce.  Their soup broth was light and tasty with tons of soft tofu, meat, veggies, and seafood.  Last, their seafood pancake is HUGE and has a pleasant taste with a variety of mixed seafood pieces.  

We were also very pleased with their "on the house" saba and lemon that was fried to perfection!

Great food and large portions for a reasonable price.  We have plenty to eat for tomorrow's lunch, too!  Hopefully we can go back for a lunch special on a Saturday!  This is definitely our new Korean place in SF.
author: Ali and Nick G.

description:
I really like hot tofu soup.  The boyfriend really likes bimbimbop (or however you spell it).  This place is only 3 blocks away from us.  It's a happy happy resolution for all of us!

I like how every time I come in here there are old Korean men who eat and drink a bottle of beer together and then in the middle of their meal get up and go outside to have a cigarette break and then come back order a new bottle of beer and then as soon as that bottle is done they get back up for another cigarette.  I usually witness 2-3 bottles of beers/cigarettes.  I have no idea how many they consume overall since they're there before I get there and there still when I leave.  It gives me a feeling that this is as legit as it gets...so you know the food has to be legit too.

I'm getting hungry just thinking about the tofu soup...damn, I may need to return soon.
author: Quynh-An P.

description: Although the meat they serve is delicious, they dump a bunch of veggies and other stuff into the dish leaving a very minimal amount of the good stuff.  Their opening hours and service is rather odd too, but thats not really something that I am factoring into my score.
author: Andrew L.

description:
While this place does not serve the best or most authentic Korean food I've had, I must say I really did enjoy the food here.

-SOON DU BU (i like it!)
-FRIED CHICKEN and MOO (chicken is very MOIST, unlike Toyose's fried mess)
-DOK BOK KEE (not cooked long enough for my taste, i like the rice sticks softer)
-DUK MANDU GOOK (great flavor in the broth and the dumplings)
-BULGOGI (meh, i would pass)
-PA JUN (korean pancake - very good!!! to the surprise of my vegetarian friend, it has oysters in it)

The service here is definitely lacking, but you can't expect much from 2 waitresses running the show.  I had to ask numerous times for more tea and forget about asking them for ice water! They also forgot my MOO with the fried chicken  The MOO (pickled cubed daikon) is my absolute favorite part of eating Korean fried chicken. I feel like the servers respond better to Korean-speakers. Time to brush up on my Korean.

We ordered a crapload of food and the bill turned out to be about $16 per person after tax and tip.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
So we went there on Friday night, I think we waited for 45 mins for a table for 5... It was a torture to see the guests inside eating fried chicken and bbq when you were standing outside staving... lol... 

Anyway, once we sat down, we ordered fried chicken, soju and beer, add ordere some more noodles later.

What impressed me is the fried chicken, it is really good, freshly fried and the skin is really crispy!! No wonder almost every table has this! And the spicy octopus noodle is good too (even though the noodle is a bit like udon)~~~
author: Carolyn P.

description:
A few months ago they changed the lunch format, so that it's to go only.  You can still eat inside the restaurant but the food is served in to go containers.  I think you can still order from the entire menu and it's much less crowded during lunch (there's usually a line in the evenings).  Plus they have cheap lunch specials (12 PM - 2:30 PM, M - F), mostly noodles, BBQ and rice bowls for $6.95 or $7.95.

I had the seafood bowl ($7.95).  The to go container was packed with food including five types of pan chan (thin fish cakes, napa cabbage, blanched bean sprouts, crunchy cucumbers, anchovies), steamed white, sautéed seafood, scrambled egg and veggies and a cup of spicy red sauce.  They thoughtfully put the spicy and non-spicy pan chan in separate compartments.  I wasn't sure if they would include pan chan or not but am happy that they did (and in abundance).  Good pan chan, not amazing but definitely solid.

I stirred the sauce w/ the sauteed items and rice first.  The sauce was a bit too sweet and not spicy enough but the sauteed squid (not overcooked), clams, eggs, zucchini, carrots, onion and mushrooms were very good.  Because you just get steamed white rice, the overall dish is inferior to bi bim bap in a sizzling stoneware pot.  

The restaurant staff is really nice (consistently so).  It's comfy inside even though the outside doesn't look too clean (not that I care).
author: Lolia S.

description:
Update: confirmed, Fridays are still busy, long wait-list even with reservations. So, try to go on another weekday, ey?
Jap-Chae=sauteed noodles (thin, clear) w/veggies/beef ($9.99)
Bul-go-gi=beef rib eye marinated ($18.99)
soft tofu w/assorted seafood ($9.99)
chicken "small" pieces - "little spicy" (deep fried) ($10.99)

Out of the way to get there, but worth the trip:
Korean Green Onion Pancake ($8.99), 
Kalbi=beef short rib ($18.99), 
calamari bok-um=sauteed calamari/veggies/noodles ($11.99), 
soft tofu with beef stew ($9.99), 
complimentary fried mackerel, 
standard small plates of side dishes, 
along with a bottle of so ju ($10.00). 
Almost finished everything because all the items were so good - even their tea. As for the fried chicken, it was pretty good the last time we had it. There were probably four, or more, tables that ordered it while we were there.

A repeater-place = good. Got there and there was no line at all - based on previous visits, a star just for that. Plus, another star for the easy to find parking. What's going on? Is it TTET* and people cannot go out as often? Will move this place ahead of Brother's for the fact you don't leave smelling all-KBBQed.
author: Peter L.

description: It is a small restaurant that doesn't take reservations. I understand that because they don't have much space in the restaurant. We came in as a group of 22 people. The waitress has excellent service. My boss and I ordered 3 dishes and it sure didn't disappoint us. The bulgogi came first. It was awesome. I got to say its a bit pricey but it was worth. The best bulgogi I've ever tasted. The second dish, OMG. That will be your first reaction. It gives you a huge amount of chicken for a decent price. My boss was so happy after she saw the dish of fried chicken that is made to perfection, golden, crispy. Its just amazing. We also got their seafood tofu soup, it was decent. I've tried better. The owners are really generous and decided to give us a few dishes of grilled mackerel. Try it, this restaurant wont disappoint you.
author: Kris C.

description:
I was going to give it 3 stars for the actual food we ordered but we got  a complimentary mackerel and also the side dishes were pretty delicious so I gave this place an extra star.

It wasn't that this place wasn't GOOD--it was good Korean food, there were just some aspects that were eh.

I came here with two of my friends, we ordered the infamous fried chicken, jap chae and this other noodle dish that was listed under jap chae in the menu. I forget what its called but it's kinda udon-y and it was swimming in soup with slices of potatoes and cucumber? Potatoes for sure but I don't know what the green stuff was, not chives or anything.

anyway, the udon-y noodle (wait, this is not to be mistaken that we ordered UDON, it just seemed like udon) came in a very big bowl and they were really generous with the portions. the jap chae was a bit on the oily side but it was still good.

now the fried chicken, everyone .. nearly EVERYONE on yelp said it's amazing but I didn't think it was worth all the hype. Sure it's juicy and it's definitely tender and really yummy but it just tasted like fried chicken. no "korean-y" aspects to it at all and I definitely would recommend getting the seafood pancake instead of this chicken. don't get me wrong, the chicken was good, but I would recommend trying something else from this restaurant in replace of this chicken dish. 

the sides were good, the mackerel was delicious and they serve yummy rice tea! 

bill came out to be about $40, tipp'd and everything. 
good place. will try their meat selection next time! it was really crowded, and around 6pm, there was a line forming!
author: Sandra L.

description: I believe that in order for a place to be 5 stars, the quality of their food needs to be consistent.  And this place is.  This time I wasn't seated at a 2 person table (with 3 in our party) like before.  We order just the right amount and the food really hit the spot.  ORDER THE SEAFOOD PANCAKE.  IT IS DELICIOUS.  mmmm....
author: Tiffany C.

description: This use to be my favorite place to get Korean food. I use to come here with my friends all the time. We would always get the fried chicken and seafood pancake to share and I always get the kimchi bibimbap in the stone pot. This place is very cozy and it's a nice place to chill and hang with you friends but recently I came back and introduced this place to my brother and sister-in-law. It's been almost a year since I've been back.  It was definitely not a good experience and I felt really disappointed. I felt bad for my brother and sister-in-law. We got seated right away and the waitress literally didn't come to us until 40 minutes later. We would try to get the waitress attention but she would look pass us and take orders from people who came in after us. Pretty sad. Not only did it take us 40 minutes to order. It took us probably another 40 minutes to get our food. We  only ordered two things which was a bibimbap. My brother would joke around saying the waitress probably hates us. I think he was right. Haha. When we got our food we didn't even feel hungry anymore so we only ate for about 15 minutes and wanted to leave because the waitress was being rude. We would ask for water but didn't even give it to us until we asked again. She took away the chair next to me when there were other seats she could have taken. I really don't know what to say about the service other than it was super shitty. The food is good but now that I think about it there are better Korean restaurants than this and way more cheaper. Haha probably never coming back.
author: Christina T.

description:
I remembered this place as Chicken Deli when they served bomb ass bulgogi sandwiches...that was over a decade ago...or was it two decades??

Anyways, came here to try them out as I needed a quick Korean fix that was on Taraval.  There was no line like everyone on Yelp says there is maybe because we came at 6pm on a weekday.  

Seafood tofu soup - Pretty good...but I had better

Kalbi - a bit overcooked, very dry and meat quality was bad (chewy beef)..  How can you have bad kalbi at a Korean restaurant...??

Spicy Octopus - Marinated very good...the sauce they used was phenomenal, however, the squid quality was bad...again...very chewy.

I won't be returning back to this place any time soon.  Though I think I will come back to get a to-go order of their fried chicken wings that everyone raves about on Yelp.  I saw a few tables ordering this and it looks like a "better-than-KFC" kind of wings.
author: Patrick C.

description:
We went a bit crazy when ordering..broiled fish (king fish I believe, came with two fairly sized fish!)...kalbi short ribs....jap chae(sp?)noodles...huge seafood pancake....two bowls of rice..the side dishes...and a complimentary spicy tofu soup? Wow..our table ran out of space and the TWO of us were stuffed (with plenty of left overs)!! ...stuffed to the max.. anyways..decent service! Came here at 550pm and were the first diners there for dinner, left around 645 and it became a full house.

Keep in mind, I prefer my food with less sauce, less salt, and essentially more toward the "bland" side. With that being said, I really enjoyed the food here! So for those that expect and enjoy saucy, saltier, and flavored-blasted typical korean food, these dishes may be up to par with you.

Broiled Fish- comes with two fishes, about 10 inches in size I guess? It was too salty ( for my tasting but I think it's suppose to be like that cause the bf loooved it). However, the fishes were nicely fried on the outside, and soft in the inside. We were only able to finish one of the two, and packed the other one to-go (which stunk up our fridge with its fishy smell lol), and actually made "salted fish" fried rice the following day...which tasted awesome.

Kalbi short ribs - these weren't as flavored and sauced up like many other restaurants, but I loved it like that! The flavor was still there, just not as heavily like how others serve it. My favorite part of ordering kalbi are the ribs..and sadly it only came with two. When the dish initially came out, it was sizzling hot and medium rare (sooo tender!!), but fifteen minutes later, the remaining pieces became well-done..so it got very tough. Although I understand that this typically range from $18-$22, I don't quite think its worth the $20ish .. *something* was missing.. can't quite distinguish what it was though. 

Jap chae noodles: these noodles are addicting to begin with, the flavor was light enough for me, but the beef was way overcooked. The onions in this dish were basically raw...generally I prefer raw onions, but the pieces were served too large so I couldn't handle it. Packed majority of this dish home & ended up re-frying it so the onions can be cooked more. 

Seafood pancake - not as crispy as how other restaurants make it. But I did enjoy the fluffiness (sorta dough-like texture) of the pancake. Pretty big ...filled with, what it seemed like imitation crab meat, squid, mussels, green onion... also had a noticeable additional layered of eggs on top of the pancake.. Again..we packed half of the pancake home, and pan-fried it again since bf preferred it crispier.

Side dishes included bean sprouts, kim chee, kim-chee radish, fried fish cake, and cucumbers...all pretty subtle flavors and not overly sauced...perfect for my tasting. There were only two other two-tops when we were there (not busy yet), so our side-dishes were automatically refilled whenever she saw it empty. 

Had we known that there was complimentary spicy tofu soup, we wouldn't have ordered so many dishes! Soup was okay..not a big fan on soups though.

Our meal ended up close to $90...included with a small hot sake. Despite how much we ordered, and the 4 boxes we used to pack our food to-go...she still wanted to charge additional 0.10 per paper bag? I would figure that she would have just given it to us. Regardless, we purchased two bags cause we didn't want to carry the boxes out without them. 

Decent food, service was prompt in the beginning, but not really sure if we would come back again.
author: Shirley A.

description:
Me and my friend were a little shocked to see this place at first because it looks run down from the outside and a little shady. But once we walked in, it was a pretty nice place. 

Food:
Awesome food! We had the beef rib eye, tofu soup, and the calamari with spicy rice cakes. All were delicious! They give you lots of side dishes, which were all well prepared and tasted great. They even gave us some fish on the house! I noticed they gave this to everyone, so i'm not sure if it's like you order over a certain amount and you get the fish. But the fish was the best tasting fish I had ever had!

Service:
Service could be improved. Not all that friendly, but they get their job done. I actually had to waved the waitress down like 5 times before she gave me a to-go box and the check. I don't know if she kept forgetting or she disliked me. Either way, -1 star for the service.
author: Christina L.

description: This is right in my neighborhood and I always see people waiting outside. For Korean food in the city, this place isn't bad. Prices weren't outrageous and wait staff was courteous. For starters, the banchan was tasty and fresh. I had high hopes for the fried chicken and while it looked delicious, there were a lot of white meat pieces that I'm just not a fan of. However, as I looked around, every single table ordered the fried chicken, so seemed like this is a general favorite. Tteokbokki with calamari was yummy and the bulgogi was tender and flavorful. They even served a tofu soup on the house. Between 3 people this was plenty! Just a note that one night we tried to eat here at 9pm and we were turned away. Closing time is 9:30pm, and the tables were all full, so it made sense. So a tip not to come near closing time! I'll be back.
author: Lisa H.

description:
One of the best sundubus I've had at a restaurant. Very tasty, perfect amount of spice, yum yum yum. The only downside was immediately after I had a stomach ache (though to be fair, I hadn't eaten food in CA/USA for a year so my stomach probably wasn't used to it).

A plus was that we got a whole small fish as one of the small appetizer dishes. Yum!!

Staff were very friendly.
author: Angela H.

description:
If I could, I would eat Korean food for every meal, every day for the rest of my life. And, if I could, I would probably eat it at Shin Toe Bul Yi. STBY is Korean food heaven on Earth. I was a little miffed that they didn't serve their full menu for lunch, but I'm really glad I gave them a try for dinner.

This place is no-frills, down to earth, baller Korean food. Every dish is significantly less expensive than other places, but twice the size. They bring you the most ban chan I've seen thus far in my SF and Los Angeles Korean food adventures: 7 different sides, not including a huge thing of fresh, boiling hot tofu soup with cucumber and mushrooms. My boyfriend ordered the fried chicken and I got the dolsot bibimbap. It was enough food to easily feed 4 people (we ate through the pain, like champs), made for excellent midnight snacks and lunch the next day, and came to $30 including tax and a hearty tip for our lovely waitress.

Let me say, the hype about the fried chicken is totally deserved. I don't know what they're doing to the chicken to make it so moist and frankly, I really don't care. I thought the fried layer was unlike anything I've ever had. It was thin and crisp, but not greasy. We took down a ton of that chicken without feeling weighed down, and it was even good cold when we ate our leftovers at home (probably because it's not overly greasy and doesn't get soggy). Way better than the extremely dry chicken they served us at Toyose.

So much love for Shin Toe Bul Yi, I will definitely be back soon!
author: Rachel A.

description:
The smells coming from this place are totally amazing everytime I walk by. Decided to give it a shot, and came out slightly disappointed.

First off, let me say this, every single table in the place ordered the fried chicken. So of course we followed suit. The best thing about the chicken is the dipping sauce; otherwise it's just mediocre. It's nicely fried and not greasy, but nor is it super moist or flavorful without the sauce.

The bimbimbap was just ok...nothing memorable about it. The kimchi soup and the seafood pancake were the best things we had while there. Don't get the clear noodles!!! The beef on it was horrible, it didn't have a ton of flavors and god forbid you take it home to eat the next day cause it will turn into a greasy soggy mushy mess. Also, there was only one server when I went and she looked like she was about to pass out from serving an almost full restaurant by her lonesome self.

Verdict: This place is just ok, if you're craving Korean this place will satisfy you, but there are better places.
author: David H.

description:
This is my all time favorite korean place. I've been coming here since 2007 (maybe earlier than that) and whenever I think Korean I go here or I at least think about going here (really depends where I'm at when I'm wanting it, but I have known to drive all the way to sunset if I really want it).

It's an old mom and pop like restaurant, like a hole in the wall but none of the negative "hole in the wall" things you think about when you say it. The atmosphere is comfortable and it's almost always busy when you go for dinner or on the weekends, but if you know the right times to go waiting is very minimal. I usually go right when they open for dinner. They use to serve lunch but now it's a "to go - take out "kind of thing. Funny though - you can eat there with you're take out if you want.

My usual order is the korean fried chicken (you get a heaping plate of this) and beef tofu stew. You get the usual korean fare of kimchi, picked vegetables, and such. They almost always give you a free side dish, usually I get the mackerel which has become one of my favorites. Sometimes we get the pancake for appetizer but the above is really enough to eat with room for taking home left overs.

I've tried different things like the bibimbap, noodle dishes, and the bul go gi. All delicious. I've never gone wrong with anything I've ordered here and the waitresses are all very nice. If you haven't tried, you need to try it at least once.
author: Mellisa A.

description:
I've been craving Korean food for THE longest time.  I didn't remember the name of this place but once my husband found it on Yelp and it's one that has some of the highest ratings, I remembered it as the place that's owned by my cousin's in-laws' friends.
We ordered the fried chicken that everyone talked about on Yelp, the bulgogi, duk bok yi (chewy rice cake rolls/dumplings), and sun dubu ji-ge (tofu in a spicy soup).  My husband tried the pan-chan/side dishes you get and he was impressed!  My man is very picky about his Korean food as he always compares it to what his mom used to make.  My eldest princess loved the meat and I had second helpings of everything.
Luckily we have leftovers tonight!  Shin Toe Bul Yi will be our go to place for K food from now on.
author: Kekumukula N.

description: We first tried this place 10 years ago when we lived across the street and loved it.  The spicy pork bulgogi is the best we've ever had and the fried chicken is delicious.  My wife loves everyting on the menu and it is one of her favorite restaurants.  The green onion pancake is great as well.  The portions are large and they provide alot of complimentary (Korean) appetizers.  It is not the most beautiful place, but dont let that keep you away.
author: Steven B.

description: So far, I would have to say that this is the best Korean food in sf. The fried chicken here is amazing; not oily at all. I love their pork bone potatoes soup. However, this place is pretty small so the wait to be seat extremely long. So go early. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone who love Korean food. I also order take out before. I would prefer that to avoid the wait.
author: Kristie C.

description: Good food. Seafood pancake and fried chicken are my favorites here.
author: Kellie S.

description:
A bustling, family-like atmosphere, enjoyable fare, and fair prices firmly plant Shin Toe Bul Yi high on the list of Korean options this side of San Francisco.

The Korean Fried Chicken Wings with maximally crispy batter guarding its juicy, piping-hot innards and accompanying flavorful hot sauce is a must-order every visit; the Seafood Pancake is basically a bountiful Korean quesadilla with no shortage of fillings; and the Noodle Soup featured in a huge tin bowl is packed full of delicious, mysterious goodies.

However, the standalone bulgogi and pork dishes were overcooked, leading to episodes of bubble gum chewiness, and the kimchi had subpar flavor.

The restaurant is not huge, so a group of 8 hits maximum, but the service is friendly and food arrives quickly.  Would definitely come back, now knowing what to order!
author: Andrew M.

description:
A very nondescript hole in the wall joint.  We've passed by this place without ever going in.  My friend recommended this place to me.  We walked in just before the dinner crowd and that was a good thing.  Within 15 mins there were tons of people waiting for a table.  

We all got different soups for the chilly night.  I got the hot tofu soup with beef (it was ok, had better at other places), my youngest got the beef dumpling soup (dumpling tasty), and my oldest got the noodle soup with egg (broth was tasty).  They gave us fried fish filet on the house with our ban chan (side dishes).  The one dish almost everyone had was the whole fried chicken.  It was a whole chicken cut up in a tempura batter.  I just wished it had some spice to it, but still really good.  

I'm glad we found a good Korean restaurant not too far from the house.  I'l always craving spicy foods
author: Twist' D.

description:
I had just flown back from LA, and I was huuuuungry.  My friend suggested we go to this Korean restaurant on Taraval.  Me:  "There's a Korean restaurant on Taraval????"  I guess I've never noticed it.

We got there just in time to get one of the last two tables.  There's not much room to wait inside, so if you really want to eat there, be prepared to wait out in the freezing cold.

We ordered the Kal Bi and the Sea Bass Jjim( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/94lDGx10qotEjBM2acJXmg/l ).  My eyes were bigger than my stomach, so I had to throw in an order of their pan fried pot stickers.  I was warned that it would be too much food, but of course, I didn't listen.   

They give you free soft tofu stew which was really good.  I don't eat super spicy food, and the stew had just the right amount of spice so I wasn't breathing fire.  I would highly recommend the sea bass.  Doesn't look like much when you see it.(Me:  "What's that pile of bean sprouts??")  It was cooked perfectly....nice and tender.... and not too spicy.   The kal bi was just ok.  My friend said it was better the last time he came, but still good.  We almost forgot about the pot stickers because they came out last.  We were already getting full, but after trying one, we ended up devouring the whole plate!  They were fried to perfection....nice and juicy on the inside, and crispy on the outside!

You will come out smelling like Korean BBQ, so make sure you bring Febreeze if you're headed out to a club afterwards.  =)
author: Patra I.

description: I came here to eat on a busy Friday night and it was packed. The chicken wings were dry and overcooked. Next I ordered thr bibimbap and instantly regreted it. It tasted extremely bland and came with two tiny pieces of beef. My friend ordered a plate with rice cake and calamari, and that didn't even came with the rice cake. Service was good for a busy night. Would not recommend ordering those dishes.
author: Tony C.

description: Oh man this place is excellent. I got the kimchi and pork tofu soup #25 and the fried chicken #67. My wife ordered a kimchi bibimbap #6. All were excellent!  The complementary Korean appetizers were better than most I've had at other Korean restaurants. I came here from sacramento about a year ago and it was so good that we came back again and I'm glad I did.
author: Nathan C.
