description:
This is a small, cozy Korean place, almost hole-in-the-wall ish. I came here with a group of 5 people around 6 and we were able to get seated with no wait. The décor is casual, there's a bunch of mirrors everywhere.

We had the bulgolgi and galbi meats. I was not impressed with these, I've had better in San Jose. It wasn't horrible, but it was dry or something. I guess I expected better. The seafood tofu soup, however, was delicious!! I'd come here just for the tofu soup, yum!

When we left around 7:30, the restaurant was crowded and there were people waiting outside.

We also ordered a "pitcher" of beer and it came in a big plastic bottle. Kinda funny.
author: Kristina N.

description:
Solid Korean food. 

Being a 2nd generation Korean and having awesome cooks in the family.. myself being one.. (shameless plug) ^_^.. I'm very keen about my Korean cuisine.. I am not snobbish.. but can distinguish average to above the bar kind of cooking.. 

Also, my parents living down in SJ where they got a whole lucky array of spots on El Camino Real, I only have a hand full of selections here in SF.

That being said, I finally ventured into Shin Toe Bul Yi after passing this place a million times going and coming home from work in the fidi. 

Always intrigued by the well patron'ed restaurant as I pass by... I finally decided to try it out.. 

I ordered Yuk Hae Jang.. which Korean people know for as hangover stew/soup. I just had came from drinking down town and needed a quick fix.

Overall, decent portion and taste. Wasn't too salty which I think a lot of Korean cuisine can be.. and the ingredients were pretty fresh to my knowledge.

The banchan selection was pretty standard.. And I judge a Korean restaurant first by their Kimchi..

They fuck that up... you know shits going down hill from there....That being said, the Kim-chi wasn't bad.. wasn't spectacular.. If you want spectacular Kim-Chi... Kun Jip in Santa Clara has really damn good Kim-chi.

I will return and try the Gop-Chang Jigae.. (Intestine Stew)...which goes really good with Soju. =)

Everyone talks about the fried chicken.. and coincidentally when I was there.. almost every table ordered it... Must be doing something right.. right?
author: Jason C.

description: One of the best Korean food I've tasted.  I had my dinner there last night.  The only waitress there was nice and friendly. I ordered seafood bibimbap which was really tasty.  The Tofu soup was given as a compliment in the house which I highly appreciated.  I'll be back again soon.
author: Surfer S.

description:
Who doesn't love free food! No my meal wasn't free but the sweet waitress did give us a complimentary bowl of tofu soup =] !! cha-ching! I'm in love. The soup was really yummy too! Maybe it taste better because it was FREE! (I still love you Tofu House)

We went in around 1:30 p.m., 1 hour before they close for dinner so there wasn't a wait. I was happy because I was STARVING. We looked through the menus and we finally settled down for bibimbaps. The bibimbap was good but the rice was on the mushy side, maybe because of the raw egg so next time I'll just get it fried instead. There was so much leftover I had to take it back home for dinner. So basically I paid $10 for my lunch AND dinner. 

After I paid the bill that's when I thought I should have tipped more. Damn free tofu soup and no extra tip. I hope the lady doesn't hate me =T. Oh well, make it up next time because they WILL be getting a lot more visits from me.
author: Tracy A.

description:
I love this place. I eat here almost every time I'm around the Avenues. It's something about their fried chicken that always makes me come back. 

For two, we always order the deep fried chicken, bulgogi w/ calamari, 1 to 2 bottles of soju and a large hite to chase. They always hook it up with free tofu soup too, not to mention there's also all the side dishes that we get to munch on while we wait for the entrees. 

The wait for a table can be a bit long on busy nights. The place is small. The staff is very friendly. The only downside for me is that sometimes you can get seated really close to another party and it can feel kind of awkward. 

Eat fried chicken with your hands people!
author: Jimmy H.

description:
Decided to come here for dinner one night, the place was packed. But sicne we were only a party of 2 we got seated quite quickly.

So we ordered the fried chicken, sea bass and a bi bim bap..I think thats how you spell it . Anyhow though, overall the food was very good. The chicken was crunchy and pretty juicy, the sea bass had just the right amount of spicyness to it..and the bi bim bap..well tahts always one of my favorite things to eat. There was also a tofu soup on the house~ yay!

I realized with all the food for two people, it looked like a lot..but I actually came out feeling just about right. My stomach wasnt over-stuffed~

I got pictures~ ^______^
author: phillip w.

description:
The pancakes and fried chicken are off the hook!   Food is on the pricier side but is consistent with most Korean spots.  

Service is OK and street parking is usually available around the block.
author: M T.

description:
So we were actually going to get Japanese food, but we had an epic fail. Drove by 4 japanese restaurants, 

Omgggggggg. Yessss. So goood.

I've been here once before with D's family, but we went again just recently with a friend. Sadly, I didn't order the chicken since we werent really in the mood for chicken, but we did get other stuff that was good!

We ordered the seafood tofu soup, grilled mackerel, and also the chicken on the hot plate. As usual it came with sides, but it also came with a cold tofu dish, on the house. The tofu wasn't that special (it was the firmer tofu, not the soft kind that immediately breaks), but it was not bad.

Everything was pretty damn good, and I was pretty pleased. The mackerel was perfectly grilled, and the chicken was a nice and simple dish. Good if you go with someone who hasn't really tried korean. The tofu soup was pretty good, not too spicy if I remember correctly, though thinking back, I wish it had a little more flavor.

Overall, not bad. It's not that cheap, but not too pricey either. But you know, I'll put it up there on my list.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I really like this Korean place. There is a really comfortable, homey feel to the place.

You sit down and they give you my favorite side dish, the green onion pancake. They always have different side dishes whenever we come. Their kalbi is good. Their bulgogi (spicy pork) has too much of this thick sauce on it on my opinion. Their fried chicken is goood. They even give you complimentary grilled mackerel which is also goood.

So it's story time. The first time I came, 8 out of the 10 tables in the place had fried chicken on the table. The only two tables without fried chicken was the only non Asian table and my table. So I decided the next time I would get the fried chicken. So the next time I come in, we ordered the fried chicken AND THEY DIDNT HAVE ANY LEFT. How depressed was I. When I saw the couple that came in before us get a plate of fried chicken, my sadness showed on my face. The waitress asked me what was wrong and I told her that I really wanted fried chicken. She said she was sorry, but they had just a few pieces left so they give it to that couple on the house. :( So sad was I. Then the waitress comes back with a plate of four pieces of chicken and told us that it was HER chicken that she was going to have for dinner! Needless to say, that chicken...was....so....good. 

In conclusion, they really take care of you here; their food is good; its a small place and they sometimes will stop taking people if its nearing closing time. I think its family run so it has a very mom and pop feel to it.
author: Christine L.

description:
This was a pretty decent  find sans Yelp.  What do you do on a scorching hot day in SF?  You go and have spicy Korean food, of course.  

Honestly, the food at STBY was not all that spicy.   The side dishes were rather limited and tiny in portion.  The kimchi was mediocre and not all that spicy.

We ordered:

Seafood pancake- very yummy, great texture and just enough dough.  Plenty of squid.  It comes with a great dipping sauce.  IMHO, this was the best item that we ordered.

Spicy beef- i wasn't too fond of the neon red coloring, which made it look inedible.  It was a bit too sweet and not spicy enough.  

Grilled mackerel- the 2 large pieces were delicious but a bit on the salty side.  We got 2 small pieces of lemon.

Spicy tofu soup- complimentary item. High MSG content and low on spicyness and flavoring. 

The joint is small and gets packed quite fast during peak hours.  Service is a bit slow.  Ambiance is not something you would find here.  The place definitely needs some remodeling and perhaps AC.  

But then again, the food wasn't all that spicy.  STBY gets 3 lackluster stars.
author: Kris H.

description:
I've only been to Korean food once before, and that was back in SoCal, so I have very little to compare this to.  Also no idea what to order.  Fortunately, a quick perusal through the Yelp reviews made the fried chicken an obvious choice.  

We also ordered the sizzling seafood pot and green onion pancake.  Funny story about the pancake--they brought us one, we ate it, then they brought another one.  We thought it was a mistake, but they explained that the first one was actually a complimentary appetizer.  Sweet!  Though in retrospect, maybe they should've alerted us to that when we ordered.  Oh right, this is the SF dive scene, no pity for noobs.  Also, there's the usual array of free Kimchi and friends (AKA Banchan--thank you Wikipedia!), including some fried anchovies that were surprisingly delicious.  As for the chicken, well, I guess this is my new go-to spot for KFC.  And finally, they have this weird brown tea that tastes like Wheaties.  Good once you get the hang of it.  All in all, this was some damn good eatin'.

The atmosphere here is also rather unique and very cozy for an asian dive.  For one, they have carpet, and also lots of windows with these great horizontal blinds.  Combine that with the low ceiling and you get...well, I'm not sure, but it stands out and feels very appropriate for SF.  Will definitely be back.
author: Wes M.

description:
Shin Toe Bul Yi is a far, hole-in-the-wall place, but I'm glad my old boss suggested this place after meeting for Happy Hour on Monday! 

We ordered the kalbi, spicy pork, fried chicken, and clear noodles with beef. 

Kalbi= Ehh, not good. Only a few pieces had char marks on it, and it was quite chewy. It tasted as if it was par boiled and thrown on the grill for a couple of seconds afterwards. 

Spicy Pork=very good. It had just the right amount of seasoning and spiciness. Unlike the Kalbi, it actually tasted like it was bbq. 

Fried Chicken=MMM GOOD. It was super crispy and moist. Now , I only wish they provided some type of sauce for the chicken. 

Clear Noodles with beef=very good. The noodles were al-dente just the way I like them. 

Tofu Soup (Free)=One of the better ones I've tasted. The broth was rich and spicy. The tofu was like silken tofu and melted in my mouth. YUM! 

I'm very sensitive to salt and didn't find their dishes to be overly salty like other reviews had mentioned. 

I will definitely be back for the Fried Chicken no less. Now only if I can convince my bf to go with me...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: If you come here on a weekday for lunch, it's served kind of bento style with no table service. I think it's convenient for people who work nearby. Food is still delicious, lady is still just as friendly. Ventilation is a bit not happening though, so you'll smell like Korean food after you're done. I see no problem with this. Unfortunately for weekday lunch, it also means less of the other banchan, which is what I usually look forward to :/
author: Donna H.

description:
Quality place. I am a loyal Muguboka patron, but I have moved away from the inner richmond to the puter sunset. Shin Toe Bul Yi has become the new Korean spot. 
Panchan is soo good. 
Kim Chee Tofu is the shit.
author: Chelsey G.

description: I come here maybe 1-2 times a month , I really love this place ! Their food is really authentic and really delicious. I usually order either bulgogi or kalbi , its sweet and very good! and i also order their fried chicken that they are really known for , the taste of the batter is different from a lot of places which gives it a unique taste that i really like , also love the small entrees that they give here! especially the spicy fried fish paste , its so good! They also always give a complimentary spicy tofu soup with every meal and its by far my favorite here! I really come here sometimes just for the tofu soup! I love it ! Only thing about this is place it is on the expensive side , but the food here is great!
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
So even though I live in the neighborhood, I've never been because I always see the long lines and I hate, hate, hate waiting for a table anywhere. But after learning that their lunch menu is now to go only, decided to pop in today.

First to dispel one erroneous yelper, you can get the fried chicken for lunch. It's just not a lunch special. The chicken had good seasoning and texture, although some pieces were a little dry. Better than KFC tho.

This place actually is quite the oxymoron. On the outside and even when you go inside the place looks and feels very, very traditional, 
like how you imagine a mom and pop korean restaurant to be like.

But actually the food to me is a little bit like 'americanized' korean food. The bulgogi I ordered was ok, but just didn't have much flavor. In fact all the banchan seemed to be 'watered down' versions. The kimchee wasn't very spicy and the mung sprouts and cucumbers just didn't have enough flavor. IMO the food has made to fit the clientele for this area.  Not too spicy, not too strong flavors. 

I guess if you don't mind the wait and really want the chicken, then this is the place. This just isn't the first place that'll pop in my head the next time I want korean.
author: Dom L.

description:
I went here with a group of friends for my early birthday dinner! This place is really small. We went on a Friday night but didn't have to wait that long for a table for 9. We ordered family style and got about 7 dishes (fried chicken, tofu soups, jap chae, pork bbq dish, spicy rice cakes and other dishes). We got a complimentary fish dish also =]

The food was pretty good. I've definitely had better so I was a little disappointed; however, I will try it again when I'm in SF!
author: Priya B.

description:
I think I had bbq'd beef? It was really really really super gooood! Mom had the bibimbap and she liked it.

The side dishes are delicious!

Completely positive review, but only an average rating. Why?
I went home and I felt like my intestines were tying themselves up. My stomach burned and ached so terribly. :/

Honestly, the food was so good..it was all worth it and I'm willing to come back.
author: Erica A.

description: Very nice Korean restaurant. Specializing in fried chicken which is one thing we ordered and was very very good! If you order two main plates you'll get some appetizers to go with it. Anyway you get lots of food and all of it is plentiful. It is on the expensive side but I think it's well worth it. The only thing you might want to think about is getting there  early cause it will get crowded it's not a big place. Go for it!
author: Keith K.

description:
Before I write this review, I need to voice an opinion about some of my fellow yelpers. Is it really killing you that you can't add 1/2 a star to your reviews? Is your indecisiveness that crippling? Are you the same people that invited me to all those "WE WANT A DISLIKE BUTTON" groups on Facebook? I know you are. Let it go. 

Now, down to business. Shin Toe Bul Yi is not just incredibly fun to say, but it is incredibly fun to eat. And by fun, I mean delicious. It smells awesome inside, and for a place that serves up a lot of seafood dishes, that is an accomplishment. 
When you walk in and take a seat, you'll notice that most of the tables are adorned with what can only be described as crispy, golden, Korean glory - scallion pancake. Why is everyone ordering the scallion pancake? Because it's incredible. Follow the fold. 

Here's what I do:
-Order the scallion pancake. 
-Order the bi bim bap. 
-When both are delivered, take the dipping sauce on the table and smear it over a slice of scallion pancake. 
-Use slathered slice to scoop up bi bim bap. 
-Eat like a pizza.
author: Chanti B.

description:
Homey , warm restaurant with bright white lights. The place feels very asian to me. It's incredibly loud as the guests all try to speak over each other. 
Expect a wait , maybe 20 minutes long. Go in and look for the little notepad-- that's the wait list. The pen they provided wasnt even working so I tried real hard to desperately scratch my name onto the list. The waitress ended up crossing off my name for some reason, probably assuming it was too messy. Maybe bring your own pen if you plan to go. 

I feel terrible for the 2 ladies [the wait staff]. Too much to do , too many tables for the 2 of 'em! 

Bulgogi was about $18. Pretty pricey. 
The famous fried chicken that every table gets, is ok. Crunchy but taste wise not extremely special. They give you maybe even 12 pieces. it's a lot! 
Complimentary tofu soup. It's red but it's not spicy. Good.

For two people, our bill amounted to almost $50. O that's too much for me..
author: Veranna N.

description:
I was introduced here by friends a long time ago and have been coming here ever since. This place is very small. Sucks half of the time when you have to wait, but lately we've been lucky and have always gotten a table right when we enter....*knock on wood* Lots of complimentary dishes, including the green onion pancake and spicy tofu soup. Once in a while they'll throw in the grill mackerel.

We normally order the Bul-go-gi, Rice Cake bok yi, Baby Octopus Bok-Um, Jap-Chae along with several bottles of Hite beer. I've tried the Korean fried chicken here as raved by everybody here. This was probably the most spiciest for me out of every dish I have tried here. Nonetheless, it was good!

After trying various Korean BBQ places, I have got to say this place isn't exactly the best, but their food is good enough to keep us coming back for our occasional get-togethers.
author: Serena W.

description:
MY OH MY HAVE I MISSED KOREAN FOOD SINCE MOVING BACK UP FROM LA! 

I wish I could give it 4 stars but it doesn't compare to K-town in LA. But it is probably the best, hidden gem in Sunset (I've lived here for 10+ years and haven't tried it till now). 

We ordered...

1. Bibimbap - it was but it lacked much flavor. I'm not the biggest fan of bibimbap so I may be biased

2. Rice cake - this was my favorite dish of the night. It is awesomeness in your tongue all the way down to your tummy.

3. Seafood Pancake - MHMMMMMMMMM GET IT!

4. FREE TOFU SOUP - Did I mention FREE?! Well, it goes pretty good if you mix the rice but other than that, it's pretty plain BUT FREE!

5. Bulgogi - it was ok, tasted kind of fake but good.

Overall, I can't believe I haven't tried this place until now. It's kind of hard to find as it's not over the top flashy, but it's right in front of the L Taraval stop.

Just go and you'll know what I'm talking about.
author: David W.

description:
This is my first Yelp review regarding service.  Lemme say that the food is great!   Me and my gf have come back several times and other Yelpers have covered the basics.  

But depending on who the waitress is will dictate whether the experience at this place is a 2 star or 5 star.  

I can't remember her name but there is one waitress who is always positive, smiling or if not, working super hard to help everybody and just adds to the whole dining experience.  When she has worked there, experience has always been 5 stars!  In fact, that's why we've keep coming back.

Buuuuut...  there is this newer waitress, who sadly I think has either replaced the nicer waitress, or works more hours now, who is a total b****.    Basically, one day me and the gf ask for more radish, kim chi, all the little stuff that they typically give you in the beginning of your meal and she gives off this really negative vibe and says that they charge extra for it.  WTF???  I've never had that in my life.  I got the vibe like she thought we were someone else or she had a bad experience with ppl who took advantage of those little dishes, but it wasn't us!  We were asking for our very first refill.  Anyways, she gives attitude to my gf (but in fairness, my gf had given her this mean look back which probably didn't help the situation)  

Ok, so that's one bad day.  whatever..  

We come back after a few months cuz we remember the food and the cool waitress, but we get PMS girl again.  So I try to be cool and hope that neither of the ladies remember each other.  I even smile, say hello and am super polite to this waitress, my gf doesn't say a word, is quiet and laid back.  We order our food, and when I ask for a water refill, I get a surprising "what else do you want?" with a negative attitude.  Meanwhile, she's chatting it up with another table in Korean.  For the record, I'm of asian descent, and my gf's Chinese so it's not like we look foreign (if that was the case) so I have no clue why this chick gives us attitude.

Anyways, after typing all this, I realize it's just not worth the hassle to come back.  I'm sorry to type that but this one waitress is the reason I'm giving this place two stars.
author: C J.

description:
This place was really good! It was packed, but the single server working the floor managed to seat me, take my order, and get food out quick. Sizzling bi bim bap was good, tofu was good, veggies were good. 

They have Hite too, which is always a plus.
author: Tyson T.

description:
The fried chicken is so good.

My favorite Korean place in the city, so far.  There is typically a line around dinner time because the place is so small.  But to me, the food is totally worth it.

My friend and I had a kim chi pancake, bulgogi, and last but not least--the fried chicken.  All three dishes were extremely good.  They even gave us a really good soup, on the house, so that was pretty cool.  The serving sizes were large, and we had lots of leftovers.  It's OK...  I wouldn't mind just coming up for the fried chicken.
author: Thuan N.

description:
KFC will never mean the same to me again.  Ever.  I will return to this later.

Friend Maria and I got there right at 6 PM on a Thursday night.  Fully expecting throngs of people chanting "K-F-C!  K-F-C!", we were pleasantly surprised to walk right in and grab a cozy table for two.  The smorgasbord of free food was a great start to our meal--we were munching on radishes, kim chee, those little dried fish AND the broiled mackerel AND the Korean pancakes--and a thought emerged from my inner hairy miser: "Should I even order?"  I dismissed the fleeting thought and we ordered the KFC, kalbi and the reddish/orangy brothy soup with noodles, beef  and sprouts.  

The KFC was crunchy but did not live up to its Yelp hype--call me crazy or Filipino--but it would've tasted great with spicy Mafran.  Mafran is the go-to condiment of the Filipino palate--a banana-flavored ketchup that hovers somewhere between sweet-tangy goodness and nasty fruity concoction.  But I digress.  The kalbi was dry and not tender and juicy like I expected.  The soup whose name I can't remember was the best part of our meal--coz' soup goes with Outer Sunset weather all year round.

All in all, I would go back and sample the recommendations beyond the KFC.  But for now a 3-star experience.
author: Joc V.

description:
Excellent food! I'm glad I looked this place up on Yelp... You guys didn't steer me wrong! The plates were full of wonderful flavor, but not overpowering. Meals come with the typical Korean side dishes, and I believe a spicy tofu soup was on the house as well. Oh, and free RICE! You can't eat Korean food without RICE! I hate when places charge for rice, so I'm glad this place doesn't!!!

The glass noodles with beef and veggies was DELICIOUS! My favorite of the dishes that I ordered by far... But there's still much to try on the menu, so I wouldn't put that in stone!

The only thing I wasn't happy about was when we got there, it was a full house and I had no idea I was supposed to write my name down on the little yellow notepad. Minor issue, I know. The food made up for it, though.
author: Sara K.

description: It's getting harder and harder to label a Korean shop as my favorite place. Each restaurant has their "best" whatever. I love this place though because of the cool, relaxing service and the sogogi sundobu. It's thicker and much more "homestyle" than other places. And I love family-run businesses.
author: Ethan L.

description:
came here with nomming teammates last weekend; Missy A. decided to treat us all to dinner (we are pretty sure she did something she shouldn't have done at the halloween party the night prior...hmmm) and Shin Toe it was, for nommy Korean fare!

Rolled in at around 8.30pm on a Saturday night, waited for about 15 minutes outside. Ordered the fail-safe fried chicken and seafood pancake, also ordered the kimchi bimbimbap and spicy bulgogi, all to be shared among the four of us.

Fried chicken satisfied our cravings for sure - fingers were licked and crispy, juicy battered chicken pieces reduced to bones in double time.
seafood pancake was addictive - crispy around the edges and the batter was not cloyingly thick. not too generous in terms of seafoodiness though, but it wasn't complaint-level skimping.
kimchi bimbimbap was just meh - it could have been spicier, kimchier, better, it was really quite bland. however! we were starving - at least i was - and so, found this to be quite enjoyable. the crispy bits of rice at the bottom, i scraped. shamelessly.
spicy bulgogi was okay - i'm not the biggest fan of bulgogi to begin with, but the homies seem to enjoy this with rice.

got the free bowl of tofu soup; flat tasting, but we dumped in the fiery-looking (not so fiery-tasting) dipping sauce that came with the banchan, and it made the soup taste better.

Shin Toe was literally, my first ever food experience in San Francisco when I got my fobby self here so and so many years ago. Got off the plane at SFO just as the sun was setting, took a cab to my homie's place on Taraval, slipped into a 40-minute nap, fought blustery winds as we trekked five blocks to the restaurant.........where my tummeh was filled with love. i believe i will always have a soft spot for this place.
author: Eliza D.

description:
This is a small place that can only accommodate 1-6 people per table.
The waitresses can be rude because when I came in and put down 11 people on the paper, the waitress said oh sorry we can't accommodate 11 people and I told her, it didn't matter and you can split us in 5-6 peoples per table.
Foods:
Stirfry Octopus with veggies- GOOD!
BBQ beef ribs- it is alright and it was hard to chew
All side dishes: GOOD
Noodle dish: GOOD
Kimichi soup with tofu: GOOD

Since they knew they were rude, they gave us 2 free dishes of foods.

However try it out since it ain't bad for korean foods.
author: A X.

description:
Went here last night for the first time for a dinner w/ the bf and friends. It was 8:30p when we got on the waiting list (a clipboard on the counter).  There isn't much space to wait inside so be sure to wear a coat so you won't freeze to death while outside. haha.  At around 9:10p they "closed" the waitlist even though they close at 9:30p.  They took our orders while we waited (which was quite nice because our food was ready within 5 minutes of sitting down (9:20!).  We ordered fried chicken but they said they sold out! We must have looked so disappointed because magically they brought out a plate of fried chicken! And the server said "You reeeeaaaallly wanted the fried chicken, right?!". YAY! That made our night.  

The food:

I didn't try the small plates they provided before dinner (mainly because our main dishes were already out!) but I'll be sure to try them next time.

Kimchee Bibimbap: LOVED IT!  Perfect mix of kimchee and beef and egg!  I could probably eat the entire bowl myself (ok, ok. half the bowl), but we all ordered different things and shared.

Fried chicken: It is delicious. It is salty, and juicy. MSG? perhaps, but I'm not allergic to it, so I was A-OK.

Onion pancake: Eh. I had a bite. That was all. It's huge though (probably 12in in diameter!)

We had a chicken dish to replace the "sold-out" friend chicken... It was the boneless chicken (on the back of the menu). It was sweet (not sticky sweet, but a light glaze). I'd definitely get this again.

We also got the beef and vegetable and egg soup.  It wasn't as spicy as I was anticipating (By spicy, I mean nose running, sweat dripping from all pores of my face. hahaha).  But the spice built up the more I consumed the broth. YUMMY! I'd get this again too!

The tea they serve with dinner was also really yummy. :)

All in all, a great experience despite the wait.  The fact that they provided the sold out chicken to us was definitely a bonus, but their other food was also really good so I'd know what to order the next time I go here!
author: Roxanne K.

description: The bibimbap is very good.  I like that some dishes come with complementary soup or fish.  The tofu soups are pretty good and the bulgogi has a nice marinate.  They close on sunday though.
author: Z G.

description:
Chicken?  Really now?  That stuff is really dry and doesn't taste like much without the sauce.  Worth a try I guess, but not the best dish there.

Seafood pancake is where it's at.  I could eat that all day every day.  With that soy sauce with scallions.  I LOVED IT.
author: Anna T.

description:
maybe we ordered the wrong things but the food that was complementary i.e. the Banchans were actually better than what we ordered.  

~ fried chicken: every table got the fried chicken so we decided to get it too.  man we were wrong.  it was sooooo dry.  my friend and i decided that it might taste better once we take off the skin. nope it was still dry and hard. 

~ seafood pancake:  bland tasting and then we asked for the dipping sauce that they forgot to give us.  the sauce improve the taste dramatically. 

~ banchans and tofu soup:  yes the complementary stuff is the only thing that is allowing me to give this place 3 stars.  their tofu soup was just perfect.  not too salty or spicy.  

they did, however, forgot to give us the fish which they gave to all the other table and when we asked for it they didn't understand what we were asking for.  

my quest for good korean food in SF continues on.......
author: JY L.

description:
Likes: japchae noodles, complimentary fish yum, six side dishes and rice with beef tofu soup.

Dislikes:  japchae was good but on the oily side because it was oily on the bottom of the plate.
author: Karen M.

description:
One word to sum up the disappointment after tonight's dinner - roach.

Yup.  Took pieces of the leftover Korean pancake home and heard Jr. Yelper gag in the kitchen after taking a bite of one of the pieces. The pancake was mushy and not crispy enough.  Fortunately, Jr. Yelper had not taken too large a bite.  The roach was inside the piece of pancake.  Hubby confirmed it was in there and went "gross".  

Up until then, we and our friends thought the food was not bad at all compared to other Korean restaurants we've been to.  The tofu soup was good and the small plates accompanying the meal was OK.  I liked their fried chicken which was a popular dish ordered by other diners.  The pan fried fish was too dry. The rib eye beef was good, not great. And the stir-fried calamari was rather spicy.  We told our friends about the roach and they don't plan on making a return visit.  Not sure we will too until they fix their infestation problem.

It's rather confusing as to the name of this place.  In the telephone directory as well as how they answer the phone, it's Han Bat Korean Restaurant, not Shin Toe Bul Yi.
author: Ry T.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant. They comp onion pancake, tofu soup, and sometimes grilled mackerel. My family loves the fried chicken here. I think it is just okay. Must be eaten hot. I love the Jap Chae (clear yam noodles stir-fried with bits of veggies and beef) and the barbecue shortribs (kalbi). I also like the spicy pork which really isn't that spicy. They also have the best variety and taste in ban chan (assortment of side dishes, mostly veggie, like kimchee). Service can be good or bad depending on who is working. But they try. Mostly family owned and operated, I think.
author: Carrie W.

description:
not bad, but strangely enough our party did not find the fried chicken to be the most spectacular thing we ordered. don't get me wrong, it was good fried chicken, but not what we want when craving korean fried chicken, i mean, where's the spicy sauces and such?!?

anyways, the tofu with spicy pork was a nice change of pace and the seafood pancake were real standouts for us. the soft tofu soup was pretty standard. The quality of the panchan was pretty good though, though not as varied as I would've liked. still, a great neighborhood stop, though not sure worth travelling too far for. service was good, friendly and prompt.
author: Phuoc K.

description:
I was taken here in a half hearted attempt at corporate espionage and since I wasn't paying, I ordered a shit ton of food. 

Highlights include: spicy tofu soup, seafood pancake and pork bulgogi

I also drank an entire bottle of OB beer to myself after shots across the street so it was a very surreal experience to say the least. Luckily we were sitting with some VERY rambunctious korean businessmen who ordered a bottle of sake each and were red by the end of the meal.
author: dr S.

description:
Shin Toe Bul Yi offers some of the best Korean food I've had in SF.  The flavor is spot on, and the dishes are as authentic as they come.  Grilled BBQ meats, esp. galbi, have the smoky flavor that you get from grilling on a grill versus in a pan, and unlike the water down version that's served in most Korean restaurants, their casseroles and soups have a real kick to it.    

The only drawback ... and it's a big one ... is the appearance of the restaurant from the outside, as it is absolutely grim, and I'd driven by it twice thinking that it was an abandoned building.  The interior of the restaurant is small but comfortable, and the owners are really nice and accommodating.
author: S. I.

description:
3.5 stars.

I know of this place for over 10 years. I used to live a block away and had owned a store a block up. I was so used to the smell and the line at the door. However, I have never tried it. The girlfriend was craving for Korean food this evening so I thought why not give it a try.

- Bi Bim Bap: great taste, we really enjoyed the rice with raw egg favorite.
- Fried yellow fish: not bad, they tasted like those home made fried fish from my Korean friends.
- Fried chicken: pretty good in a different way, KFC's is tastier but a lot more greasy. It's crispy on the outside and still juicy on the inside while I didn't notice much oil in the plate. Very good dish with beer.

I'll need to bring more friends here to try more dishes. We'll be back.
author: Rio T.

description:
The fact that this restaurant is a hole-in-the-wall in a less accessible part of the city makes me like it more.  I don't like the big Asian restaurants on big streets who think they are so WELL-HUNG.  I like these hole-in-the-wall places that serve authentic meals without waving their big HUNG's around.  Every time I've been here, I've had great Korean food and service.  Of course, I can't complain about all those freebie dishes, either.

1 star off: totally smelled like smokey Korean food afterwards...the cast of Ratatouille followed me home
author: Ally W.

description: Amazing Korean BBQ, what more is there to say? The outside of this place looks like a run down shack but don't let the lack of aesthetics turn you away! The food is delicious and while the service can suck at times it's only because it gets PACKED as the night goes on. Overall delicious BBQ in the sunset :)
author: Seiji S.

description: Tasty, lots, reasonable and attentive service. What more? Combine best fried chicken planet with veg specialities and happy crowd and it's a draw to the Taraval Trolley Trail. I'll overlook the fight that broke out here a few years back that added extra Kim chi to the evening.
author: Fred  D.

description:
BEWARE CHINESE PEOPLE!! THESE KOREAN LADIES DISLIKE US!!!
We had a friend visiting from Asia and she wanted some Korean food, we came here based on ratings. I would expect a 4 star to have good food and good service. I cannot comment on the food since we did not even get to sit down, but their staff were TERRIBLE TERRIBLE TERRIBLE!!! 

We went in there and wrote down our name for party of 4, there was a party of 2 in front of us. There was no greeting, zero communication. We waited for about 10 minute, two tables freed up, a large table fits 6 people and a small table fits 2. The tables remained empty for another 15min, then for god knows what reason, they sitted the party of 2 at the big table. We stood there like stupid for another 15-20min, the small table is still empty and the large table is sitted with only 2 people, still zero communication, I decided to stop one of the lady and asked her when are we going to be sitted, SHE LOOKED AT ME, WITHOUT SAYING A WORD AND WALKED AWAY!!! HOW RUDE!!! I felt absolutely INSULTED!! I have no evident to say they are racist, but I felt it from the way they stared! I thought maybe we did something that makes them angry, but all we did were standing there in front of the cold freezing entrance chatting with our foreign guest in Chinese. Maybe it was the chinese part, who knows!

We wasted 45minute waiting and all we ended up was disgusting greasy smell all over our clothes. Not to mention they have poor ventilation and tables are packed! We went to JANG SOO BBQ instead, and we only wished we were here sooner! it is like heaven and hell, from service to food to environment, Jang Soo is 100% better then this place. AVIOD SHIN TOE BUL YI!!!!!!!!
author: Wan Y.

description:
One of the better Korean restaurants in San Francisco. They have a pretty wide selection of food to choose from and you can always ask them to help you change something and they would gladly do it. The service here is descent. The waitress is nice, but when it gets busy, it takes awhile to get her attention.

I tried the Japchae, Tteokbokki, Kalbi, and their Fried Chicken. I think the Japchae was pretty good, has enough flavor but I wish it had a bit more meat in it. The Tteokbokki is really good too, although not as spicy as I expected, at least they gave us a lot of peices of tteokbokki unlike this other korean restaurant i went to (not saying the name, but u can find it if u read my other reviews.) The Kalbi had good flavor and was cooked very well, but pricey for the amount they gave us... either that or the guys ate it so fast that I didn't realize it... I really like the fried chicken. The outside was crispy and easy to bite into (unlike some fried chicken where the outside is like a shell) and the chicken was cooked perfectly and juicy too. Soooo yummy! loved the flavor of it too, although I would prefer a little bit more flavor.
author: Alicia W.

description:
grilled meat lacks flavor. the bulgogi was dry.

complementary tofu soup, but then again, their prices are a bit higher than other places. 

just an average korean restaurant. very very old decor....
author: Erica L.

description:
REAL good Korean food right here.

A small spot in the middle of nowhere.  Looks like a house converted to a restaurant.  But it was busy in here.  The place was full and people were clicking shotglass after shotglass of soju.  I love it.

The food was real tasty and delish.  We ordered the kalbi and their special deep fried chicken.  Both were excellent and very satisfying.  The chicken was extremely crunchy and extra delicious.  We were also given a tofu soup on the house.

Lots of good food here.  Check it out!
author: Chai S.

description:
This is the 2nd Korean restaurant I've been to in SF and it's the best, so far! We ordered the Jap Chae, Kal Bi (short ribs), Soft Tofu Stew, and the Chicken Teriyaki. They were all amazing! 2 of my friends never had jap chae before and they couldn't stop raving about it! I've ordered jap chae before at other places but i don't remember it tasting that great. The kal bi and chicken teriyaki were superb! I'm usually not huge fan of meat but this was delicious. The place is nice and clean. They also give a lot of side dishes that accompany the meals, and we took some home because it was too much. We also received a free fish because my friends knew of the owners! Price is $10+. 

My rice tea spilled on the table twice.. i think the tables are crooked o.O
author: Vicki L.

description:
Just OK. Don't think I'll go back. I'd drive out to Geary to get better Korean. 

Good
Free mackerel with 3 dishes
Cheaper than most Korean places
Small neighborhood restaurant 
Onion pan cake

Bad 
The do sol bi bim bop (stone pot) not hot enough and had a raw egg in. In the end after mixing was Mushy rice. Not crispy rice
Bean paste soup. Just OK
Pan chan or side dishes. Not home made. Simple pickled stuff with jar like kimchee
author: Sam S.

description: Ahmazingggg Korean food. Completely delicious. Huge portions and very kind service. I knocked off a star because it wasn't the most spic and span restaurant I've been to, but the food will knock your socks off. My husband says its better than Brothers, which is quite a statement for him! We will be back!
author: Kristen C.

description: I have to say i've been to many korean restaurant in the bay! This place is the best korean food in the bay! I recommend the fried chicken!
author: Kiho K.

description:
The elusive "Tong Dak" continues to elude, and with each disappointment, the passion for the quest subsides. I've only had it at the now defunct Koko House in Berkeley, where Oriental BBQ Chicken Town now resides. Unfortunately they don't offer Tong Dak either.

Cut to the chase: Tong Dak is the whole chicken fried or rotisseried then fried, the WHOLE BIRD IN ONE PIECE. If you know a place, please let me know and maybe I won't be too fat from eating all this fried chicken.

A reputable source said they had it here, but alas it wasn't offered. The pieces of fried chicken were thickly battered, but nicely fried. Unfortunately it didn't hit the spot for me, but they were good in their own right, albeit with dry white meat.

The kimchi chigae was rather thin, but I hear the soondubu is the thing to get here. Why though, when you have My Tofu House on Geary?

This is a neighborhood spot, the prices are CHEAP, and tables tend to get freebies. Unfortunately, I don't live in the neighborhood.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I'm confused, I thought this place was Shin Toe Bul Yi? Oh well whatever, I still call it the Chicken Deli place, haha. I'm not Korean but I do enjoy Korean food!

I hate hate hate hate hate the long wait for this place sometimes. It gets super crowded around dinner time so I reccomend going either a little later or a little earlier. When there's a wait, you sign your name on a clipboard and if you're lucky, you can grab one of the like, 3 or 4 chairs they have for waiting or you can brave it outside in the damn San Francisco fog. I do not do well with cold. Anyways. 

I usually go with a group of friends and we order the beef tofu stew, jap chae, pork bulgogi, and pending on who I am with - the octopus. The watiresses are generally friendly, although sometimes they might forget your water on busy nights. 

After you're seated, they start you off with a green onion pancake (on the house!) that comes with its own little dipping sauce. I usually find myself fighting my friends to the death for the last piece. If you order a certain amount, they give you grilled mackeral (also on the house).

It's not the best Korean food there is out there, but they're not shiesty with their panchan (yes they give you seconds if you ask) and it is DIRT CHEAP for Korean. 

Definitely one of my favorites. =)
author: Susy C.

description:
Split a #14 Haemul Dupbap Lunch Special (sauteed ssoted seafood, veggies, and egg--i asked for egg white--over rice) for $7.95 with a friend and we were stuffed at the end. It came on a tray with kimchee, some picked daikon-my fav of the banchans, seasoned fish cakes-the thin kind, seasoned cucumber, and some bean sprouts. It came with that awesome hot sauce for bi bim bap which we covered it with and mixed together. There was squid, squid tentacles, some thin and some tube-like fish cakes, and some small shrimp mixed in. I thought it was really tasty and the egg scramble tasted similar to the egg I've tasted on Japanese okayodon. We also came with tea.
I've only come at lunch, so I'm not sure if this system applies for dinner, but we ordered at the counter and then sat down and had our food brought to us (like crepevine or squat and gobble). Some days, I really want that kind of service.
There were only 2 other customers in the restaurant during our time there. Quiet, slightly small (about 40-50 or so people perhaps?), but very friendly service and good food!
1 star off for gloomy atmosphere, but it may have been just due to the rainy weather outside
author: Alice R.

description:
MAN, haven't been back here in a while...their hours are so weird...  :(

BUT we loved the food and the service was EXCELLENT!  They are super friendly and very humble.  I remember I was telling the lady the food was really yummy and she was so thankful :)  We went for lunch and the place was not too busy.  Parking is pretty easy; better than Geary foshow.  The kalbi and bulgogi were very flavorful + yummy...and the banchan is alot better than freaking Teo.. ... :)  I'd like to come back soon!  It's been a while.

Again, we had excellent service when we went for lunch around 12ish~~
author: Kat C.

description:
disclaimer: i came 30 minutes after food was served (i was late)

pancake was okay but sauce was awesome
squid dish was okay
the bulgogi was really good
didn't get to try any of the side dishes
the soup with the chewy dumplings and glass noodles was alright
complementary fish was yummy even cold (i was late, remember?)

service was super nice. they weren't mean about me coming in late (i had gotten lost, okay? i'm new to to the city.) and my party having finished eating already.

i have had better, don't know if i'd travel over just for dinner. appears slightly desolate area but the restaurant itself is cozy and pretty full for a tuesday.
author: Vicki T.

description:
Order the fried chicken before they run out!  They will cut up a whole chicken, fry up the pieces, and serve it with cubed pickled sweet radishes, which is the perfect complement to this dish.  

The restaurant itself is a modest place with a 45 minute to 1 hour wait.  Come for the food and leave your fancy dinner dates for another night. :)
author: Jenny K.

description:
Really don't understand what all the hype is about.  This was probably one of the worst Korean restaurants I've eaten at.  I came here for dinner with a friend before going to see a movie and we ordered the soon doobu (soft tofu soup) and nak jee bokkeum (stir-fried spicy calamari).  The spicy calamari was OK, but pretty bland and not spicy at all.  The soft tofu soup tasted like tofu and veggies in hot water.

One of my rules for eating out is to not pay for something I could cook better, so I probably won't be back any time soon.
author: Jen L.

description:
I would've never realized that this place was here if I never yelped it out. It's honestly not very memorable based on how it looks from the outside. It's a hole in the wall.

I don't have a spectacular opinion with this place. It's one if those that I would say "ehhh, it's alright." The food is expensive. But what Korean places around here isn't? I always love the complimentary dishes. You can't really screw up on those. What actually surprised me was that they also gave out free spicy tofu soup. That was a good plus most  places would charge about $8 - $10 for that. 

We ordered the bulgogi and the "spicy" fried chicken. I've always gotten grilled bulgogi that came in a sizzling plate, however it seemed like they only panned fried the ones here. It was just ok. I personally like the grilled ones a lot more.

My "spicy" fried chicken was a bit disappointing. First of all it was not a bit spicy. Where did my spice go? Secondly I thought they were all kind of dry. Dang...and I had so much high hopes for it. I was so sad after. :(

Oh and the service kind of sucked. There was only one lady working and we had to ask her twice before we got what we wanted. 

Total for our bill was about $45 for bugolgi, fried chicken and a bottle of beer.  I don't know. I felt like it wasn't worth that much for just "ok" food.
author: Shirley T.

description:
Keep in mind, I'm not a huge fan of Korean food; only when it's a cold night.  That being said:

Not a bad place; fast, quick friendly service.  For $30, you'll get quite a bit of food.  The Kim Chee's not bad and the hot pot tofu stew is excellent.  I had the #7 yesterday and it's ok.  I mean it's edible and flavorful but just not spectacular.    I also tried some kind of barbeque meat dish.  I love the taste of lighter fluid on the beef, but it was a tad too oily; it would have been ok, but there was an entire plate of this meat.  A half a serving would have been enough.

Also, prior to ordering, you'll be served some interesting dumplings with a simple, tasty, lightly spicy pepper sauce.  Pretty good.

That being said, this is a great place to eat at on a cold night which is 90% of San Francisco nights.  It can get crowded from what I've heard.  On Halloween night, it was at 90% occupancy at 8:30pm.

If you are cold, eat here.  There will be hot barley/corn tea on your table before you can ponder how cold you are.  You won't feel rushed in this simple, homey place with outdated interior design, but superb service.

The overall atmosphere of the place is blue collar like, for lack of a better term.  There are no frills and the space is somewhat crowded.
author: Tony U.

description: They give you lots extra food.  Go in a little bit bigger group and more will come.  A little pricey but lots of bang for your buck.  I ate this for 2 meals and a snack.  Just add rice.
author: Ashley I.

description:
I really liked the tofu soup that came with the meal. They use very nicely textured soft tofu in their soup. I ordered the bibimbap but it had very little beef in it. Korean Village's bibimbap is much better. My friend had the very large seafood pancake and that tasted .. okay. We did get a lot of food from just ordering two main dishes and had leftovers because we just could not eat it all.

It seems the fried chicken is the major draw here and I should try that next time. The grilled short beef ribs at the next table looked delicious also. I'll come try their other dishes and see if those might be better than what we ordered. Efficient service from the waitresses and, yes, the Muni train did rumble past the restaurant at each pass!
author: Everso T.

description:
shin toe bul yi, yes:
a personal favorite
much unlike the rest

a korean feast
is what my friends and I say,
one order - jap chae!

and the fried chicken
tasty tofu soup, kal bi...
plus seafood pancake!

can be extremely 
busy, be prepared to wait
'tis worth it, damn straight.
author: stevie b.

description:
K lives just one block away from this place and every time we go in and out of his house, we smell their delicious Korean BBQ. I'm always conflicted when we're about to leave for another restaurant because I catch the smell of their juicy Kalbi ribs.

The scene:

The place gets super packed, but oddly enough, we got a table for 6 right away last time we came. Make sure you wear old clothes because you'll smell like Korean food when you leave.

Service is lacking, however. They turned me away once since I came at 9 and they closed at 9:30. They also forget to give you some of the free items such as the soup or the fried fish.

The food:

What's great at Korean restaurants is the plethora of appetizers. You have the kimchi, pickled turnips, cucumbers, anchovies, fish cake, bean sprouts as well as kimchi tofu soup or a fried fish. I think the rule of thumb at this (and most) Korean restaurants is if you order soup, you get a fried fish; if you don't order soup, you get the house tofu soup.     Shin Toe Bul Yi does give seconds on the mini trays of appetizers - major plus in my book since I can't get enough of that fish cake.

Calamari Bok (sautéed rice cake, calamari and vegetables in spicy sauce) - This is my faaaavorite dish at this restaurant. It's made with 4-5" pieces of the chewy rice cake sautéed in a sweet and spicy sauce. I'm not big on calamari though, so I ate around it.

Pork Bul-Go-Gi (broiled lean pork marinated in spicy sauce) - This is K's favorite dish. The thin slices of pork are marinated in the same sweet and spicy sauce. The meat is very tender and has great flavor. The only thing that worries me about this dish is the bright red color; it doesn't seem natural.

Kal Bi (beef short rib marinated in house special sauce) - Koreans make some dang good short ribs. I just love their marinade. It's sweet, salty and spicy. This Kal Bi was much meatier than other Korean short ribs. Usually, a majority of the pieces are just fat and bones.

Chicken Small Pieces (deep fried) - Last but not least is the fried chicken - hands down, the most popular dish at the restaurant. It's not your typical fried chicken that you get at KFC or Popeyes. The chicken is very crispy. I'm pretty sure they use cornstarch rather than flour for their batter. The cornstarch brings the crunchiness to a whole other level. After the chicken has been deep fried, it's sprinkled with a spicy powder. One time I came here, we had a ton of chicken left over and I accidentally dropped 3 pieces on the floor when boxing it up. I was SO devastated!
author: Sam L.

description:
Fried Chicken - The thing everyone raves about. It's nothing terribly impressive. The meat is juicy and the portions are huge. It's deep-fried so it can't be too awful in terms of flavor. Good luck arteries.

Beef Bulgogi - Not as flavorful as other Korean restaurants. I think if they used fresher meats, it might be better off.

Jap Chae - Not bad. Not bad at all. I liked their noodles and it's a nice change from a meaty meal.

Tofu soup - Yummy for the tummy. It's a little spicy but gives the flavors that much more character. Glad this comes with most meals.

Other sides - I like their kimchee, bean sprouts, and the small fishes. The other sides are alright. 

The wait here can be long. Maybe, 1/2 to 1 hour during peak hours (usually 6-7pm until 8pm, not sure about lunch time). The portions are huge and you're practically assured to not go hungry. It's not the best Korean food in the world but it's a pretty good deal for food. Go with a group to get the most out of your money. Otherwise, the bill is somewhat steep.

3.5 stars
author: Jonathan L.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean restaurants.  The place doesn't look like much outside, so you'll most likely end up passing right by it if there isn't a crowd of people standing by the door.  It's really small and crampy inside, but the food is delicious.  

This place was back and forth with the food quality for a while.  What I mean by that is years ago it was really good, then up until a few months ago the flavors were lacking.  Now it's really good again.  They stopped giving complimentary Korean pancakes though, which sucks because it's pretty pricey for what it is (dough and green onions).  They still give the spicy soft tofu soup on the house though.  You come out smelling like Korean BBQ but it's worth it.
author: Sandy J.

description:
We were in the mood for Korean, but thought Toyose may be crowded so we headed over here and after a few times circling around, we got a parking spot right across the street!

I was so indecisive on what to order..but we decided on sharing the famous fried chicken & he got the beef dolsot bibimbap which has kimchee in it and some seaweed, which I'm not too big on, but it was okay, and at least some of the rice got crunchy, like it's supposed to!  I only liked the bean sprouts and cucumber banchan dishes & looking at the anchovies totally gave me the creeps!  The fried chicken pieces are totally unidentifiable; don't try to guess what piece of the chicken you got, just eat it!  I thought it was okay and the plate was plentiful for the price, but I don't think it lived up to the hype.  I liked the batter and the pieces weren't dry, but it was just okay, and it was not spicy at all like the menu said!  The waitress did bring us comp kimchee tofu soup and a bowl of rice (since my fried chicken was a la carte), I thought that was nice.  I loved the soup, it was not overly spicy and had plenty of veggies in it and so much soft pillowy pieces of tofu.  

If you'd like to get here early come no later then around 6, the place is small and gets packed, and there's only two waitresses.
author: Cat C.

description:
#1 thing to know- psssttt First timers... this is a must. Fried Chicken is the thing.You will kindly notice,  every other table in the joint  has the poultry piled high.
Its perfectly cooked, not at all greasy or salty comes with a great side sauce to boot.
OK,So first you get the six Korean appetizer offerings to help chill your Chi  and kool your karma.The obligatory kimchi- the vinegar noodles, somthin sweet, somthin sour,
some white cubed veggie, small anchovies ...I'd suggest composing an art piece,
but you can eat some of it too.
right then-We ordered the Seafood pancake, tofu soup, fried chicken, and got comped a side of mackerel. 
Once again Fried Chicken is the shit,super crispy and moist inside, dry outside. good hot, and salty side sauce. You need to know  that.
Tofu Soup- rich and red spicy broth with  velvety  and generous pcs of  tofu. We slurped that down in an instant. Perfect  on a cool foggy SF  night. 5 of 5
Seafood pancake- pretty good but the bottom was bit soggy , the top side was perfect, should have asked them to return to grill  for a few. I've had it before and it is another must.
The comped  mackerel was real average, would not recommend.
Would have like to get a few other items but ended up taking home half the pancake and 3  pcs of chicken.
Weeknight it was just busy enough to stay full with 2-5 people waiting at any given time. We had one server for the whole room ( approx  40 people at 12- 14 tables) , she was adequate but not really "serving" or doing much clearing. Very much a neighborhood place. Parking sucks as per usual on the Main Aves.The decor is basic, a notch or 2 above hole in the wall. Allow  $ 15 or so PPerson and you'll be stuffed.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Toyose was packed so I trusted Yelp and came to Shin Toe Bul Yi with a couple of hungry friends. The restaruant was also pretty packed at ~9PM, and given there's virtually no 'waiting area' inside the restaruant, we shivered in the rolling Sunset 'strict fog for over 15 minutes while we waited for a table.

After finally being seated, we quickly ordered the Fried Chicken (supposedly a 'must'), Kimchi Fried Rice, and a soup. The banchan dishes were all yummy and of high quality. We were also given complimentary grilled mackerel (and they were pretty large) ...Big plus! 

Now, the Fried Chicken IS all it's cracked to be. It's like a huge plate of crack-laiden crispy crunchy spiced deliciousness that's chicken, smothered in lard! I'm a-okay with that! Everything else was very good. This place definitely offers a more traditional Korean fare. No fusion, just good Korean food!! 

Love the name too. But, what does it mean?
author: Jing D.

description:
wouldve gotten 5 star cept of the low ceilings and the amount of smoke that lingers
kind of overrate because there's alot of hype for this place
not that many tables so at times, you will have to wait
overall good food
plenty of side dishes
fair price for korean bbq
the meats were tasty
great friendly service
had the spicy octopus, was kind of chewy
parking was a hassle because it's in residential area


willing to come back if i am ever in the area
author: Andi I.

description:
Really good Korean food.  We usually order the seabass dish--lots of seabass and so delicious!

Fried chicken and chop chae are good, too.
author: C L.

description:
As I walked past all the other tables, I kept thinking "man, everyone really over-ordered."  Thick kimchi pancakes, huge bowls of dubokki with squid, and bubbling bubbling cauldrons of broth.  But then, man, oh, man, we managed to leap right in.  Before I knew it, banchan plates were precariously balanced on the edge of jigae bowls, hite being poured as fast as it could to make more room.

The dubokki is incredible.  But I think it's always incredible, so I'm a lousy judge.  We ordered plain, sans squid, and it came mixed in with rice vermicelli.  Loved it!

Banchan was impressive in scale/scope, but nothing grabbed me.  I didn't like the kimchi.  The kimchi-spiced daikon was pretty great.  The thin sliced tofu squares were just nothingness. 

The fish jigae (sole? cod?  I really don't remember) was pretty good.  The broth a little watery, lots of huge bone pieces, but it was tasty.  From the other reviews, it sounds like tofu jigae could be the right way to go.

And the chicken!  "Chicken - small pieces (little spicy)" on the menu.  Should be called "huge plate of super-tender big-ass double-deep-fried chicken pieces (not at all spicy) (and somewhat falling off the bone)"  Oh, man.  It was great.

Freebie mackerel plate was brought out also -- so-so.  But I never did like mackerel.  Wharf fish, as Trey once said.
author: Andy D.

description:
Honestly, I don't understand what's the hype with the fried chicken. After reading Yelp reviews, I had to go try it for myself. Fooled. And so was every other table in the restaurant. 

I came here on a Saturday night right when they opened and the place quickly filled up. It looked like every table had a plate of the "famous" fried chicken. I was pretty surprised that they give you so much food for the price. However, the chicken was dry and tasteless. Yes, it wasn't oily like most fried chicken, but that's about it and that's where they failed. As my friend would say, you can get better fried chicken in Chinatown.      

The only good thing about this place is that they give you complimentary soft tofu soup with your meal, when most places charge you like crazy for a small bowl. It too lacked flavor, or maybe just some spice.
author: Adrianna C.

description:
Just checked out this place earlier this week with my boyfriend. We didn't know during lunch time they only have to-go boxes, so we were a little disappointed we couldn't order from the whole menu. We ordered the kalbi  and the daeji bulgogi (spicy pork). They were good, but not great. However I compare korean restaurants to my mom's cooking, which almost never wins. 

I was expecting a little more seasoning on the kalbi. But they did give you a great amount! And they gave you the bone also which I LOVE. The daeji bulgogi was pretty good too. It wasn't greasy or too spicy. It was just right. The banchan the mains came with were also great. Their kim-chee is great and I loved the bean sprouts.

I've already made plans to go back this week for dinner 'cause I need to try that fried chicken I see everyone raving about! Oh. And to order those LITER beers :D
author: Nicole D.

description:
Excellent. I brought my mother there for lunch. Technically, it is take out only at lunch but the owner was very accommodating. Friendly. A little translation problem but the experience was wonderful. 

The food was fantastic. We had the special Korean Fried Chicken-KFC from the main menu. Great. I just wish they cut up the chicken like Julia does. Can't always determine dark versus white meat. It was moist and tender. We also ordered the beef and chicken noodle dish off the lunch menu. It was also great. The meals also come withe rice and 4 other sides. A lot of food and take home too. The owner served us there with tea. Must go back for dinner. 

Note: the front of the restaurant is not much to look at but the interior was clean and quite comfortable. Highly recommend experiencing a meal there.
author: Lorna R.

description:
This is my Go To Korean. Here's a rundown of the place:

Small, the interior is clean but not that charming. Go for the food, not for the ambience. Smells like charcoal, which I happen to like.

Waitstaff consists of two overworked ladies--know what you want to order 'cause they are in a hurry.

Bi Bim Bap: Delicious and fresh. I order it every time. Get the one in the sizzling clay pot, with egg, not the one in the regular bowl. Price range from $9-13 or so.

Green onion pancake: house special, one order will do for a family of 4-5 if you share.

Fish: Broiled Mackerel is good. Skate is not to my taste (but I generally find skate has rubbery/flat taste, not just in this restaurant) It's more expensive, I think about $17-18 per order.

Jap Chae: Greasy, with too many noodles and too little yummy stuff and veg. Skip it.

Bul Go Gi: Sizzling platter, good taste.

Many people order the salted fried chicken, I usually steer away from fried foods but visually it looks pretty good.

If you order a couple of dishes they usually throw in a spicy tofy soup thing and sometimes--if you order alot-- a scallion pancake. Yummy.
author: John S.

description:
The meat was bland, the soup was bland, and the experience was bland. Ordered a wide range of dishes and was rather disappointed in most of them. Bulgolgi was overcooked and a bit watery. The seafood pancake was passable and the chicken(non fried) was okay. 

Next time i'll just skip this place and walk a few blocks to the spot.
author: Colin H.

description:
Best traditional Korean food in sf. 

One of the few places in the bay that have legitimate gamjatang.  I lived in Korea for a year and pretty much ate gamjatang at least 3 times a week. When I came back to the states I wanted to find a spot that makes it remotely as good as the motherland, and the only place in the sf area that comes close is shintoebulyi. This place is loved by many, so expect a wait for dinner time. Some things I always get and always enjoy in addition to the gamjatang are: hemul Pajeon, fried chicken, and nakji Bokkum.  I still havent tried everything on their menu, but there hasnt been a dissappointment yet, last but not least, the Service is always good, the family that owns the place is really friendly and polite.
author: Lee B.

description:
This place is near my office so I can pick things up for lunch sometimes. It is out of the way and small and unimpressive looking but the food is great!

The decor/ambiance are utilitarian - not a great place for a first date unless you are both big time foodies. It often gets smokey from the grill and they try to keep the door open to vent the smoke, so it can be cold and smokey.

My favorite is the Kal Bi; for the lunch special it is a pretty good deal. They serve nice Kim Chee too (actually, all the little side dishes [ban chan?] are pretty darn good)

For dinner it can get a little bit spendy, but the portions are good sized and the food really is excellent.  It is usually crowded at dinner time. They seem to get a lot of families. 

About the Fried Chicken - honestly, I tried it a while back and didn't see what was so special. Maybe I went on an off night ; while it wasn't bad, it just was not special. No special flavoring or anything. However,it was cooked well.

Kal Bi, Jap Chae, Kim Chee Bowl are all excellent. My family goes crazy for the sea bass.
author: Audrey H.

description:
I had a satisfying meal here, but it wasn't superb.  I didn't think the Korean style fried chicken was anything wonderful.  I mean, if you're going to market the fried chicken as the dish you're known for, it better be mindblowing.  Too bad it wasn't. 

The tofu soup I had was decent, but nothing memorable compared to the tofu soup at SGD in Santa Clara. The jap chae was good, but I have to say that my boyfriend makes it better :)

Overall, it was a filling meal, but I'm not sure if it was worth the 1 hour wait for my very hungry stomach.
author: Kristine B.

description:
Love their lunch specials!  I always order the kal-bi rice bowl (comes with kim chee, rice, and a mix of beef, egg and veggies on top).  Delicious & fast for under $10!

That's what I call an affordable Korean lunch.

*Lunch is carry out only.  If you eat in, you'll be eating with take-out boxes instead of dining ware (per their sign on the door..)
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
One lesson I learned here - NEVER judge a book by its cover. 

Found this spot on Yelp and decided to give it a go. We drive up and see a sign "Korean Restaurant" and ask ourselves "Is this it?" It was raggedy, rundown looking from the outside, but we said... screw it, it has to be good.

And good it was. We got there at 6 and were seated right away before the bum rushing of people came. There were 5 of us total and we ordered Bulkogi, their chicken fried pieces, Kim Chee Tofu and Jap Chae. Our waitress brought some tofu soup and we thought it was a mistake, but she kindly told us it was on the house. Sweet! 

Anyway, all the dishes came out and we were pretty overwhelmed and had way too much food than we bargained for. The meat was good - standard but not the best in the world.. it was also pretty oily. Same with the Jap Chae. The Kim Chee Tofu - my BF enjoyed a lot and the Fried Chicken Pieces was pretty damn good too. It's a lot of batter and be careful when you eat it because there is a lot of tendon and hard bone you need to teeth around.

Overall - Decent experience with a really good price. For the 5 of us and our 4 dishes and on the house soup - the bill came to $60 w/ tip. We had a bit of to-go also so we were all pleased.
author: Alyson C.

description:
I don't know if it's Korean style or not, but get the FRIED CHICKEN.

I ain't even playin'.
author: Isaac L.

description: Hubby loves the fried chicken but not so much for me. I always order the same thing, Beef bulgogi, Silver noodle, and I tried the pancake once, it was pretty good. Overall, it was okay. We come here coz it's closest to our house.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
This Place has the best tofu soup in my opinion and my husband's too.
The side dishes are great as well.
The place is small so the wait might be a while but I think it's worth the wait.
author: zoey x.

description:
Good. Jolly good.

Food: Everything we got was good, well except the jap-chae - I wasn't all too thrilled about it. The bulgogi, calamari, fried chicken (good mother of god), seafood pancake were all really enjoyable. Their complimentary dishes were really good as well.

Service: This is probably what I noticed most of the night. It's one single lady taking orders, cleaning, bringing out the dishes, refilling your water, etc etc...She does it all on her own without showing any frustration, +1 for her. 

Price: A bit on the expensive side, but quality of food is exceptional. 

Been here for years now and will be back.
author: Kenneth L.

description:
All their sides are pretty delicious and fresh-- especially the pickled daikon radish and fish cake. I love the fried mackerel as well. The spicy tofu soup was yummy, but not reasonably priced for the portions. That goes for majority of the menu items. But surprisingly, you do get full from it. The fried chicken is so fresh and yummy (better than KFC ok!) 

Service was a bit hectic today. The tables were all full and the wait was a bit long. There was only one server around 8pm, and she did ALL the work. I mean ALL! Taking orders, cleaning tables, serving, cashiering and take-out orders! So I don't blame her if she came across as a bit rude because I would go crazy if I were her. 

Side note: In the afternoon, it is take out only. You can eat in but don't expect to get any service.
author: Allyson L.

description: Yum yum I'm 1/2 Korean and love this place for comfort food. Seafood pancake, short ribs, spicy rice cake with calamari I love it all. Good to eat here family style so you can have a bit of everything. Good place for families. If you want more of an adult atmosphere go to spot lounge down the street for flavored Soju, good music, karaoke, and flat screens showing sports.
author: Roxanne W.

description:
5 stars for the chicken only - my friends thought it was okay, but I loved it!  The skin was light and super crispy.  I think they fry it in super hot oil, so hot it practically disintegrates the bones.  The result is fried chicken that tastes almost like gourmet pork rinds.  if you like pork rinds, this is the place to go.

Service was okay.  I didn't care for the bbq - kalbi, bulgogi, and chicken were either too tough or too salty.  Actually, alot of items were too salty, now that I think about it!

Will be back for the chicken!
author: Josie M.

description:
Come early (like right when they open) to avoid waiting in the inevitable long line!

I came here b/c I saw spicy dukk bokki on the yelp pictures and I was craving it really  bad.. but when we sat down we saw that everyone had ordered fried chicken.  So, we ordered that too -- SO good!  Perfectly crisp and salted, and served Korean style w/the daikon (If you've tried Kyochon in LA - this is the same deal).  Also, they give free spicy soon doobu, which was really really good!
author: s m.

description:
I pass this place on the L everyday..and it's always intrigued me...but I knew it was pretty popular on yelp.

The bf and I couldn't decide what to eat for dinner last night so I suggested shin toe bul yi to him last night.

It looks pretty shabby from the outside, but inside it's nicer..there were alot of families in here last night.

We ordered the pan fried potstickers, and I got the sizzling kim chee bowl w/ pork and an egg on top, the bf got the the grilled octopus w/ noodles.

Assorted banchan was placed on our table - yum! My favorite was the teeny tiny little fish ..it was chewy and kind of reminded me of dried squid..their kimchee was really delicious too, but I would hope so-this being a korean restaurant!

My sizzling kim chee bowl came out and it was a bowl of steaming goodness! I broke up the egg and mixed everything up..it was filled w/ veggies, crab & pork..my food was steaming hot until the very end I tell ya!

My bf raved about his octopus and noodles...it looked pretty good in that spicy red sauce..the noodles were nice and chewy.

We also got a steaming hot pot of spicy tofu soup - on the house! It was nicely spicy and just perfect and FREE! heck yeah!

Next time I gotta try their famous fried chicken!
author: Jade B.

description:
2.5 
I got the lunch special here (i think it was about 8 after tax and tip). They had average side dishes, some what dry beef bulgogi, and tea. We also had to wait about 15 minutes since they dont have that much seating. The portions were not that big as I was still hungry after. There are better korean places out there but this is one of the few in outer sunset that I know of. I would come here if I was craving korean and didnt want to drive that far to get it. Parking as always is a hassle in san francisco.
author: Robert Y.

description: This is a pretty small hole in the wall. I ordered the seafood pan cake, Bibimbap and a bulgogi lunch special. When I ordered the seafood pan cake it thought it was expensive but boyyyyyy was the portion huge. Its good, pretty averageoo, i wouldnt come here just for it. The bulgogi lunch special was just a small lunch special. It wasn't worth it at all. I rather make it myself. The Bibimbap is good and i think this is the reason I come here. I am going to try out the fry chicken next time.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
This place was legit good. I don't know what it is about Korean food, but I love their side dishes and this place gives you tons of them. Their dishes were also very good. The food was juicy, tasty, and just plain good to eat after a long day of work. 

As for the place... it oddly reminds me of a restaurant in Japan mix with an antique shop. The Japanese part because of the muni rail next to the place. It always shakes/makes noise in the place. As for the antique... it is because it has a lot of random items inside it.

Overall the place was good. I recommend to go to this place with about 2-4 people.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
Bulgogi taste original but not worth it. 

Shredded beef, eggs, and veggies soup taste like water.

Fried Chicken was good

If it wasn't for the chicken and the free fish on the house this place would've got 1 star.
author: Joshua M.

description: Love the place live arcoss of it, love their soup the most....if your around the area a try...bbq is also good too.price is not bad, there alway lot of ppl in line or outside waiting, so get there early.
author: Calvin T.

description: decent, but i do not know what all the rave is about w/ the fried chicken. it's way too breaded. the tofu soup doesn't really have any flavor. the best things were probably the banchans (comes w/ a fried fish!) and the dok bok ki. will get the seafood pancake next time.
author: Tammy T.

description:
Great residential neighborhood resturant.  This is a tight-spaced restaurant with decent number of small tables and just a few large tables.  If you plan on coming on weekends, plan on arriving at or before 6pm, or expect to get waitlisted.

This is a typical family business, the staff is friendly and prompt.  On occasions when it gets super busy, you might need to wait a bit for service; however, you do feel they try their best and is very courteous with their service.

I love the bibimbop, spicy squid, and a type of black-bean sauced noodle.  They also give you spicy soup and kimchi plates on the house; and depending on how much you order, you may get the free pancake!

The pricing is decent and dish serving is good.  So I'm a fan of this restaurant.
author: Ju D.

description:
A lot of people probably think it is weird that for lunch, it is only to go only. Or you can eat in the restaurant with a to go box, which i like so much better! I can never finish my meal, so now I can already have the food boxed up. 

The tea here is really good. I usually get the spicy pork, but do wish it is a lot spicier. I miss their complimentary soup =( On the plus side, there is still kim chee with your meal!
author: Willa L.

description:
My initial reaction went something like:

Wait, the tofu soup is fucking free?! I knew places were over charging me for that shit. FINALLY, a place that makes sense.

Then my next discover went something like:

Korean fried chicken? Well, I have a passion for fried chicken and I do love Koreans. That's like a celebrity baby; how can you not like it?!
