Slap on some Korean hot sauce (the sweet spicy one that always comes in a nondescript bottle but any real foodie knows the goodness that squirts out) and mix it with rice and you got a wholesome meal.

This joint is not exactly cheap, at about 10-12 bucks a dish... but the quantity is solid and the food is tasty.  and the freebies make me cackle in glee.
author: Joe Z.

description:
It's ok, it's not bad Korean food like most Korean in SF is, so it's better than par for the course for SF Korean food (which is baaaaaaad, eww.  I can't believe even Oakland, or even way out in Concord, has WAY better Korean).  Anyway, this is not bad, not Seoul food, but not bad.

They are not open until 2:30 for lunch.  They close by 2PM, even as early as 10 til 2 you could get denied and be told to come back for dinner.  I know this because I usually eat lunch around 1:30 - 2.

PS, you can also only get the basics for lunch, and it is to go only.
author: Greg J.

description:
This is one of those places people love because of the friendly Korean ladies and good 'signature' items but overall its not that great and the majority of dishes aren't anywhere near as tasty as moms (Hi Omma!  Youre Korean food is still the best!  Iron Chef Korea!!!!) 

The 'KFC' everyone raves about tastes like Japanese chicken karaage not Korean fried chicken but still its deep fried and that automatically means its gonna be delicious.  Also they usually give everyone a complimentary big side dish so if you dont get one it means they hate you.  

Davids Bottom Line-  Im kidding they dont hate you.  It probably means you didnt order enough stuff to warrant getting a free dish so order some soju and beer!  Ill definitely be back but probably only for the fried chicken and beer.
author: David L.

description:
Everytime I go up north, from So Cal yo, I visit Shin Toe Bul Yi the day before I fly. 

We always order the sweet/spicy squid; I think it's by far our favorite dish. The panchan are always delish, I wonder why didn't give us mackerel like the last time we visited. We also ordered kalbi and the seafood pancake. The pancake tasted really good but eating rice and seafood pancake in one sitting was too much for 3 girls. 

Only thing I dislike about the place is the long wait. We waited for more than half an hour last time we were there... And it's usually the case.
author: Anette N.

description:
BBQ beef?  Good.  Jap chae noodles?  Good.  Fried chicken?  Good.  Getting a table at peak hours?  Bad.  Some of the best Korean dishes for the Sunset District.  Personally, I think Brother's on Geary is the best in SF.  Just too far away for me.  But you can BBQ at your table at Brother's, which is part of the fun.  

The place is small, hence the long wait.  Go in, find the self service wait list and sign up as soon as you get there.  The staff may or may not tell you to.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Ate the Bulgogi lunch for to go.

Very cheap, huge portion. For the price that I paid, I cannot complain much about the taste. Read: cheap taste food
author: Cliff T.

description:
Cheap food that tastes homemade.  

The fried chicken was not remarkable.  My last try in the search for good Korean fried chicken.  I mean it's chicken, how good can it get?

Kimchi chigae was a homely soup, comforting but also lacking.

Since the bill for two people was in the 20 dollar range and they gave us free mackerel, I can't be too unhappy with this place.
author: jane d.

description:
I knew that I should have worn clothes I could get stinky in. Luckily for me, I also spilled juice all over my lap during lunch, so at least my pants were ready to be cleaned anyways.

We had the Gal Bi, Chap Che, and the Seafood Bok-Um. They also threw in a tofu soup and other minor dishes.  

I'm used to a lot more side dishes, but by the end of the meal, I was totally ready to unload what I had eaten. Although it wasn't nearly as spicy and tasty, the seafood Bok-Um brought back memories of the old Ko-ko's in Berkeley where I would literally cry due to the spice they added. The Gal-Bi was pretty much run-of-the-mill, but it did fair better in tenderness compared to other restaurants.The chap-che was the most lacking of all dishes, needing a little more soy sauce.

I would stick a nice 3.5 stars for this place, but I alas , I am forced to round up in this case.
author: Alfred Y.

description:
this is a place where everyone seems to know the location, but can't remember the name.  

decor-big hole in the wall, but fairly clean.  table for two are small.

service-under staffed, but friendly when available.

food:

Tofu stew (on the house)-it lacked flavor.

short ribs were tender perfection.  it was not over seasoned so you can taste the quality of the meat.

Spicy pork-not spicy at all.  I had to request hot sauce.

side dishes were ok.

soju-good for the soul, especially on a cold day :)

I keep coming back when I'm in the area because the food is consistent.
author: Michelle S.

description:
My boyfriend and I met his mom here for dinner recently and before the day arrived, all my boyfriend could talk about was their fried chicken.  I thought  this must be some good chicken and expected it to be spectacular.

We ordered the chicken, jap chae, bulgogi and calamari bukum.  The chicken was pieces of chicken cut up, battered, and deep fried.  the menu mentioned it was a little spicy and i tasted nothing.  the chicken was pretty bland all together.  the bulgogi and calamari bokum was alright.  the calamari tasted a little fishy for me (one of my favoritest dishes in the world is ojineh bokum and it's never been fishy anywhere else!).  also, it wasn't as spicy as how I've had it at other places such as To Hyang on 2nd and Geary.  I didn't try to jap chae but it seem a bit dry.  The rice itself was mushy too. :/  The highlight was, they did give us a free bowl of tofu soup.  Nothing to write home to mom about.  it was pretty much broth with chilli peppers and a block of tofu in it.

Would I ever go back?  Maybe if i was in the area.  I live too close to To Hyang to cheat on it ever again!
author: Sally T.

description:
Okie dokie, so Shin Toe Bul Yi is one of those places that I visited some time ago and was planning on visiting at least once again before writing a review. Looks like my nerdiness and dedication to reliability and validity of findings will have to be sacrificed. 
 
This was a very memorable dinner for me because it is the second time that I broke bread w/ Ms. Poo. Cindy K and Grace's friend joined us and good thing they did because that means we could order MORE FOOD! Grace calls up Euge and says, "Hey, we're at Shin Toe Bul Yi, what should we order?" Here's what we ordered:

- Bul go gi (marinated bbq pork)...average. My memory fails me to remember any more so it must have just been OK.

- Spicy sea bass soup...AWESOME! fish was fresh, and the soup was packed with flavor. 

- Korean fried chicken...okay, so the KFC here has a different texture from some other places (San Tung, Toyose). It's got more of a crunch to it (potato flour?), which I like quite a bit if it is done well. Pretty good with the crunchiness, but I thought that it was overall a bit on the bland side. Whoever made that comment in that STBY vs. San Tung thread to take STBY chicken and pour San Tung sauce on it should get an award for their genius.
 
- Jap chae (thick cellophane noodles w/ pork and veggies)...average. consider it FILLER! 

- Seafood pancake (on the house)....average, I was waiting for everyone to arrive and was starving so of course it tasted good.

- the usual banchan of stuff...not bad of a selection; notable was the little mackerel (was it a mackerel or one of those extinct fishies?). oh man that fish was good!

So overall, it was a 3.5 food experience...I'm really bummed I can't come back in the near future to check out whether it is really a 3.5 place. So why the 4 star rating?  
 
Because they had the BEST DAMN 90's R&B MIXTAPE PLAYING when we came in. That tape was so freakin' good that Grace said, "That MUST have been made by a Filipino," and we seriously considered asking them for a copy. Not to mention that there were TAGALOG songs playing in the bathroom. Nice to know that my people (or at least our music) can hang with the Koreans.
author: Steph P.

description:
mmmmm KFC... Korean Fried Chicken without the Colonel!
The sea bass soup, fish roe soup, bul go gi (marinated bbq pork), short ribs, broiled mackerel, and octopus tentacles in a spicy-sweet sauce are excellent dishes.  Order any or all of those items, with rice, and you're good to go.
author: Grace M.

description:
friedchickenfriedchickenfriedchicken
dolsot bibimbap
soondobu

the best of these within (at least) a 4 mile radius.
author: Ben T.

description:
Are you interested in trying some tasty food that you might not otherwise order?  Kidnap Euge and head on down to Shin Toe Bul Yi.  Korean pancakes, sea bass soup, bacon, calamari (I wouldn't recommend the fish egg soup-yuck) and a dozen or so little bowls of dipping sauces and condiments.
The star of the evening (other than our boy Euge) was the fried chicken.  But if you're watching your sodium intake look out.  I've been called sweet lips before but after my meal tonight I may have to change that nickname to salty lips.
author: phil h.

description:
"Yelp invades Korea restaurant, leaves only bones, empty bottles."

We came, we saw, we ate with extreme prejudice. We killed our food dead. Octopus, mackerel, sea bass, beef, pork, chicken, shrimp -- all good, all dead. Notable favorites include the pork bulgogi and the spicy sea bass soup. We ran about 18 deep. With drinks and bloated bellies, the bill ran just under $30 a head.

As for the restaurant itself, the place is no frills, no atmosphere, all food. We took up half the place, leaving a line of people kind of staring, either in annoyance or in envy. The joint was surprisingly crowded for an early Tuesday night. The waitstaff itself was very attentive and helpful.

As for the KFC... Korean fried chicken = huge chunks of chicken karaage, fried bone-in. Good, but not up to the hype. I must try elsewhere for comparison. Of course, that means another Yelp invasion...
author: Perci N.

description:
I don't think I've heard "on the house" so many times. My sister and I ordered two items and ended up with a full table, dishes piling up on the side. We were stuffed. And most was quite delicious! We ordered the rice cake soup and the bibimbap.

We went for lunch on a Saturday. Parking was not a problem at all. No wait for a line, and it felt like the food just kept coming. I can imagine it being super crowded any other time. Just one of those local joints you've gotta love and catch on a non-busy day.

I think their goal that day was to see how much they could stuff us before we'd give up.  :P

Update: I'm changing this to a 5 because I just love this place! We had the sauteed rice cakes (medium) = YUM!!! Plus, my mom was impressed by the smartness/speedyness of the waitress/owner lady, who could handle ALL the customers and not leave them with their necks stretched out from waiting... I think she has eyes on all sides of her head. She's amazing!

Update: I can't stop coming here. Spending three weeks in Idaho, and I know that there won't be anything like this out there, so I made yet another trip. That's 3 times in 2 months. They'll start to recognize us. Tried more food this time because we had a bigger party. The sea bass soup is delicious too!  

I've never ordered the chicken, and I probably never will. Why ruin something so wonderful?
author: Tinna H.

description:
Yesterday I walked 11 miles across the city and ate tempeh, yellow peppers and brown rice. Today, I shoveled bright red meats and spicy pickles into my mouth and washed them down with soju and beer. 

On the way home I went to unbuckle my belt, only to discover, it already was. 

Shin Toe...unfamiliar territory for me but quite the experience. We started with a tall "Hite" beer. Kind of the miller of Korea, goes well to cool the palate. 

I'm seriously bursting at the seams and I don't even have any seams on. I'm about 12 bites beyond where I should have stopped. This is what a day at Moscone Center will do to an otherwise finicky eater. Yes, I was there at the tradeshow today checking out the exhibits and eating happy hour post seminar dumplings with those Oklahoman business men. I immediately ripped off my tradeshow pants once arriving home, and put on my reserved "fat pants" (girls, you know what I'm talking about) but even they were too tight. 

Here at Shin Toe, where I met my (also-Korean-food-virgin) husband...I devoured miniature dried fish - faces and all.  Pickled pink Daikon was plentiful and fun to crunch. The pork tasted much better than it looked. The flavor was spicy, savory and a bit sweet. We ate it over little bowls of warm rice. 

Not used to this kimchee fashion  of small picked spicy things scattered in tiny bowls on the table and bbq'd bright red meats and stews of calamari and green onion cakes.
author: Amy E.

description:
I am clueless when it comes to Korean food.  I don't even know the name of the dish I ordered.  And even if I did, I probably wouldn't be able to pronounce it.  But I do know what tastes good to me and what doesn't.  My noodle veggie dish, pancake appetizer, and soup were all very tasty, only for $7.  The lunch portions were more than adquate.  

There aren't a huge variety of restaurants in this area, let alone good ones, but Shin Toe Bul Yi looks to be a good standby--a place you can count on for a good meal (as well as a place to practice your chopstick skills!).  The restaurant is frequented mostly by neighborhood folk.  I'm sure I never would've happened upon this place if I weren't working nearby.  I found the staff to be cordial, with quick and quality service.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
My ex-boyfriend is half Korean.   I spent two years of my life feasting on his mom's authentic barbecue and the kimchee she assembled herself and buried in the backyard to ferment. I've also spent a fair amount of time traveling in Korea.
hence: I loooove Korean food. Love IT! 

My Korean friend, Bobby, first introduced me to Shin Toe Bul Yi in 2003 and I've been back several times since.

It's way out in the sunset, but totally worth the drive and I've never had to wait. The food is awesome and, unlike most Korean places, Cheap!  The give you all the little standard, starter side plates and often times additional soup and pancakes.  You don't have the option to cook at the table like at Brother's, but the barbecue is still fantastic.  

I usually always get the Pi Bim Bap (sp?!) in the stone bowl. It's more than enough food and delicious!

--- "bibimbap" -- Vegetables and beef on rice is made from cooked rice mixed with bits of meat, seasoned vegetables, and egg. If desired, it can be eaten with "kochujang" ( a red hot pepper paste ).
author: Shayna N.

description:
I'm giving this place 3 stars ONLY because they are closed on Sundays (WTF) and it's no longer a sit down restaurant, it's a take out spot.  How am I supposed to enjoy my food if it's take out?!

The decor is...OK, it looks like someone's garage turned restaurant.  Janky? Yes.  Delicious? HELLS YES.

The fried chicken is literally the best I have ever had at a Korean restaurant.  There's nothing super special about it except the batter is done exceptionally well, not too doughy and fried to perfection.  You eat it with this crispy pickled radish and the combo is to die for.  Oh yeah, they do NOT serve it for lunch so dinner only.

Their tofu soup is just the right amount of spicy and not too watery.  

The little dishes (I don't know if they still offer it, seeing as though it's TAKE OUT now!) are tasty too, especially the little anchovies (my fave).

I've also tried a bunch of other items but these are the only ones I care to write about.  The end.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Unfortunately when all my friends talk a place up, I am super excited to go and then let down. Maybe from now on I am better off just ignoring what everyone else says, then going in on my own so I don't get down. I have a feeling if my fiance and I had not been so hyped up about the place we would have liked it more. Isn't that always the case though? I still liked my experience here though and enjoyed everything, it just wasn't as amazing as I had hoped! 

It took me awhile to make coming here a priority, even though I literally live across the street on 30th. The reason was because it looked so icky, dirty and run down on the outside, and I never peeked in. But once inside, it's warm and inviting all dark wood and cozy and super clean. Every table is always filled and I have never walked by or driven by where there were not people waiting for a table, even when it's raining. 

Put your name on the sign in sheet along with how many are in your party and wait. 

You're seated, get your menu and order. 

Some of the dishes can be opted to order as you cook yourself at the table, or they can be cooked and brought out to you. The waitress told us though that since it was only two of us if one of us wanted the cook it yourself option the other had to go with that also. 

So we opted for the prepared and brought out to you option for the short ribs, and the onion pancakes, and some other items. The onion pancakes are something I love at Chinese restaurants, and the difference here was that these are made also with egg batter on the outside! YUMMY. It is a large order so of course I had plenty to bring home since my fiance is not a fan of that dish. In terms of the ribs, it was good, but a little plain. I guess the magic is in the 6 little accompanying dishes that come out for you to enjoy your meat with. Sprouts, flavored cucumbers, kimchee, little dried fish in a spicy sauce, and some other stuff. Pair that with your meat and there you go! Flavor! 

Next time want to try the fried chicken, when I saw the platters of it walking past me, I kept on wanting to change my order, it looked really good! 

Anyway regarding service, it was quick and fast, in terms of bringing us what we asked for, but there was about a 20 minute wait for the food (maybe dinner rush?) and when the food did come out it was almost tossed at us (again, maybe rush). Everyone was really nice though so I don't feel like any of it was intentional. 

Now I have another dining option in the area, that I can literally just cross the street for. 

Yipee.
author: Denise B.

description:
Alrighty, any place where you can eat beef, pork, chicken, fish, fish roe, and octopus in one meal is worth eating at.  Particularly if Euge L. is doing the ordering. 

Go with a bunch of people, order all your major food groups, leave happy. As several people were noting, skip out on the carbs, and load up on the stuff that will clog your arteries. 

The banchan could be fresher, but you won't need too much of that if you are eating their fried chicken.
author: Sooj O.

description:
Complete with a crappy looking exterior and interior, this hole in the wall seems to always have a line out the door, particularly on weekends. You may have to wait 15-30 minutes, but it is well worth it. Shin Toe Bul Yi serves some of the best Korean food I've ever had. Unlike a lot of Korean eateries, this one varies its spicing significantly per dish; with enough variety in your order, you'll be taken on a palate-tickling voyage of Korean spicing.

The fried chicken seems to be quite a hit here, as nearly everyone was eating it when I was there, but personally, I recommend the seabass. It is amazing. It's not so soft it disintegrates in your hand, nor is it overcooked, and the sauce steals the show for the evening. 5 stars: a must-go in SF.
author: Frank B.

description: Yummy fried chicken and free tofu soup along with all the sides.  What more can you ask for....The only downside is that it is usually packed so be ready to wait.
author: Cin T.

description:
My new fave korean place since my fave korean bff has left me for the other side of the country. 

Pros: 
-(Free) ban chan, spicy tofu soup, rice
-delicious spicy calamari, spicy cold noodles, jap che, and fried chicken.

I ordered to go and they gave me ban chan & rice in addition to whatever else I ordered. I was pleasantly surprised. Another surprise is that the prices are extremely decent for Korean food...
author: Jocelyn W.

description:
I love this place. I've only been once, but I'll be back. Shin Toe Bul Yi offers delicious Korean food at excellent prices with no frills. You'd never notice this restaurant if you were driving by on Taraval, seeking a promising-looking place to eat. And the decor inside is equally basic. Hip it ain't.

We enjoyed the green onion pancake to start, which was accompanied by a less-spicy-than-you'd-think red dipping sauce. Next up were the small dishes of banchan. The fried chicken was great -- fresh out of the fryer, moist, full of flavor. We also enjoyed the soft tofu stew, which was spicy but more mild than its bright red color promised. Finally, we had a plate of the bulgogi, along with servings of rice. We waaay over-ordered and had plenty of food to take home. Excellent!
author: Tara M.

description:
My friend recommended that I check out this "really good hole in the wall Korean place" on Taraval. Glad I finally did and so were the other two who came with me.

Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING that was served to us was good. The food was distinctly flavored but not overdone.  We ordered Sea Bass, Seafood Soup and fried chicken, which are good pics. Even the complimentary broiled fish dish given to us was d-lish!

The restaurant is set up home-style. My friend said it right when she described it as 'sitting in someone's living room.' The waitstaff was friendly and the prices were decent for Korean food.

So you don't have to go downtown or to Geary to get good Korean. Yet another place that speaks volumes for the great mom and pop restaurants in SF.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
OK, yours truly should do a proper restaurant critic thing, i.e. visit at least three times - but after my first visit, I am thrilled!
Since I ate lunch right after a flight from Europe (and no sleep for 3 days), I really don't remember what we ordered, but it was all so excellent that I am presently drooling just thinking about it. 
So I thought I'd give it 5 while I remember...and because the other Ivana I. wanted another review.
author: Ivana I.

description:
MmMMmm........this is the spot to go when you're craving for some good korean food! 

i 've been here two or three times and altho it looks like a hole in the wall i can assure you that its more like a converted garage =).  hahaha...that doesen't stop me tho, it would be so much fun if they had the fruit flavored sojus....yummmys! 

the tofu  soup is ok here.....i think they specialize more with the meats and chap jae and chicken wings.....and as usual the bulgolgi is yums! 

Parking may be hard...the line may be long but it is well worth it.
author: Shirley H.

description:
Han Bat, for me is love and hate.

Love, because it's food is in general very tasty, and it offers lots of free Korean small dishes on top of the appetizer pancake and a complimentary fried fish or tofu soup.  You can still be STUFFED with 4 people ordering two main dishes.  

Food in general is as oily as typical Korean food.  The tofu soups are great taste and texture.  My favorite dish is its steamed sea bass in spicy stew.  Must order.  I have seen almost every table ordering Fried Chicken - but personally I think it is similar to KFC, which is a few streets down.  

Servers are hardworking and friendly.  Most of the time though, they are short-handed.

DO NOT TRY the seafood pancake on the menu -- we barely found any seafood in the huge pancake.

HATE:  Like typical Korean restaurants, the place is packed and full of oily smell in the air.  The poor ventilation makes the experience there worse.  One reminder, don't wear any jacket that you love when you are eating there.  For sure it will absorb your Kal Bee or fried chicken smell.  

Bottom line:  Try Han Bat on a winter night, when you are prepared for good authentic Korean food and a nice shower after dinner.
author: Alex T.

description:
Not a Korean BBQ, this is an authentic homestyle restaurant with a waiting list as long as Taraval St. It's called Shin Toe Bul Yi and you should get to know it.

I especially love their soft tofu soup and all of the fish dishes, but I've never had anything there I didn't say "Yum" out loud to. 

If you plan to go there for dinner, no matter which day of the week, get there early and write your name on the clipboard. If you don't do this, you will literally wait a couple of hours. 

p.s. staring at guests who are finished eating doesn't make them leave faster, trust me =)
author: Antonia W.

description:
Came here for dinner last night at 8:30pm. The wait was only about 5 mins. For two of us, we have three dishes. The bul-go-gi was pretty good, but not spectacular. The tofu stew as super soft, but kinda "thin" (not what I was expecting). The imitation crab meat they put in does not make the dish very "authenthic". The Jap Chae was the best dish of the night. 

Will probably try other Korean restaurants before coming back.
author: Fanny L.

description: Always see a crowd here when I pass by so decided to come here for dinner one day. I ordered some noodles and then some soup to go with it. The flavors were pretty nice but was not as spicy as I would think Korean food should be.
author: M C.

description:
This place is so yummy.  A group of us go once a month to fulfill the crave! 

I checked out Brothers on Geary recently, but I like this place much better.  Better tofu soup and you don't come out smelling like Korean BBQ.  Also, they don't serve the fried chicken at Brothers.  

Good stuff man.  Don't forget to order some Korean beer with your meal.
author: Aileen C.

description:
Good Korean. The (complimentary) green onion pancakes are my favorite -- perfectly thin and not too greasy.   I also like the wide variety of banchan.  
 
As for entrees, this place is better for meat-eaters than for vegetarians. The other night we asked the server for a vegetarian version of the be bim bap, but it still came with some sort of fish product (We think. It tasted pretty damn fishy).  
 
The vegetarian rice-cake dish was gooey and dense, with generous globs of spicy red sauce.  It's tasty, but I found it hard to eat more than a couple of these rice-cakes, as they were so chewy they tired out my jaw.
author: angela n.

description:
Fried Chicken - tender, juicy, great texture, but where's the flavor?  I don't understand all the rave about it.  Maybe I was spoiled from San Tung.

Jap chae - definitely full of MSG, but at least it wasn't as salty as the last time I had it there.  We could actually finish the whole dish this time.

Bulgogi - once again, where's the flavor?  The color also looks quite dull, like the meat's been sitting out for hours unattended like a sad little child.

Soft tofu stew - the tofu was great, and definitely soft.  The soup was okay, too.

+ for front door parking.
+ for excellent service.
+ for all the extra side dishes that we asked for.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This Korean restaurant is located on the corner of Taraval and 30th Avenue.  Upon entering the restaurant ,I felt like I was in a spa.  It was rather stuffy since the kitchen is not enclosed. 
I had ordered the fried chicken ( 13 pieces for $10.99 )  it was delicious and piping hot.
I also ordered the Jap-Chae was also very good.  They give you complimentary  onion pancakes and tofu soup in addition to the many other small dishes .  The good thing about this restaurant is that everything came out hot.
Parking can be difficult during dinner time.
author: norine h.

description:
I actually was taken to this place on a group outing several years back, and re-visited it with The Boy last week (now a month, since I've been majorly slacking) on our weekly City Date. He picked Korean, and it was between here at Toyose. I think that Shin Toe Bul Yi has better food than Toyose, but that it's a draw between the two due to the flavored soju (and quirky atmosphere) at Toyose. Shin Toe Bul Yi is not fancy-schmancy on the inside - this is a date place to go to once you have already settled in with the other person, and don't need to impress them anymore. 

Anyways, we get in, and they don't give us that "darn foreigners" look, and happily and quickly seat us. Water and tea is brought to the table, along with the pan chan dishes. I haven't had a lot of experience with pan chan, but the ones here are tasty. 

I believe we ordered the fried chicken, some type of tofu soup, and bulgogi. All tasty, all hot and fresh, and she also brought us rice. The food here tastes authentic (well, as authentic as I know - I don't have any Korean friends that live nearby, so I have not tasted "mom's cooking"), and has just the right amount of flavor. Also, one of the nice things about this place is that they give you a free piece of fish when you come here. 

Korean food always seems to be a bit more expensive than the other genres of asian food, but Shin Toe Bul Yi won't make you wince when you see the bill.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Since we ran out of Korean restaurants choices around SF city, my friend suggested we venture out to the inner Sunset to try our luck on this home style Korean restaurant. 

The restaurant is small, cozy and feels like eating in a Korean family's dining room. The people who own and work there are Koreans, so we were confident that the food would be authentic and delicious. 

I should clarify that the factor that motivated the 3 of us to drive all the way across town to Shin Toe Bul Yi is because of Korean fried chicken. We ordered the fried chicken, a spicy tofu soup with beef, stir fried squids with scallions in spicy sauce, grilled beef short ribs on sizzling pan. Our order also came with rice and small plates of condiments like pickled cucumbers and cabbage, kim chee, bean sprouts, bean curds, and a few more. The small tables soon ran out of space with all the plates. 

When the fried chicken arrived, we were anxious to sink our teeth in the chicken pieces, but it was way too hot to handle needless to say take a bite. From the look of the chicken, it seem well prepared, fried to golden brown with a coding of batter. Once it had cool down enough for our mouth, we tasted. For me, it was nothing to hype about. The batter was too thick and you can still taste the flour. There were very little or no seasoning on the chicken so it was bland. The frying part was also disappointing that they probably put the chicken pieces in when the oil was still lukewarm, hence the chicken was greasy on the inside. Not like southern fried chicken or Japanese chicken karage at all. 

The rest of the dishes like tofu soup was good, the grilled beef was fine, although I found the marinate a bit on the sweeter side. The stir fried squid with scallions and onions was common. After awhile, every item tasted like the typical red Korean spicy sauce, the soup, the stir fried, and the grilled items. Our taste buds were bland and couldn't taste the difference anymore. 

Overall, for a first time visit on a spear of the moment dinner is considered a success given that we got to eat a Korean dinner, laugh, and catch up with friends, which is the most important element of that evening and we did just that. However, when we brought up Shin Toe Bul Yi again, none of us were enthusiastic about going there the next time we get together. At least it won't be my first choice of Korean restaurant in town.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
This is the first time yelp reviewers  have let me down. 
This restaurant is pretty terrible. I will never go back. 

I say you can always judge a Korean restaurant by its kim chee. Good kim chee usually equals overall good food.  As soon as I had a taste of the kim chee here, I knew this meal was going to be a huge disappointment. 
 
We had the pork bulgolgi, the chewy spicy noodles, and the kim chee chigae.

Pork bulgolgi 
Not good. It was the usual thinly sliced pork however the sauce was bright red, only slightly spicy, very sweet, and thick with ketchup - Not what you would expect to find at a Korean restaurant. It reminded me of a bad Americanized Chinese restaurant's version of sweet and sour. 

Chewy Spicy Noodles
This was OK. The texture of the noodles was as advertised. The sauce was average -  Sweet and spicy, but not very refined in flavor. 

Kim Chee Chigae
This was average. It had a nice smoky bacon flavor, and a bit of tang from the kim chee. The broth was watery and not particularly hearty. I prefer "My Tofu House", but even their kim chee chigae isn't  extraordinary.

The only bright spot in the meal was the deep fried mackerel that came "on the house"  - Crispy and full of fish oil goodness. Yum!

Unfortunately, on top of the food being sub par, the cleanliness was exemplified by the food spattered menus, and rice sticking to my shoe (the hair stuck in the pork bulgolgi didn't exactly get my mouth watering).
Hey, I'm all for mom & pop joints, but the comfort (and I don't mean hair) must be found in the food because there certainly is no love in sticky condiment bottles, and greasy tables.
author: Miyas J.

description:
my only sadness about this place is that its not open as often as i like and apparently now it only does dinner service and lunch is to go??

they are super friendly, always gives bunches of yummy sides (as usual per korean restaurants) BUT along with that free green onion pancake and tofu soup (love!!)

the food is plenty (and i mean plenty, the little chicken was not little at all) and while i never really talk to the servers there because they speak more korean then english..they are super sweet and even remembered me months later when i left an umbrella there..which i did not realize i did..but when i went back before i left she gave me a huge smile and gestured me to wait while she went behind the counter to retrieve..my umbrella!

now if only the restaurant where i left my camera would do the same..
author: Whitne Y.

description:
I've got to say, I wasn't too impressed after all the rave reviews. I had the tolsot bi bim bap (which they had some English name for I forgot) - the rice dish in the stoneware dish. The dish was not warm enough, such that the rice did not get all crispy as it should. I don't know what it is in SF - between Brother's and this place, I can't get a decent bi bim bap.

My girlfriend (who grew up Korean) said the kim chi that came with the ban chan was the worst she's had - not salted properly before prep, I think, but the cold noodle dish was excellent. The soon dobu was good, but not as good as Mom's on Grand in South SF.

Maybe we should have stuck with the fried chicken.
author: Chris K.

description: Still my favorite Korean restaurant!  Their fried chicken is amazing (even as leftovers), and the thin onion pancake is the best (they used to give it as a complimentary part of the meal, but now it's just $2.99.  Totally worth it).  Get there early if you don't want to wait, but trust me, it's well worth it!
author: Emma L.

description:
I came here with my sister after she got off school and boy, were we surprised! It's lunch time and every thing is served in take-out boxes! you know, the clear plastic with two small and one big section? Even if you dine in for lunch, you eat out from take-out boxes! Awkward to say the least, but that's an unique way of eating Korean! 

Anyway, we ordered a Bul Go Gi bowl and a Pork Bul Go Gi special and it took about...oh, 10 minutes or so to prepare. While we wait for our food, they were nice to provide some tea. I guess it's a good time to catch up with my sister and talk about random stuff. 

So after getting our food, we decided to rent a movie (two actually: Step Brothers and Wanted). Blah, blah, blah and we're home! I didn't try my sister's Bul Go Gi, but the pork was perfect red with just enough charred spots to avoid getting cancer. Not as spicy as I thought it would be, but the set did come with some sweet and spicy sauce. So I drowned the pork with the sauce and the kick of the spiciness punched right through! I wish I had more rice, but it's good that they gave good side dishes (Fish Cake, Kimichi, Pickled Cucumbers, Beansprouts and Anchovies), all which are my favorites! 

I really feel like eating once in a restaurant can't give you the full experience of everything they have to offer, but my first impression of Shin Toe Bul Yi is well-founded to say the least!
author: Jeremy L.

description: KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) is very tasty!
author: Eric G.

description: Love the fact that they give u free dish whenever u order something. The service can b a hit or miss but will definitely b back for the food!
author: Emily K.

description:
People from Chowhound were right, there was Korean style fried chicken here on the menu. Huge portion but sadly it didn't hit the spot with me like it did for others. San Tung's dried fried chicken wings are better, and the chicken steak (ji pai) at Cupertino Village A&Js Taiwanese style is SUPREME.

Only been here once almost 3 to 4 years ago. The most disturbing sight was the kim chi (the spicy marinated daikon and cabbage dishes) sitting on a counter and roughly a foot or two above were a swarm of flies buzzing in the air. I don't know if any landed (perhaps the local flies didn't like kim chi?), and granted it was a hot day outside, but this place is not terribly well ventilated.

Food was average. Would have just walked away with 3 stars but kim chi sitting out with a swarm of top gun buzzer nuisances was not something I needed to see. -1 star for that. It is tempting to call this place Shin Toe Bul Shizzle

But I had a flashback from my college days as I rewrote this review. One of my close friends from college, who is now married, is Filipina American. She and I were making fun of one of our ex-classmates who was a bit of a slut herself, and it was then I learned that Bul Bul in Tagalog meant pubic hair.

A side lesson in Tagalog bad words, excuse me for my spelling:

"Puta-ina-mang" - your momma's a whore (this is as bad as F*** someone's mom)

bul bul - pubic hair

bahkla - a fabulous happy man (to put it nicely). Also known as Mr Thang, or another word for gay but not in a good sense.

So Shin Toe Bul Bul? Uhhhhhh...don't even go there.
author: Ken K.

description: The place is tiny. A bit pricey. But the food is HELLLLLA goood. You come out smelling like the food which reminds me of how wonderful it was. *sniiiiifffff* yuuuuuum.
author: Marti L.

description:
If you're willing to wait at least 30 minutes for a table, then this a place to check out for Korean food.   One of my favorite restaurants!!!  I love their Kal Bi and their fried chicken is pretty decent.

Defintely will be back when I crave for Korean food.
author: Shana W.

description:
So after reading all these great reviews about "KFC" I decided to try this place out a few nights ago.  The place was packed, and luckily we got the last table available.  Service was reasonably attentive, quick, and friendly.  We ordered the famous chicken and the rib eye (i forget what it's called).  As is typical with korean restaurants, we got a ton of sides including an onion pancake kinda thing (which was decent), a tofu soup (pretty good), and your usual batch of sides.  The chicken was good, with a nice crunch when you bite into it, but I agree with some of the other reviewers in that it's missing a spice punch.  It's a shade on the bland side.  The rib eye was not good at all - didn't seem like they marinated it.  

Overall I would probably go back to try some of their other dishes but in general this was just a typical restaurant to me.  Nothing really special.
author: G-Man ..

description:
What I really, really wanted was San Tung's dry fried chicken! I'm not up on the real KFC apparently but figured I'd try out this place. It's down the street from my son's karate school and being a Wednesday and shit out of luck for going to San Tung, we ventured here.

Located on the south west corner of 30th and Taraval, like the many others have said the decor inside and out is minimal. Driving past the first time, I wasn't sure I wanted to stop, but I made a trip around the block and said to myself that if I found a close parking spot, we were eating there. Sure enough. There was my parking spot.

Got the kids out of the car and smelled the delicious smells of bbq. Okay big seller. Initially we were going to take it to go, but figured the wee one was sleeping and I wanted to see what free goodies we were getting. Heh. I'm frugal like that, didn't you know ;D. And I like FREE.

It wasn't crowded yet at 6:45PM, we got a table no problem. First thing on the table, onion pancake and hot tea. YUM. Next were the 6 banchan. I only really liked the pickled daikon and the kimchee. Those little fishies and the cut up fishcake just too fishy for me. The cucumber too salty. We ordered the teriyaki chicken and, of course, the fried chicken.

EVERY. SINGLE. TABLE. had the chicken... so we had to try it. It was piping hot when it came out. When it was finally cool enough to eat... it was alright. Rather disappointing actually. My mom's fried chicken is tastier. The flavor of the teri chicken was mild, like it needed to be marinated longer. They gave us the free tofu soup and it was too spicy for my liking, and the flavor was just a little funky for me.

I can cross this one off my list. I can now say I've tried it and I won't be wondering anymore. For Korean I'd much rather go to Pine on Noreiga, the flavor of their BBQ is very tasty. And I eat much more of their Banchan. And well, I obviously know nothing about kfc, but if that's what it's all about then I'd rather just eat my mom's chicken or wait for a nonWednesday for San Tung!
author: Dina V.

description:
this is my favorite Korean place to eat...

their fried chicken is gooooooooddd.. a most order!.. the white raddish side dish that they give out when you order them is veryyy goooooodd...

the pancake is alsoo a most order!.. the red sauce looks spicy but dont let it fool youuu, it is not spicy at all and it iss yummmmmmm delicious with the pancakes...

This is a mom and pop restaurant, super tiny, decor is outdated, no reservations, wait can be long but let me tell you that the food is worthhhhhhhhhhh the wait!...

TIPS: if you do not order any soup they will give you complementary tofu soup.. if you do oder soup then they usually give you fried fish.. 

parking sucks... customer service is good but can be slow..
author: Linda N.

description:
I will always refer to this heavenly spot as Chicken Deli because that's the name was always on the side of the restaurant. LOL.

Anyways, I LOVE this restaurant, but it is always packed! My sis and I once waited over an hour for grub - this is how much we love it. We will wait outside in the cold just for one table for two...LOL.

I love the free pancake - it is 100% delicious! I also love ALL the food they serve there because the quality is fabulous and the taste is second to NONE. And yes, it is pricier because Korean food is pricier, but I don't mind paying more at this place because I love it so!

GO TRY IT FOR YOURSELF. YOU WILL LOVE IT!
author: MishEddie G.

description: My wife is a huge Korean food fan. Since she moved here from LA she has always been on the look out for really good Korean food. A salesperson at Cowgirl Creamery in the Ferry Building of all places recommended this place and its been great. The tofu kimchee is really good. The owners are also quite friendly.
author: Will C.

description:
I love Korean food. I like to come out of a night of Korean food with burning lips and tears in my eyes, staggering around from all the Hite or OB I drank to alleviate the pain. 

I don't love waiting 45 minutes for a table because the restaurant is tiny and they don't seat people at the table by the open door because it gets too cold and drafty. Why is the door open? To ventilate the kitchen. Where is the kitchen? Not by the door.

The food is average, in my opinion. It's hard to go wrong with spicy, meaty things. The pork that my friend ordered had definitely been marinated in kiwi a little too long--the words "like grainy pudding" came out of his mouth more than once. The two things that were super good: the Chilean Seabass soup in the hotpot and the little whole fish you get as ban chan if you order soup as an entree. The other ban chan...meh. 

By the way, did you know that Chilean Seabass is just a fancy schmancy name for Patagonian Toothfish?
author: J N.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean restaurant.
When I want to eat, I mean eat, 
especially after you had a bad hangover 
or when it's really cold outside and you need a hot hot soup, 
this is a great place to go.
This place gets packed, so expect that.
I like their homy warm environmnet; however,
I wish they kept inside a little bit cleaner.., 
i would give them a five star.
chicken karaage, spicy chige are great.
author: Chihiro O.

description: A "lighter" tasting Korean restaurant. My friend and I were going to buy fabric for our Halloween costumes, so in order to fuel up for all the thinking and buying, we came here. Immediately, the nice lady brought us some pancakes to munch while we looked through the menu. Korean food is pricey anyway, but we still ordered a bulgogi to share and a soon tofu for each of us. I guess I'm used to them adding hella flavor at other K restaurants, so I deem this one the "natural" tasting one. Soon tofu wasn't too spicy or kimchi tasting. The bulgogi wasnt too sweet or oily. The service was also very friendly compared to other K restaurants I've been to. Only thing is it takes a big bite outta pocket for lunch- we each threw in 22 bucks w/ tip.
author: Thomas L.

description: A friend and I dropped-in here today to have some good ol' bibimbap, and I gotta say.. I was impressed! The woman (I'm guessing she was the owner) was very friendly, and the beef bibimbap was delicious. We asked for seconds of the fish cake and the kimchee that they give you before your meal, and they gave us a complimentary tofu soup to share. I wish I coulda tried their green onion pancake, though! My girl was raving about it, but we were guessing that nobody else got it along with their kimchee and fish cake, either. When I come back, I wanna try their fried chicken. Every single freakin table had it! lol
author: Monica M.

description:
I've passed by this place dozens of times but never thought to try it until my friend had a belated b-day dinner here. 

YUM. Everything was pretty good. I love their chicken wings. Best part of the whole experience was the free soup and assortment of apps.
author: Sue L.

description:
Friend and I tried their Korean style pancakes and their "sizzling" stoneware pot of rice with vegetables/meat/egg (I think it's called Bi Bim Bap?  though on their menu, it wasn't referred to as such).  Friend raved about the tea they served - it was some Barley tea (?), and I agree it definitely hit the spot after riding through the cold/foggy SF weather (yes, in July!) to get to this place.

They brought us over this mildly spicy tofu soup during our meal (pretty tasty - though as mentioned in other reviews, it ain't them super hot/spicy/red ones that clear up your nasal passages) and told us it was on the house, which was nice!!!

It was a lot of food, but a lot of good food so we were content:)  I took off one star because afterwards my clothes smelled from the smoke!  Nonetheless, a big thanks to my friend who took me here and would eat at this place again if I have the chance.
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
Excellent food! One of my favorite Korean places in the city. Service is great and the staff here are super friendly. Can't complain about all the freebies either.

The decor could use some help, but the great food and service more than make up for it.

Fried chicken - delish! Korean pancake - yum!
author: Tony L.

description:
first time in here, this place felt very home-made, and of course it actually is home-made. the kitchen is NOT very far from the dining area which is small too. 

on a Friday night, the wait was at least 30 mins for a table for two, considering how small their restaurant is and how bad parking is, thats not TOO bad. The garage was an hour wait so we came here. 

It took a little longer, so i opted for to go. 

Ordered:

----bulgogi, squid and rice noodles, and the fried chicken.
 the bulgogi - seasoned decently. seem soggy and i've had better. no onions tho? 

----the squid and rice noodles was OK. very greasy / oily

----The friend chicken - i like how they weren't oily but it was very dry, the outer part was good and very crunch, needs more seasoning though.

very disappointed that they ran out of spicy pork and the KOREAN PANCAKE that i specfically came here for. what a bummer. 

maybe i'll come here again and possibly update my review next time.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Wow, definitely my favorite Korean restaurant.

Shin Toe Bui Yi is a cozy family owned restaurant with gooood fooood. II just love their fish cake. The people there are so nice, they're always smiling and I feel welcome everytime I go there. Their Cal-bi is so good, argh. They also have this hot sour soup with beef and soft tofu. Great to have with your rice! They give you free food on the house sometimes as well, usually mackerel.. The plates you order are huge and they give everyone a bowl of rice. At the end, they even give you these cute little Korean gum pieces. (=
author: M J.

description:
It seems I'm always here about every other Friday night with my cousin, his wife and daughter.  (cousins wife is Korean)  Anyway, if you like Korean food, Kim chee, fish, Kalbi, Bulgoki, korean pancake, then this place is perfect for you.  

Also, their fried chicken is very tasty and be careful cuz they serve it piping hawt!  I also find myself drinking lots and lots of their tea.  I come to find out that it is either barley tea or corn tea.  Both are easy to find in a Korean market.  

It's just a typical hole in the wall type joint and I feel really comfortable during every meal there.  

Here's a tip, if you're planning to have dinner there, be there by 6 or earlier or else be prepared to wait at least 30 min to be seated.  

I like meeting my family there for dinner.  I think you will too.
author: Paolo E.

description: First you go in they don't quite acknowledge you. You sit yourself at a table and find a greasy, loud exhaust fan going full blast about 2 feet over your head. Even with the fan, the dining room has a strong  smoky smell. At lunch time, there is minimal to no service and menu selection is very limited. Food is lackluster at best.
author: YM L.

description:
at a young age i was adopted by koreans and taught to eat korean food in the most traditional style and manner.

okay, so i wasn't adopted... but i've got a few korean friends.

regardless, i've been to better korean than this spot.  the lunch specials are quite the deal, but i'm not sure if i would pay the dinner premium to dine here.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I'm Korean and I'm from LA, land of the Koreans. My mom is the best Korean cook and I'm not exaggerating.
San Francisco is lacking when it comes to all things Korean. There aren't as many Korean restaurants, grocery stores or businesses but I've been trying to make do. I've been doing some Korean cooking at home but there is only so much I can do so I made my husband take me to Shin Toe Bul Yi for lunch a couple weekends ago.
The banchan is OK, nothing to write to mom about and yes, it's free and you get refills but guys, it's banchan.
We got the stone bowl bibimbap, which was pretty mediocre. Something was missing, like sesame oil or maybe it was the type of red pepper paste that they have on the table for it.
The dumplings were decent - my husband (a white guy) inhaled the entire dish.
The fried chicken was good. Sure, it's not BBQ Chicken (a place in Koreatown) or even Chicken Day (another place in K-town) but the seasoning on this was a good balance of salty and garlicky, not too greasy. Eat it with the white pickled radishes they give you.
The freebie tofu soup that came, as they say in Korean, "service", was just OK. My husband liked but I thought it was bland but fine for what it was - free soup.
They play really good Korean Christian music, the ladies are very nice and all of it really was a nice reminder of home.
The portions are huge, most of the dishes are meant to be family style. All in all, this is really not that bad for San Francisco Korean food and probably one of the better choices in this city.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Not bad for San Francisco. 3.5 stars.

After living in Southern California for six and a half years, my pallet became accustomed to what "good" Korean food is. When I moved back to SF, my hopes of finding decent (not even good, mind you... just decent) Korean food were shattered. I recalled eating at Shin Toe sometime during college on one of my random visits back home and was satisfied by the quality and quantities. Today was such a day. After being defeated by the cold and lack of fish at Lake Merced (yes... my friends and I attempted to fish here) this morning, we thought to come here and pay for fish instead. We ate the Sea Bass chiggae and the fried chicken. The soup was pretty good, great flavors and hearty portion (fed three). There was also a variety of pan chan that complimented the meal very well. The fried chicken was whatevs. Our meal came out to $29.90 and we walked out with warm stummies. 

Great service. Higher prices than I'd normally pay for. Sometimes there's a bit of a wait. Would I come back again? Most probably yes for the sea bass chiggae.

I agree with Kris H's comment regarding the spiciness of the food here. If you can't take "spicy" foods, don't worry... the redness of the soups and dishes may cause a bit of apprehension, but fear not! The dishes are NOT spicy at all. For those craving the sweat and drippy noses, ask the servers for EXTRA spicy... it'll almost equate to what is normally "spicy".
author: Teresa Y.

description:
I brought my roommate here for her first-ever experience with Korean food, and we enjoyed it immensely. That bulgogi was really effing good.

Funny thing was, she went nuts over the house tofu soup that comes with the meal and ended up eating more of that than the Korean bbq. Which, I guess, can be read as a testament to the quality of their cooking.

You can bet that the next time we're wanting some really effing good Korean, we'll be taking our broke asses back to Shin Toe Bul Yi!
author: Le V.

description:
The food was good and delicious, but I hated that they could not seat my entire party of 10 people. 

They did not even bother to try to seat us all together. We all went out to be together and I was really disappointed that they split us up like that. 

I also hated that we sat by the door with the door open. It was so cold, but they have to keep it open because it will get smoky inside.  I also did not like sitting by the door because everyone waiting for a table was watching us eat. 

6 of us got seated together by the door and the other 4 got seated in the back of the restaurant. 

The waitress also took our tea kettle, but she never returned it, we had to ask for it back. 

For six people our tab came out to be $87.28 with %15 tip. 

Again, food was good, but not really happy with the service and they probably can keep on giving that kind of service because they always have people waiting. 

I don't think I want to go back.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Food: 5 Stars
Service: 4 Stars

I've been here a couple of times with friends and family so I think I owe it to review. This place is probably best for dinner, as the lunch menus are not as extensive. For dinner, you have to get here early, or you will have to wait in line as there are not that many tables. There is not much space inside, so you'll probably end up waiting in the cold. You can smell the strong Korean food smell even from the outside, and in the winter, it gets pretty drafty for the tables nearer the door.

I noticed that a lot of people order the fired chicken, and it is pretty tasty, even if i don't usually like fried stuff. My favorite dish is the bul go gi(?) the beef on a sizzling plate, I order it every time I am here. I absolutely love this dish, whatever sauce they use on it, is great. This place has the greatest side dishes, much better than the other Korean restaurants I've been to in SF. I've tried a variety of their dishes, and since I'm not Korean, I can't say if the dishes are authentic or not, but the dozen or so dishes I've tried have always been good. 

Every time I've been here, the place always gives a dish or two on the house. Many times there is this green onion pancake and sometimes we've gotten a soup or other foods.

The waitresses don't always see that your side dishes, the spicy tiny fish side dish is so good, or teapot needs to be refilled so you might have to remind them.
author: Jay L.

description:
Excellent food and great service.  We were brought two free dishes (scallion pancake and soft tofu kim chi soup).  

I've had better bul go gi and wouldn't choose the KFC as my favorite dish.  But the bim bim bop was amazing.  

much more reasonably priced than a lot of korean restaurants in the city (for example, brothers)

Definitely would go back.
author: Vishnu R.

description:
This place rocked. I'm a fried chicken fanatic, so I couldn't resist. The chicken is served in deboned chunks, not whole parts you might be used to. And when I say chunks, I mean off a real chicken, not some pre-formed, mass-produced "nuggets." (Side bar: Isn't it a little creepy that McDonald's nuggests only come in 2 shapes?)

I have been once only; I'd go back more often if I didn't live in the East Bay. I went with my brother and one of his friends (a professional cook), and we had a surprisingly great meal. We got 2 or 3 extra dishes without asking. One was a whole grilled mackerel. The cook guy says, "Wow, mackerel is my favorite fish." The food just kept coming, and we just kept eating. Way cool.

The fried chicken delivers, in a mountainous portion the 3 of us couldn't finish.  It is a hole in the wall, but 5 stars for service and cheap prices. Rock on!
author: Keith L.

description:
My friend and I checked out this place a few days  ago. We ordered the spicy pork and the spicy chewy noodles. The spicy pork was good, but it still doesn't compare to Steve's BBQ in Berkeley though. Avoid the spicy chewy noodles unless you like cold noodles drowned in hot sauce. The side dishes and the tofu soup on the house  were yummy!

If anyone knows of any other Korean spots that serves great spicy pork, I'm always up for recommendations=)
author: crystal e.

description:
Forget Hahn's Hibachi, if you want Korean food, get to the outer sunset and wait in this 45-minute line. They bring out little pancakes and appetizers for you, which is awesome. Absolutely no ambiance or any kind of nice environment, but damn the food hits the spot. 

My roommate's Korean, and even he likes this place.
author: Steven H.

description:
my friend and i inhaled a whole order of chicken. highly recommend that you take it home and eat it with siracha (cock sauce).

btw this place looks bigger and packed than it is because it has magic mirrors.
author: Cyndi C.

description:
Not exactly the most authentic, but it does the job. When I went we got a free tofu soup (not like the hot soup you order at "tofu houses") which was my favorite party of the meal. It was spicy enough, but not too spicy to ruin your taste buds for the rest of the meal.

Other things we ordered were the seafood pancake, which was decently good but the sauce was not as good as I've had at other places. Spicy pork sizzling plate was nothing special and NOT spicy. The bibimbap was good and spicy and had a generous portion to share between the 5 of us little asian girls. That would probably be the only thing I recommend. 

Sadly, we didn't get the fried chicken even though everyone in the restaurant had a plate. Next time I'll try it.
author: Katrina S.

description:
I had dinner here a couple of weeks ago with some friends while a friend of mine was in town visiting.  We wanted to go to a Korean place and this was a good meeting point for us already in downtown and my friend coming from San Bruno.  She had been here before and recommended it.  The place is quite small but it was full when we got there and we had a short wait for a table for four.  It's well lit and has a friendly atmosphere.  There were four of us and we ended up ordering the hae mul pa jun, ddeok beok gi, a fried fish (forgot what type) and a noodle soup.  The waitress was extremely nice, maybe because my friend visiting was from Korea and she ordered for us in Korean.  Though, I think they would be that nice even if that wasn't the case.  The waitress even brought us a complimentary plate of their fried chicken that so many rave about here.

I thought the fried chicken was really good, the ddeok was really good too and had the squid with it.  The pa jun was okay.  I've had better.  The soup was good, but I prefer other types of Korean soup.  However, if you like that type of soup, it was pretty good.  The fish was good also, and I think you get more here than other places I've been.  The ban chan however, wasn't the best.  So far, I've found Korea House in Santa Clara to have the best ban chan. 

Overall the place gets 4 stars for good food, decent prices, and extremely good service.
author: Wilson C.

description:
LOVE IT! 

went there for dinner for the first time and it feel pretty traditional Korean ambiance, which i like!   

I LOVE their tofu soup!! and the side dishes were yummy!
I can describe more, but basically I loved all the food I ate. XD

altho the two seat table was a bit small~ hardly fit all the food on the table. but it was okay. feels cozy. :D
author: Karin L.

description:
We tried this place a few weeks ago.  We got the spicy BBQ pork and the chicken teriyaki, which was $30 combined.  It seemed a bit pricey but when you get all the food, it was pretty worth it.  Both of those dishes tasted pretty good, although my fiance said the BBQ pork had an after taste.  Also, the amount of food they gave us got us dinner and next day's lunch!  

We took the food to go because we read about the stinkiness of the place.  =)  We waited outside instead.
author: Joyce L.

description:
This place is one of my favorite neighborhood restaurants. But something seems different about the place now. 

They've remodeled the place so no more sticky tiles, being replaced by hardwood floors and their sticky tables have been replaced with newer, albeit less sticky ones. 

We ordered the Korean Fried Chicken which is still the same awesome dish. Big chunks of chicken, seasoned, battered, and deep fried GB&D (Golden brown and delicious-thanks Alton Brown). Its still tasty and juicy and the best bang for your buck for fried chicken @ $9.99 an order. 

The seafood pancake was ehh.....nothing but mung bean batter, some green onion here and there and the only seafood in it was squid. What happened to the shrimp? There wasn't even one! I prefer the one at My Tofu House more. 

Kal bi is consistent, can't really go wrong with kal bi. 

They didn't give us the complimentary vegetable pancake appetizer like they did before. Maybe it was because we had already ordered the seafood pancake, but I didn't see any other table receive it either. 

The complimentary spicy tofu soup was lacking. It was riddled with MSG, nearly spice-less and watered down. A huge disappointment.

And when we got the check, we literally just got the check, No 30 second gum, nothing. The place was packed on a Tuesday night but maybe with the economy in shambles they decided to save some change by not giving you the gum.
author: Derrick L.

description:
This is one of the best Korean restaurants in San Francisco! 
Here serves more home-style Korean foods, I would say,
So, if you wanna do BBQ on charcoal, try others like Brothers on Geary St.
They however do have grilled meat, which comes on hot plate. It tastes perfect for me; marinated well to soak their original sauce's flavor, not too sweet, meat is always tender and fresh. 
My favorite items are Bulkogi & Squid, Yuk ke Jang and Fried Chicken. Here serves the best Yuk ke Jang in US! It's a hot soup with beef, vegetable, egg and clear noodle. I LOVE IT! 
Service is excellent as well as food! Waitresses are polite and friendly, and often give all the customers something on house, like soup or grilled fish. 
This is very busy restaurant, specially on Friday night, you may need to wait long to have seat, but worth waiting!
If you don't mind walking a block, it's easy to find a parking spot, and when you take public transportation, Muni 'L' stops right in front.
Try here!
author: Ray C.

description:
Friday night.
The wife and I.
SEA BASS!
...fo' dat ass!
Heavy rotation at this spot may be just a few more bites away!
author: Barry A.

description:
Anyong haseyo...that's the Korean way of saying hi, hello, good morning, good afternoon, good evening...a general welcome. Shin Toe Bul Yi serves home made Korean cuisine that many Koreans and Korean Americans enjoy...a key indicator of authentic Korean food.

The moment you sit down, they serve you tea along with a pan-fried sticky rice scallion pancake, accompanied with a vinegar based chili green onion dipping sauce. The place offers the commonly found entrees like kalbee, beef and pork bulgogi, chap-che, tofu stew, meat or vegetable in sizzling stoneware pot, etc. 

Highlights of the place, however, are the unusual dishes. The crispy moist tasty deep fried chicken. Ne-jang-tang...a stew of pollack roe and cod intestines. Minuh-jigae...sea bass and vegetable in spicy stew. The pork and potato spicy stew. The Korean sausage soup. Tofu with shepherds purse in soy bean paste. "Hayake" is the term for ordering the soup or stew without the spiciness. It means white or plain non-spicy soup/stew.

Other entrees worth trying are the sea bass jjim (steamed sea bass in house special sauce), sauted chicken gizzard and vegetables, and steamed skate wings or monk fish.

All entrees comes with six to eight panchan or small side dishes of pickled vegetables, along with a section of pan-fried mackerel. The entrees are substantial. Prices are very reasonable. Korean meals are best consumed with several cold bottles of soju (Chamisul or Sansoju brands).  Wee-ha-yo!
author: aL Z.

description:
So the hubby and I were craving some Korean BBQ. We seen this place packed before, checked it out on yelp and we had to try it. Ever since I had some  bomb ass Korean BBQ in LA I needed to find a place here. 

So LA is know for Korean bbq, hence the 4 stars. It just doesn't compare. However I liked this place. We ordered the onion pancake which I thought was really good. By the way, I'm no Korean bbq expert. I like Steve's Korean BBQ in Berkeley...and I haven't tried Brothers yet. 

We also had the Kalbi and yum. That was very tasty. The soft tofu soup was really good. Not too spicy. I really liked that. nice and soothing for a cold SF evening. 

We'll be back!
author: Leena C.

description:
It is a popular place. All dishes are good. Goddammit, missed the fried chicken. SOLD OUT!!!!  Someone took the last order!!!

Overall food is good BUTTTTT.......by my standards .........too expensive. 
Service was very slow......Only one person serving the whole place.
I will come back to try the legendary chicken everyone screams and dies for here.
I live on the peninsula and there is better value to be had at a couple of spots in San Carlos and San Mateo.
author: tiny w.

description:
My Korean roommate has taken me here twice now to OD on kim chee and tofu. The first time was over a year ago, and I requested a "revisit" last night for our monthly roommate catch-up dinner. Both times, the food has been awesome. This is the place he claims makes food most like his mother's. I've had her cooking, and it's gooood. So is Shin Toe Bul Yi. 

We order:
--Green onion pancake
--Spicy tofu stew
--Fried chicken
--Tofu with fried kim chee and pork over it
--Bulgogi

My favorites are the fried chicken and tofu stew. For three of us with tip, total came to $52. We could have easily fed two more, totally over ordered. It's certainly not a fancy place, but to feast on authentic Korean food at a bargain price I love it here.
author: Shoshana D.

description: We got here at around 7pm for dinner and there was a waiting list with four other parties. I think it was only because we were just a party of two that we got seated pretty quickly. I wanted to order bulgogi but apparently they did not have bulgogi that day. I think they raised their prices because the bulgogi was $18.99!! We ended up ordering a spicy pork dish and the Rice Cake Bok-yi which my friend wanted. Our meal came with a complimentary bowl of rice each, the spicy tofu soup along with the tiny sides. I liked the spicy pork, soup was good, and the rice cake bok-yi was ok. Like last time there was only one waitress so service was slow. I wonder why they just dont hire an extra waitress? I may want to try coming here during lunch between 12pm & 2pm for their $8 special as a cheaper alternative.
author: Helen L.

description:
A friend told me about this place randomly one day, so I figured I'd check it out.  I'm always game for new ethnic eats.

Two of us arrived around 8pm last Friday night.  The ambiance is a little boring, but I could tell the focus was on the food.  There was a line and about a 20 minute wait, but it seemed to go quickly.  We asked them for a beer while we waited and they obliged our request.  While waiting in line, I checked out what other people were eating, and everything looked interesting.  I'd only eaten Korean food a few times and was excited to try as many items as I could stuff into my stomach.  

After sitting down, we ordered a BiBimBap, a pork dish, and the fried chicken (way more than two of us could eat).  Immediately after ordering, the waitress brings about 6 dishes with little hors d'oeuvres/appetizers in addition to rice and a large bowl of spicy tofu soup (freebies!!).  The little dishes were filled with various items; cucumber, pickled daikon, pickled sprouts, anchovies, and a couple things I'm not sure what they were.  In a matter of minutes, our table was filled with food.  

Of the items we ordered, the least satisfying item was the BiBimBap.  I ordered the Kim Chi one and it really didn't hit the spot, not because it's not a good dish, but because it didn't suit my palate.  I think one of the other BiBimBap's would have been better.  The fried chicken was great as was the pork dish.  

I really enjoyed eating here.  It was a lot of food at a reasonable price, fairly good quality, and it was something different than status quo.  If you're really hungry, with a group, or just looking for something new and different, try this place out.
author: Justin H.

description: Overall the food is good and come in big size. The place is kind of small and bad ventilation. The waitress is not too friendly. She wants us to wait outside the restaurant with my 3 yr old kid. It is too cold to wait outsidel. They should have a outdoor heater or something.
author: Shirley C.

description: I went here with my housemates for my birthday and loved it! We tried a lot of dishes, including the sea bass soup and the fried chicken. Both were very very good...even thinking about it now makes my mouth water! The only problem is that the place is extremely busy and is understaffed, so it takes awhile to get extra stuff you might want (water, tea, napkins, etc.)
author: Jenn C.

description:
This place was WAY too much effort (so far to drive) for the quality of food there.
Everything was simply, 'so-so.'
But what was especially disappointing was the Korean pancakes (too much flour they were like 5 inches too thick!) and the free tofu soup was just so bland.
The claypot, Korean fried rice was also very very bland and nothing special to it.
The most bizarre was the so called fried chicken thing that was just simply wrong.  It was like a wanna-be Kentucky Fried chicken but just poor on delivery.  It was the oddest attempt at the Korean style of 'fried chicken' and tasted nothing like it!  
I feel fair in saying that this place has very mediocre food and if it weren't for some friends who we met there, I would definitely not make the trek from the city to check it out.
author: Ahnee M.

description:
Being just a block away from home, I visit this restaurant whenever I'm craving Korean and I'm too lazy to venture too far away.  It serves pretty good Korean food, although it's definitely not top notch.

The one dish that we always order when we go is the Spicy Fried Chicken (small pieces).  It is deep fried and usually still sizzling with oil when it's brought out.  I don't know why they call it spicy though because it's not in the last bit spicy.  I'd say that this is one dish that is consistently good here.  Last time we went, we also got the steamed sea bass, which I liked as well.  When it came out though, it didn't look like the name of the dish suggested.  It was smothered in a red kimchee style broth and covered with tofu, veggies, and bean sprouts.  Large chunks of sea bass were at the bottom and it was admittedly very moist and delicious.  We also ordered the Kalbi, but it was a bit of a disappointment.  The pieces were sliced thicker than normal, but it was a bit dry and not nearly as tender as I'd like.  Like other Korean places, you get an assortment of free little appetizers with your meal.  In addition, they will give you a free tofu soup or fried pancake if you order enough food.

I think Richmond has much better Korean food, but this is a decent substitute if you live in the Sunset like me and don't want to travel very far.
author: Tyler C.

description: I love coming here with family! We never order anything but the fried chicken and the rock cod stew. You MUST order the stew when eating the fried chicken. The spicy kick from the soup compliments the oil and texture of chicken. You also get nice chunks of fish with the stew. YUM! Don't be intimidated by the red because you're missing out on out-of-this-world deliciousness. I guarantee your mouth will be producing about a gallon of saliva.
author: Erin M.

description:
It's not very classy in here. Very hole in the wall-ish but the food is a good value for your money. I really like their fish dishes as well as their ChapChae! Recently I had the DokBokKee with Octopus and asked them not to make it too spicy. And it was delicious! 

Can get crowded at times...
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
Really good grilled Korean food.  We had four people and since I didn't know what to order, I let my friend do it.  We had four items and they were quite expensive, but came in quite some large portions, so the value was alright.  We had the following:

1. Fried Chicken - Yum, deep friend and definitely not healthy, but FUN to eat and was definitely tasty.
2. Bulgogi - My favorite dish out of the four, perfectly cooked beef and GOOD CUTS (rare for a korean place) and drowned in korean bbq sauce and tasted great.
3. Spicy Pork - Not my favorite because of the texture - kinda mushy - 
4. Korean Chicken - Tastes like normal Japanese chicken terriyaki to me and wasn't anything special.  Well cooked and moist and juciy though.

We also had a variety of side dishes which were delicious and a complimentary spicy tofu soup that added to our food.  Add this to the rice we were given and this was way too much food.  2-3 plates for 4 people is more than enough.

We spent about 70 bucks here, quite pricey, but we did order way more than we could eat.  It was good traditional korean bbq beef and yum crispy chicken.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Came here a long while back in their infancy and didn't come back for the longest time but always wanted to return so I recently.....

Came here for their Lunch Specials and really enjoyed my meal.  I think they are one of the most fair priced Korean places in the city.  We had their Bulgogi Beef and Bulgogi Pork.  Liked their Pork much better.  The beef didn't have too much flavor but there are so many other things to try, we will be sure to order some other things next time.  Have to try their Fried Chicken and probably the Korean Pancake.  

Lunch wise, in addition to the small plates, they even gave some soup, which was cool.
author: Mark W.

description:
I love this place.

I love how, like most Korean restaurants, they provide a ton of free stuff to go with your dish.  

You order one thing, and they give you fried onion pancakes and kimchee tofu soup.  You order one of those things and they give you a fish.  

The Fried Chicken kinda tastes like it's got that Chinese Restaurant Crab batter around it.  MM.... soo good and juicy.

Man... I think I might go there this weekend.  I do live about half a block away and the place makes the entire parkside smell good.  Oh yeh, don't go half an hour before closing time, they will refuse you.
author: K L.

description:
FREE FOOD?!?? Shin Toe Bul Yi knows how to hustle.

The first time I came here they blessed us with a free pancake type dish - Pajeon. I thought this was just because we were newbies to the block. Hungry for the high they provided us I've come back about four times since and they continue to bless us with a free dish with each meal - fried fish or tofu soup. 

If you can't appreciate that then the flavor will knock some sense into your senses. The Tofu Soup is a crack. The Fried Chicken is crack. The sides are crack. The Jap Chae is crack. Get your fix.




.
author: Steve H.

description:
So I've come here numerous times throughout the years and I must say the food isn't as good as everyone raves it to be, and it isn't the worse Korean food I've ever had either. Basically the food is mediocre at best. So as I was saying, the food here isn't the best, or bad, but because I live so close to this place, I usually just settle for it because I don't want to drive too far to into the richmond district just for some food. The soups are usually bland and watery, their meat dishes like the kal bi is usually burnt to the grilling plate, and their fishes have this nasty after taste, which typically means its not FRESH! The only upside to this place is their green onion pancake, but that alone is not enough to save this place. And after the last TWO times I've been here, I've had the WORST service ever. If I could give it 0 stars, I WOULD.

The first experience was with the old lady (probably the owner), who was a total B**** about an order of soup that my party and I DID NOT ORDER. She not only forced the soup that we did not order upon us, but had the audacity to charge us for it. Apparently she has a hearing problem, so the next time you go there and she's your server, be sure to SPEAK UP. 

The second experience was tonight, and it was with the short/stubby  waitress.
