I was waiting in line with my sister, and we preferred to sit in the inside since the seat they offered us was in the front near the doors, plus my sister has kids. So we offered to wait for the table away from the door since they were practically paying the bill and ready to leave. After they finish cleaning, the stupid girl comes with her broken english and tells us that shes giving that table away when we clearly told her that we'll wait for THAT table. We asked her why, and she was like well... they're customers. I looked at her as if she was stupid or something because... HELLO, we're customers too!  Not only did it not make sense since she was giving a table that could have seated 6 (which was the size of my party) to a party of 2 instead. So my sister asked the dumb waitress politely if we could get the bigger table since we had a larger party and if the other party could get the table next to ours instead (which seated 4, which would have been perfect for the couple). Instead of even acknowledging our existence she just rolls her eyes and walks off, oblivious to everything. So we finally had it with this place, and we left, FOR GOOD.

Goodbye Shin Toe Bul Yi, we've had enough of your BS service and your mediocre food. I would much rather drive my ass to the richmond district and be treated with respect at a better establishment than here. For those of you who don't mind being treated like garbage, and eating garbage, then feel free to come here, otherwise I would suggest My Tofu House, Han Il Kwan, Muguboka, or any other place than here because they either serve better or the same quality food as Shin Toe Bul Yi... but the only difference is at least you would be treated with respect. It's a different story if they served GREAT FOOD, then I guess it would be okay to treat your customers like garbage, but if you don't serve great food and your service sucks, then you have no right to treat anyone that way. 

P.S. I don't know why everyone thinks the chicken wings here are great. Honestly, it tastes like chicken! It's dry like cardboard, there's no taste, and oh did I mention its DRY?!?!?!
author: Johnson S.

description: The korean style fried chicken is the best.  I love the tangy sweet pickles that come with it.  Also, the 'on the house' pancakes are great.  Also, love the steamed sea bass -- heavenly.
author: Andrew L.

description: The best taste, price for generous portions and side dishes. The only hassle is that the shop closes often and is closed on Sundays.
author: W L.

description:
This place is good.  Smaller place, so expect to wait at certain times.  I did not have the Korean BBQ or Jungol.  I did try the fried chicken.  This is not your typical fried chicken. . . it is nothing like hot wings or KFC . . somewhat crispy but also a bit chewy. . . if that makes sense.  It reminds me more like chicken that is prepared with sweet and sour pork breading.  I think I'm talking in circles now.

We had the spicy race cake as well, which was very good.  The Soon Tobu (Tofu Soup) is awful.  The broth is watery and contains little flavor besides the spice.  Perhaps the worst Tofu Soup I have had. . . similar to pieces of Tofu in Ramen.  Overall, I won't venture back, but it was fun to try the chicken.
author: E L.

description:
Whenever I pass by this restaurant, it's usually empty. We went here last night and the place was packed! We put our name on the wait list and sat down to wait. I've been here once before (10+ years ago) but I didn't remember if it was good or not. Every table had fried chicken so we had to get it too. It comes a little spicy but you can order it not spicy too. It was so yummy! So tasty and juicy. Wayyy better than KFC. So the fried chicken is a must have when you eat here.

The kalbi was very greasy and didn't taste like the kalbi I usually get in other Korean restaurants. It was kind of chewy too. 

We got a fried mackerel fish that was "on the house". It was good. 

We also got the seafood casserole. I didn't try any cuz I can't eat anything spicy. 

We got the seafood pancake. It was very bland tasting and the sour sauce did sort of help. But I prefer soysauce. I wish I read through the Yelp reviews on here. There was someone who wrote that there was barely any seafood in the pancake. 

I probably won't come back since there are better Korean restaurants around. I will probably only come here for the fried chicken.

Really enjoyed the bibimbap. Great quality, really enjoy all the fun extra sides they give (even when you order take-away), and the service was warm and friendly, even for a white boy like me. I will come back here every time I visit the States.
author: Alland B.

description:
We have been living out in the sunset for almost 2 years and had probably passed this place a hundred times, but did not check it out until last weekend.
Surprisingly good, seemingly authentic Korean food.  All the food around us looked quite tasty.
We ordered the soft tofu seafood stew, the Beef Bul-go-gi, and the chicken teriyaki.  The soup was outstanding and the other dishes were above average, if not a bit overpriced.  Everybody else in the restaurant had order the friend chicken, and I wish we had done the same.  We had too much food for 2 people, and had to bring some home with us.
If we had to do it again, we would order the seafood stew and fried chicken, and come to think of it, we will do it again.
author: Leo S.

description:
Top 5 Reasons to go to Shin Toe Bul Yi
5. The name is fun to say.
4. The Dol Sot bibimbap/Hot pot(~$12) is really good.
3. Delicious fried chicken(~$10)
2. The sides/kimchee is well chosen and made.
1. Lots of non-metered street parking outside.

Top 5 Reasons NOT to go to Shin Toe Bul Yi
5. The BBQed meat is usually very fatty.
4. Sometimes though they do not hear the order right and bring you something else.
3. Then when you tell them it is wrong they argue with you.
2. Then they bring you what you wanted originally, which ends up tasting odd.
1. Finally, they charge you for everything.
author: Artur R.

description:
I have driven by a few times where I completely miss it and by the time I pass Sunset Blvd, I am like, where the hell did it go?  Some nights it's easier to spot, because of the groups of people standing outside waiting for a table.  I don't know if it's because there is nowhere else to eat around Sunset, or if it's that good.  I think it's that good. 

The first difference is the green onion pancakes.  Out of all the Korean restaurant on-the-house pancakes, these are the best.  I love that chewy doughy texture.   We usually get the bi bim bap or bul go gi, always satisfying and enough to take home as left overs.  Last time I tried their hand made noodle soup.  What a treat!  You can tell the noodles are hand made because they varied in size A LOT, but like any good hand made noodle, they are very fresh and very chewy.  By the way, the noodle soup is good for people who can't handle spiciness; it's sort of a clear broth with green onions and potatoes (but menu say it's anchovy based).
author: Candice B.

description:
If you want great tasting Korean food, go here! I recommend getting here before 6pm. Any time after that, the place tends to get crowded and you'll find yourself waiting around. Don't forget to sign in on the waiting list if the place is crowded. The list is hanging on the far end, near the cash register. I go here every now and then. Every time I go, the food is always excellent. 

No matter what you decide to order, you get a free green onion pancake as your appetizer. It is really tasty with the red sauce. Also, you get free mini appetizers as well (some kim chee, tofu, pickled cucumber, takuan, etc). 

I went there with my family today and tried the soft tofu stew with seafood. It has soft tofu, clams, octopus, and a red soup stock that looks really spicy, but it isn't. You can taste a hint of spiciness, but overall, it is really tasty. If you don't like seafood, you can always get the plain soft tofu stew. It's good as well. Also, if you order soup, you get a free fillet of broiled mackerel. 

The mackerel comes with a slice of lemon and is broiled to perfection. Crispy on the outside, warm and flaky on the inside. It practically melts in your mouth. 

We also got a seafood rice bowl. It comes in a stone pot that's still sizzling when it gets to your table. There are bits of squid, clams, kamaboko (fish cake), a raw egg in the center, etc, all over rice. just stir it up (adding the sauce is optional) and eat it up! Also, we tried a new dish that has calamari, vegetables, and noodles in a spicy sauce. Again, it looks spicy like the red tofu soup, but when I tried the calamari, it had a slightly sweet, yet savory taste. Very delicious. 

Overall, you can tell that the food here is fresh and of good quality.

The fact that so many people show up at this restaurant everyday is a sure sign that they're doing something right over there! If you haven't gone already, I highly recommend going here at least once! five stars!
author: Kay T.

description:
VERY TASTy!!! 

the restaurant itself is small and doesn't look that clean..they have break hours and they open like at 11:30 or 12:00...and they are usually packed with people waiting outside..HOWEVER...

the food is GREAT..they have the best tofu soup ever...appetizer is good and the free fish and pancakes too...

but service might not be that good since its usually one server...

but food is so good that they deserve 5 stars!
author: Tammy F.

description: Delicious & great Korean food. Do not order soup, they will give it to you for free at the end when you finish your meal. Yummy fried chicken & jap chae & bibimbap.
author: Cindy C.

description: A convenient location (because I live close) in the Parkside district. Friendly service and great food! The restaurant is small, so getting there early is a must.
author: Amy C.

description: BEST soft tofu soup, 5 stars for actually having the owner cooking in the back! if thats not authentic Korean I don't know what is.
author: Hao N.

description: A usual Korean restaurant. I heard about the fried chicken but I wasn't too impressed with it.
author: Gabriel K.

description:
The prices here is way cheaper than most other korean restaurant in SF.  Service is quick and friendly.  I went Friday night at 7:45 and waited about 10 minutes for a table.  There was a clipboard that you sign your name on to get a seat.  Only one party in front of us so the wait wasn't too bad.  By the time we finish, there was a crowd of people jamming the door waiting for  a table.  So my recommendation is to go early.  

Food quality overall was above average.  We had the pork bulgogi and sauteed bulgogi with calamari.  They were both sooooo good.  The only bad thing is the side dishes were a little bland.  The kimchee obviously need a little more time sitting in it's marinade.  So minus one star for the side dishes.  Also, scallion pancake and tofu stew were given to each table for free.  Definitely will go back for another visit.
author: Heidi F.

description:
This place has its pros and cons, although I am no Korean food connoisseur, so this is just my personal taste.  and apart from my most recent visit about a week ago, I haven't gone in over 2 years before that, so it might not be exactly the same anymore.  

Its appetizers are great.  along with the little plates that they give, they also serve grilled mackerel to every table, and they used to have free pancake but I didn't get it last time, so perhaps they've stopped. We ordered the spicy rice cake (dduk bokki?), fried chicken, soondoonboo, and japchae.  this place has one of the best spicy rice cake (dduk bokki?) I've had so far.  It's not too spicy (in fact it can be much spicier), but it has a good blend of sweetness to it that's to my liking.  

I know everyone RAVES about the fried chicken, but really, it's very typical to me, nothing to write home about.  I think they might use a bit of corn starch or whatever because the fried texture is a little different.  but it's relatively bland with no special flavor.  I actually enjoy it quite a bit, but it's just not as special as other people said it is.

The japchae was normal, tasty as always, not too oily.  The soondoonboo was somewhat too salty for me and not spicy enough.  But i'm a huge fan of the soup so unless it's horrendous to eat, I'll love it no matter what.

Other things I've tried in years past, bbq chicken, kalbi, bbq beef, bbq pork, bibimbop.  From what I remember, the taste was slightly off from other places I've tried before (I guess depending on your preference..this might be better or not).  The kalbi is cut differently from most places, it has one large bone with some meat around instead of cutting deep into the bone if that makes sense.  And nothing's too spicy.

While the prices are pretty competitive with the other Korean places, the meat is somewhat on the pricier side ($14-19).   And the wait can be long, and it's small, so you'll definitely come out smelling like your food.  

Regardless, I still think it's one of the better Korean restaurants in SF, and I always have Korean cravings every now and then, so I'll definitely go back again.
author: Christina D.

description:
One of the better Korean places in the city, but it is a pretty small place. Parking can be hard, and if you are going out later...make sure to wear cologne. This place fills up with so much smoke, you end up being a walking korean bbq skewer. 

All the dishes I've tried here are pretty good. I haven't had one that I didn't like to the point where I would make note of it. At the same time, I haven't had anything that I would rave about either. Also, it can get expensive, but all Korean places do.
author: Josh M.

description:
I went for the tofu stew ... it was great.  Tasty and spicy, fantastic stuff, actually looking forwrad to the cooler weather.  
Probably 5 stars after my next visit.
author: Jon P.

description:
In general, the food here isn't as spicy as I'd like  -- I should have read all the reviews and asked for everything extra spicy. Especially the fried chicken! Bibimbap could have cooked longer -- the rice didn't have quite enough time to crisp up. But the gigantic amounts of chicken are crisp-a-licious and the free onion pancake is delicious with the spicy dip. Solid types and amounts of panchan (especially for the vegetarian I came with). And you can't beat some spicy tofu soup to round out the meal, especially when it's free (and you have some extra red pepper handy). 

Do I sound unimpressed? I came away loving STBY. Love love loving it. I will drive to 30th and Taraval. I will wait for 20 minutes in the wind (Yeah, bring your poncho. It's COLD out there). I will cram myself and two other people into a table meant for only two. And next time, I'll ask for everything extra spicy. I'm giving this one four stars for general coziness. The food isn't fancy, the decor isn't fancy, the service isn't fancy, and the prices aren't fancy. It's all kind of homestyle. But unlike a lot of people writing reviews, I like it that way. Everyone looks like they're having a great time, and it seems like a point of pride for the waitstaff to send everyone off with mountains of take-away cartons from the enormous plates of fried chicken. 

Shin Toe Bul Yi is warm and friendly, and a little grungy. Like my mom's kitchen -- if my mom were Korean instead of Jewish.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
This place was hard to find to write a review for. Apparently typing in KOREAN RESTURANT didnt cut it. I like this place because it feels like your eating in your korean grandmas living room. 

The Octopus noodles tasted like a garlic round table pizza for some reason.
author: Paul Q.

description:
Kimchi Chi-gae (tofu/meat stew), fried chicken, and  tofu kimchi.  All of it was tasty.

The wait was long though.  We were standing outside for what felt like eternity but ended up only being 35 minutes.  Hey, that's a long time to wait when you're stomach is talking to you.

Otherwise, I can't believe I didn't know about this hidden gem until yesterday.
author: Jeanne L.

description: a couple of friends have told me a lot about this place...i.e. thee place to go in the Sunset for Korean. seeing how i've never been to a Korean place in the Sunset, i really had nothing to compare it to. from what they said compared to my experience itself, the place was a little disappointing, so to my surprise of how well-rated the place is on here. it's definitely has that classic mom-and-pop feel to the restaurant and isn't the biggest place. combined with bad parking (of course, it's SF!), apparently it gets pretty crowded too, so the wait once you actually find parking can be stomach-grumbling bad. but once you're seated, the service is relatively good for the most part and pretty friendly (our waitress was kind of hot). their food (i ordered the bulgogi like i do at every new Korean place i go to; it helps me compare it every other Korean place i've been to). it was good, but not as overwhelmingly fantastic as some of these reviews say, nor were the chicken wings and bip-in-bop. good, but Mom's Tofu House in SSF has it beat.
author: Mike C.

description: 1st time going there with a few of my bestest friends..we ordered 5 dishes i think LOL but the fried chicken is hella good..it was packed around 730 crowded,pplz were waitin in lines and decent price.
author: alan l.

description: Yummy Korean food! I went here about a month ago.. so I don't really remember what I ordered. It was those glass noodles I believe (forgot the korean name) but it was tasty. good service but can get a little packed.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Absolutely our fave Korean place - very homey, dishes are tasty.  My friend and I always crave for the Seabass soup - flavorful with good chucks of seabass in it.  Hubby likes the Korean-fried chicken - they are fried well and not too greasy, plus flavorful.  I also like the meats - good Kal bi and chicken teriyaki.  I also like their spicy chewy noodles - noodles with good texture and great octopus/calamari pieces, yumm!!
One setback is that they are too popular, so on Fridays or Saturdays, they cut their waiting list at 8:50 or 9:00pm, even though they close at 9:30.  Got turned away a couple times because I worked late on Fridays :(.
author: Vicky F.

description:
This place is so good! I've lived in this neighborhood most of my life and I have never tried the food until last year when my Korean co-worker brought me here, I can't believe I've been missing out for so long! Definitely one of the best Korean restaurants I've ever tried.

I'm not sure if they've raised their prices, but it seems a bit more expensive since the last few times I was there. Anyway the food is still really good and you get lots of extras so it's well worth the price.

I love getting the fish soup there when I'm feeling sick. The soup is so spicy with lots of veggies and it warms up your insides in a jiffy. The onion pancake super yummy too, I always finish it when my friends don't want anymore.

So far I've really liked everything I've tried which includes 3 of their soups, the chap jae, bul go gi, and a bunch of other dishes that I can't remember at the moment. It's a bit expensive, but it's my place of choice when I'm craving Korean.
author: Felix T.

description: We arrived just in time to grab a table before a tour bus came and dropped off a boat load of elderly Asian folks. Yummy Korean food that isn't overly spicy.  We ordered a ton of food (see here: http://hphotos-snc3.fbcdn.net/hs121.snc3/16832_404498945001_735120001_10220347_5806000_n.jpg) and everything was delicious (and devoured). The complimentary side dishes are always a plus.
author: Fotos C.

description: Fried chicken is the bomb, also boneless rib dish good food. Lots of food plan on taking food home.
author: David B.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant.  They always give nice freebies such as korean pancakes or fish.  My wife and I normally order Bulgogi, kim chee chi gae, and the fried chicken.  We absolutely love the pickled radishes.  Delicious!  I'd love to eat their kal bi more, but its a bit pricier compared to the bulgogi.
author: Nand D.

description: I love this place. Has great service and of course the food is delicious. The place is small, but it's all about the food that I care about. Won't fail you, check it out.
author: Isaac B.

description:
I was there yesterday with my hubby & cousin. We're waiting for 30 minutes & then the waiter made a mistake for giving our seat to other people. She had apologized many times, but still we had to wait another 15 minutes.

We ordered:
1. Fried chicken (everybody there ordered it)
2. Bulgogi
3. Tofu soup
4. Jap chae (Korean noodle with beef & vegetables)

I was very disappointed that the Fried chicken was SO plain (KFC's spicy crispy chicken at Geary & 5th-6th street is much better!!!)

Bulgogi & tofu soup was good, but I think you can find it better in My Tofu House at Geary or Pine Restaurant at Noriega.

Jap chae was also good, nothing special.

Sorry, I won't eat there anymore, it's better to me to eat at other Korean Restaurants.
author: Natalie S.

description: Who knew Koreans could make fried chicken so mouth watering good!  It is always moist, crispy, and the spice in the batter is genius.  The fried chicken here is the best I've had so far.  Along with this menu item, I often order the jap chae, tofu soup, and bul go gi, which are all good as well.  I would recommend take out because this restaurant is always crowded and gets super smokey.
author: Linda P.

description: This is not my second time here... haha... giving it a bonus star because I forgot they liked to hook you up with extra food! They love to give you an extra dish which is always a plus in my book. Order their fried chicken! Koreans know their fried chicken!
author: Gordon L.

description:
I use to go here for lunch twice a month. The staff was always friendly, and the food was always good. Thought my friends and I referred to it as cat-er-ing, since that's what it said on the sign.

When ordering it is important to assume that they will provide a free main dish for a group of two or more. It will likely be broiled mackerel or chigae, both are excellent. They also have really good fried chicken.
author: Geoffrey P.

description:
This place is good, but it is TINY inside. I have been pretty lucky to always get a table right away at this place. They have good banchan and offer you some grilled fish on the house after you order. They have these really tasty casseroles filled with veggies, tofu, meat or seafood. Had their tofu and kimchee entree and it was pretty yummy and it tasted like something my mom would make if she was Korean. This is one of my favorite Korean places and places to eat in the Sunset.
They have Korean fried chicken here, and almost everyone orders it, but to me it just tastes like regular fried chicken, so I would skip it.
author: Sheena L.

description: Best fried chicken in the city.  Too bad the dinning room is a little bit small...  i wouldn't go here with more than 5-6 people.     This  and tofu house are my favorite korean family hangs in the city...
author: mike y.

description: Place is deceivingly small and the line of people adds to the slight disappointment. Alas, the famed fried chicken is not the true Yang Nyum Tong Dak I longed for but it was tasty. Everything else was fine. Not the greatest but not terrible. Definitely somewhere worth going if/when the funds are lower, you live near by, and your soul is in need of some quality time with the friends!
author: Mina L.

description:
This place was OK.  There are better Korean restaurant out there.  

Why I like it:  Free soup and side dishes

Why I didn't like it.  Costumer service was Super slow,  Took 7 mins to ask for my order.  Tea and water came in about 5 mins later.  The server look like they didn't want to work there. No smile low energy.  Waitress did not ask if I was ok if i needed anything.

The food was OK.  I ordered jap chae, Kolbi and seafood pancakes.  
Sea food pancake - good 13 bucks
Kolbi - average - 18 bucks
Jap Chae is average - 10 bucks
The portion of the food was big
The total was 43 bucks 

Shin Toe Bul Yi is an OK restaurant.  The food was average.  I did not like the slow customer service.  The only thing i like is the free tofu soup and side dishes.  There are other better Korean restaurant out there.
author: Hien t.

description: The food ain't bad. I've had better Korean food in the city. The menus pricing and meal sizes are confusing. Also, not cheap
author: Thomas C.

description: Located at the corner on Taraval and 30th, this Korean resturant has a small cozy atmosphere. The food was average, nothing really special. When we first went in, the waitress provided 5 menus for a party of 6 and I had to ask for a menu. It took them awhile to refill the teapot. However, the food was cooked really fast. I ordered the seafood and vegetable with rice in a stoneware pot. The seafood pancake wasn't cooked thoroughly.. And I've had better seafood pancake than this.
author: Brenda C.

description: The one best thing that this place has is the: KOREAN FRIED CHICKEN.  yes I said fried chicken, its sooooooooooooo yummy and you can't stop eating it. lols. They always give you a free item on the house from soup to fish and many other things. There is usually only one lady that waits the table and I give her props cuz she works really hard and manages to still smile and greet the customers. I went here wit a good buddy of mine and the funny thing is that I ended up back here two days later to enjoy some more yummy chicken XD. prolly wasn't the best idea for me to do but oh well u only live once lols. It is good to go for lunch because it isn't too busy but I am not sure about dinner. Overall it was good :D
author: Jonathan W.

description: If you come here you must order the fried chicken. The pork feet was very tasty and good. I'll definitely go back and try other dishes.
author: Mary L.

description:
Wow! who would have guessed? I have past by this place a million times and i always thought this place is closed or empty.  Finally after reading the Yelpers' reviews, i finally got the courage to step inside and taste their food.  
Don't let the exterior of this restaurant fool you, the food  and the atmosphere inside is WAY better than expected!!!  I have to say, their menu is way better than a lot of average Korean restaurant in the city...
We had a couple dishes that recommended by all you Yelpers:
Jap-chae-surprisingly chewy, but good
Terikayi chicken-moist but not browned enough, however, the charcoal flavor compensate the flaw
Stoneware seafood rice (bibimbap)-the best i have ever had, the flavorful sauteed seafood mounted on the rice is even good without adding the hot-sauce. Hmmmmm....Yummy!
fried chicken- YUCK!!! bland chicken with enormous amount of thick batter.  The crust is just hard and flavorless, and it was even tough enough to break your jaw!!  Hmm..I guess the only purpose of the crust is to make the chicken seems larger 

Oh... also they have FREE tofu soup!!! even it is just MSG with soft tofu, i cant complain because it is free!! and they offer alot of side dishes too! which is always a plus! =)
Overall, its special menu and food does worth a try, but don't bother going for second because the food are WAY too pricey and oily.
author: Cathy C.

description: Big disappointment! Based on the strong Yelp reviews, my group of 4 was looking forward to some delicious Korean food tonight. Wasn't going to happen! We ordered the highly touted fried chicken, seafood bi bim bap, eel bi bim bap, and gal bi. Along with the ban chan, we received the soft tofu soup on the house. The fried chicken was crispy but had a heavy batter and no seasoning at all. The flavor of chicken was lost somewhere in the cake-y batter. Had to create my own dipping sauce from soy sauce and the red paste used for bi bim bap to give it some life. The gal bi was the worst I've had. It came out on a room temperature hot plate (not hot and not sizzling any of the beef either!).  The beef was also at room temperature and without any grill marks. Hmmm...me thinks this was pre-cooked and thrown on a sizzling plate for looks. the bi bim baps lacked any flavor from the eel and from the seafood. Both toppings were clearly once frozen and defrosted. The free soft tofu soup lacked depth and character. It tasted like blocks of tofu soaked in boiled water that was laced with leftover sauce from kimchi jars. I'm not joking...it tasted like kimchee bath water! The ban chans were the highlights especially the little anchovies and fish cakes. The kimchi lacked both heat and tanginess. Service was efficient and lacking any warmth. Had to ask for water, tea, napkins, refill on empty ban chan dishes. Will pass on this joint next time I'm feeling in the mood for Korean food. This place and To Hyang are very over-rated. Difference is that the prices are better here. Avoid both!
author: H E.

description: I'm picky about my Korean food and the ways in which some places water it down. This place is the real deal in consistent authentic Korean Flavor. They make chap jae (Clear Bean Thread Noodles) differently from alot of places because this one is served hot and has a smoky flavor to it. The Sea Bass Jim is also a fave and the fried chicken carries a crispiness that makes me cry tears of joy. Go right at 5:30pm becuase if you hesitate you'll have to wait outside in the cold waiting for folks to finish their chicken wangs. No Joke
author: Leslie L.

description: The scallion pancake and its sauce is sooooo good. I love the free sides too, the tofu soup, radishes, etc. I think just those items are good for two three tasty meals already.
author: Jen Y.

description:
As with most of my reviews of Korean food joints, I must begin by stating that this was certainly not the best Korean food that I've ever had.  It is, however, one of the better places to eat Korean in San Francisco. *shrug*

My boyfriend and I were able to get stuffed on only $30 (including tax and tip!).  He ordered the stone-bowl bibimbap, and I ordered the grilled croaker.  They comped us the soft tofu soup and zucchini pancake and offered plenty of side dishes to keep my belly satisfied.  

A few observations worth noting:
* WATER & ROASTED BARLEY TEA - the server brought us our own large bottle of chilled water and pot of hot tea to keep us hydrated the entire meal without having to wait around for service.  YAY!
* COMPLIMENTARY DISHES - it was so nice to order only an entree and have the restaurant decide that you should be able to enjoy an appetizer and soup any way.  The zucchini pancake could have included more veggies, but it was free and had enough flavor to not need the sauce.  The tofu stew was on the blander side, but it was still loaded with silken tofu and veggies enough to chow down on!
* SIDE DISHES - good balance of seasonings and oil, tasted as if they had been made the same day rather than days before. Good variety ... no fewer than 7 dishes.
* BIBIMBAP - could have sat over the heat longer to get the temperature of the bowl up.  The best part of this dish is usually getting a delicious crust of rice to sizzle around the edges, but this one just sort of died prematurely as soon as the egg got cracked in.  Bummer.
* CROAKER - they gave me two entire fish with my order... heads and all.  TWO!
author: Jenny K.

description: I went out to this little spot with one of my friend along with her family who live about 3 blocks from this little gem!  We went out and between the six of us, we ordered 6 dishes and and I must say the tofu soup and their fried chicken was amazing!  It's definitely a small little place but the Korean food and the sides are so good, When we got there two parties of 4 were adhead of us, we got seated probably in about 15 minutes, people have a tendency to eat and go, the food comes pretty quickly on the night I was there and yes the one of waitress there was pretty bitchy.  It's all good, the food was freakin amazing and on those 6 dishes it came to about 65 bucks, definitely coming back here for my Korean fix.  People say it has a sketchy atmosphere, I don't think it is that bad, I've eaten in sketchier places, but then again it was a narrow smoky alley in Japan...
author: Chris T.

description:
Anytime you can grill your own meats is a good time in my book. And it can be done at Shin Toe Bul Yi 
Our merry gang of Yelpers got lured here with the promise of oh-fuck-me-good Korean fried chicken. It was good but not oh-fuck-me good. I ate most of the meat but didn't savor it enough to gnaw off the gristle.  
The spicy sea bass soup was definitely worth at least a hand-job though. Even I, a spice wimp, devoured my bowl of this brothy/chunko-mad-tender-white-fish concoction.
And yes, the portable tabletop grill they bring out was my highlight.  They have 3 grilled meat options. We got a platter of an uncured bacon, which you then dip a oil/sesame/pepper sauce. I think the platter was like $19 alone, which I thought was a little expensive, but it's a BIG platter, so order accompanying dishes, accordingly.  So much grilled FAT goodness...it should rightly kill you.  Oh well, at least you'll have gone out with a happy palette.
Don't forget to use the apathetic-waitstaff-attention-grabbing-waves-in-the-air for service.
3.5 stars.
author: CINDY K.

description:
i remember i used to come pick up my pops after dinner with his buddies there. id arrive and at a table for four, they had an entire another table filled with empty beer bottles. 

more than a decade later, just so happens a friend of mines uncle buys the place and we do the same thing there. 

great spicy fish egg soup, spicy seabass soup and the fried chickens damn good. 

FYI HAN BAT AND SHIN TOE BUL YI ARE THE SAME PLACE.

id stay away from the place if youre sensitive to smoke.

being korean, i cant bring myself to give it more than 3 stars. the food is good, but nothing to write home about. id stop by if youre in the neighborhood, a nice casual weeknight dinner.

edit 2/14/2007

so last night a bunch of yelpers invaded the joint. for putting up with a party that took up half the place, add half star. another half star goes to secret menu. so apparently theres items not on the menu. must try more.
author: Euge L.

description: Once you've tasted the fried chicken here, you'll be hooked for life.  Light years better than any of the soul food joints in the city.  Who knew?
author: Reality Check S.

description:
oh hell yes!!!!  the fried chicken here was so ridiculously tasty and not greasy one bit.  the banchan dishes that they served was all so tasty, especially their kimchi.  not too spicy, but not too tangy.  the soon dubo that comes with your meal was also incredibly tasty.  sort of a smoky flavor to the tofu.  

we went with a 10mo year old highly excitable (but very cute) little boy and they immediately brought out this lovely antique highchair for him and no one cared when he made a lot of noise.  they servers were super friendly and prompt (and gladly doled out more banchan to us) and the clientele seemed all so friendly (though that may have been because they were all drugged by the delicious fried chicken.  

This place will make my "list" of regular dining spots.
author: Andrew r.

description: korean comfort food....a mix and match of homestyle cookin'...deep fried ginger seasoned battered chicken....little over battered, but tasty......spicy seabass soup...hearty meaty good......spicy roe stew....intensely packed with large sized fish roe........uncured korean bacon...fresh and delicious......complimentary flour pancakes and pan fried mackeral was a nice touch.....small selection of sidedishes..soju and beers are plenty.....bit cramp seating....service can be sluggish on packed nights........
author: Hen A.

description: The fried chicken with the red sauce is so delicious!  All the panchan are fresh tasting, including yummy fish (thanks for the rec K/T!).  Get there early to avoid the long wait.  A must try for authentic, delicious Korean food.
author: Hello K.

description:
Fried chicken, green onion pancake and steamed pot stickers are listed as house specialties. We had all three and they were awesome, especially the fried chicken. 
If you use the restroom remember to flush three times. Although the riptide is downhill it is a few blocks away.
author: Jeff B.

description: This place may be the best Korean restaurant in the city, and in terms of cost-to-value, it is definitely the best. The Korean friend chicken is light, sweet and a little spicy (a must-have). The dol sot bibimbap is pretty good and about $7 cheaper than at most places in the city. The broiled mackerel is also solid. Plus you generally get a free green onion pa jun and tofu soup when you eat here.
author: Ray N.

description:
a friend of mine swore that this was one of the best korean restaurants he's ever been to. i should have known better than to listen to a non-korean regarding korean food.

kimchi jigae was too sour and the bulgogi was dry and flavorless. i enjoyed the the fried chicken and the variety of pan chan but that's about it.

if you know your korean food, this isn't the place for you. but if you're not picky and don't know the difference, this is a decent korean spot to grub at.
author: elsie k.

description:
i'm korean but i'd never had korean fried chicken before tonight.  my mom did not make a lot of fried foods, except squid when we had dinner parties.  considering my lifelong love for fried squid, it is probably good i was never exposed to the fried chicken of my people as a kid

i tried the fried chicken, the seabass soup and a bibimbap with seafood in it at shin toe bul yi.  since i was late and my friends ordered before i got there, i didn't see what else was on the menu.  the chicken was good but we didn't get any sauces.  it was flavorful enough on its own but i was curious about the sauces.  i'm not used to bibimbap with mussels and i don't think i'd get it again but the seabass soup was excellent.  

we got serviced the mackerel and the pancake which was nice and the banchan was on the skimpy side but as mentioned by someone else, that was fine considering the portions of food we got.  

i want to go back and try the roe soup and maybe the barbecue.
author: Seong P.

description: I decided to join some Yelpers for dinner recently.  Someone had enticed me with promises of KFC...Korean Fried Chicken.  I'd never had it before and in my quest to try the best fried chicken joints, I decided to add it to the taste test.  Like a lot of Korean restaurants, they give you a lot of side dishes to go with your food.  Personally, I stick to the main courses, but that's just me.  I dove into the bul go gi, Korean bacon, octopus, and the KFC.  I don't recall what else was there, other than several shots of soju and some Hite beer in front of my plate.  As for the KFC...it's good, but I'd put it up against Chinese fried chicken any day.   I did get to witness the immaculate conception of Poe's little Korean offspring...that was a sight to behold.
author: JeFF T.

description: The food is good, but their spiced Korean fried chicken is what makes me go back for more.  It's delicious!  The chicken is still juicy, the seasoning is perfect and enhanced by the white pickled dikon radishes.  Have chicken and  with a cold glass of beer and you too will go back for more.
author: Michelle S.

description: How could I have not gone to this place sooner?!  I've driven by so many times and last night the bf and I decided to check this place out. This place has a home-style atmosphere so don't expect anything fancy. The food and service was great. They threw in some freebies - plate of scallion pancake and hot n spicy tofu soup. This place is a keeper and I'm looking forward to my next visit.
author: hello k.

description:
they only serve takeout during lunch and are open for dinner.

i like this place because they give lots of banchan and sometimes you can either pick btw free mackeral (i think. or some sort of fish) or tofu soup.

the fried chicken is a popular item here. the batter is light and crispy and not oily like KFC.
author: sara n.

description: I love this place. I really do. The service isn't the best. But theirs is the only food that satisfies my Korean cravings. If I go anywhere else, I just wish that I came here. Staples that we always order are the soft tofu stew, bul go gi, pork bul go gi, chicken teriyaki, and jap chae. I have to admit though, the jap chae has gotten a bit less tasty and more oily over the past year. But, seriously, best soft tofu stew.
author: Tiff L.

description:
Sketchiest looking Korean Restaurant ever. 
Best Korean Homemade food ever. 
Bitchiest Waitress (The prettier one) Ever!

You'll definitely miss the spot if you drive pass it, when it's not dining time. But you'll never miss it if you go around dinner time. It's like Tartine Bakery, the line is the sign. There are several tables in the restaurant that accommodates groups of any size, 2 or 10. As many reviewers suggest, the circulation is poor so be prepared to smell like Korean BBQ.

Homemde food is what you get here. There is a big difference between "party food" and "home food" in asian cousine. You only eat the "party food" when you have guests or go to fancy restaurants. And the food is so different from the food that you eat everyday at home. Let's put it this way, the food tastes like your mom, that's how we describe it.

The banchan (complimentary dishes) is pretty good. Fresh kimchi, pickled turnip, sauteed dried fish (great with beer or soju!), among many others. The complimentary Tofu stew is just amazing when it's freaking cold and humid out. If you order a stew, they would give you some bbq fish instead, very thoughful.

My favorite food here is the steamed sea bass. OMG...the chunks of fish are so huge and thick, steamed in the homemade spicy and sweet sauce, with tons of soy bean sprouts, and the soft tofu. I love the combination of various textures in a dish. The sea bass contains higher amount of fish oil (which is good for you) so the soy bean sprouts balance it out very nicely. The Tofu and the chunks of turnip are so tender and packed with the flavor from the sauce....mmm....so yummy!!

The rice cakes and squid stir fry is very tasty too. The rice cakes are well cooked so they are sticky, chewy, and soft in a balanced way. We ordered about 3 different dishes that are with spicy sauce, but none of them are alike, unlike some so-so restaurants that every spicy dish tastes the same. 

The fried chicken seemed to cause a big storm on yelp reviews. They are good, with a kick of spicy marinate. But it's not THAT great. It's great if you go with a group of people and most of them are guys.

Lastly, the bitchy waitress. If it's your first time there and there is a line, GO PUT YOUR NAME ON THE LIST!! My roommate and I once went there in a very cold evening, all starved after a long day, and we waited inside while the line was short. The waitress obviously saw us many many many times as she walked around serving, and she smiled at us. But how on earth would we know that we need to walk all the way into the restaurant to put our name on the tiny book since there's no sign of any sort? We waited for like 40 minutes, nothing happened, of course, because we didn't know that we were supposed to put our name on the list. When we finally figured that out, we talked to the waitress, hoping that she would do something to accommodate us, since she knew we've been there forever. But she "pretended" that she was "deaf". She did!! It was as if she couldn't understand what we were saying. Totally ignored us!!!!! So we had to wait until everyone else is seated, and by the time we got a table, it was more than an hour later. She is the rudest waitress in the world. I bet if we were 2 cute guys, the situation would be totally different. Ahh....I'm still so pissed after so long.
author: Yuchi C.

description: there's a wall of mirrors to make it look like the dining area is twice as big as it really is! horrible when you're starving and in line for a table and realize that your eyes just played a big trick on you! we ordered tofu soup with beef, pancakes with scallions, and their fried chicken. 2 out of 3 were winners. if you guessed pancakes and tofu soup you're right! the pancake was extremely fluffy with a dipping sauce that exponentially elevates its taste. plus the portion was in line with my hunger level. the tofu soup had a good kick to it and very flavorful. as for the fried chicken...you're better off with kfc or popeye's. the batter was tasteless and there were lots of it. the meat wasn't marinated beforehand either. not impressed, but the complimentary fried fish and sides made it all better.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Oh my! This place seems to be the only place to get korean fried chicken for a 50 mile radius around San Francisco. I've been going to Shintoebulyi since i was 5 and their fried chicken is very good. The moment the pieces of chicken enter your mouth, your mouth will salivate as your teeth chomp down on a crunchy and slightly spicy skin and then you will penetrate the soft and tender chicken while you rip away using your jaw and munching with great comfort. Also be sure to eat this with the white radish cubes they give you for the full orgasmic effect. Great Korean Friend Chicken.
author: James K.

description: Nevermind that the name has "Toe" in it. :)  This is a great neighborhood restaurant when you're craving good, cheap Korean food.   What's really great is that they have a good selection of FREE appetizers such as anchovies and green onion pancake (which comes with a great dipping sauce).  We normally order the Bul Go Gi (bbq beef) which is really tasty!!
author: John c.

description: Meh.  Some of the side dishes tasted old and rubbery and they only served about 5 dishes  The meat we ordered grilled was drowning in the marinade.  The service was really rude but that's how my people are sometimes so I'm not too bugged out about that.
author: Joyhan S.

description:
best korean food on this side of golden gate park.  there's no grills on the table, so its not the most interactive korean restaurant, but at least you leave without attracting a pack of wild dogs.

the yums: fried chicken (really thick, crunchy batter), sea bass (not the stew one), the spicy bbq pork, and home-made noodles with soup--either potato or spicy seafood.

the freebies: the usual small dishes (sprouts, cucumber, tofu, dried fish, radish, kimchi), tofu soup, green onion pancake, and sometimes a mackeral

i've been coming here for years, but it's getting way too crowded nowadays since people are starting to notice it. so go away people, i need a seat--it's really not that good.
author: Audacity L.

description: Korean fried chicken bitches!  Off da hook.  Great food here and great sides.  Small place and long waits but well worth it.  For dessert cruise upto Marco Polo for some Chinese gelato.  Definitely not a party for the lactose intolerent especially after some kimchee.  Ohh but it might be worth it
author: goldberg d.

description: Just found this place today, in my search for Korean fried chicken (which I promptly forgot to actually order).  We had the tofu, jap chae and #67 (which, if you get the large, is huge).  All of these dishes were tasty and awesome. mmm.... Korean tofu makes me happy.
author: Jan C.

description:
1) Parking can be a pain in the butt
2) The wait can be long, especially if you arrive after 630pm on weekends
3) Due to the size of the restaurant, it's not really ideal for parties of more than 6, unless you arrive early or perhaps make reservations
4) Free ban chan (size dishes) + rice + soon doobu (spicy tofu soup) 
5) Love the bulgogi and spicy calamari bok um 
6) Love the tea (not sure exactly what it is) 
7) Not a fan of the fried chicken like what the other yelpers are raving about 
8) For $30, It was enough to fill two person + two boxes of To Gos! 
9) Some of the stuff really aren't that spicy, so if in fact you do want it spicy, feel free to request it spicy!! 
10) I'll definitely come back!
author: Emily L.

description: the most authentic Korean food in town so i eat there most of the time when i feel like for some real and homestyle Korean food.  the reasons i give 4 stars are that they only serve lunch in to go box, and does not open on Sunday.  the food quality can be slightly diminished during busy hours. and the wait is somewhat long because the restaurant is quite small. other more that, i love the food very much.
author: Bei K.

description: Shin Toe Bul Yi is my favorite Korean restaurant mainly because the waitresses are great and the food is tasty. I love the green onion pancake and the spicy sauce it comes with. The only thing I don't like is the lack of ventilation, so you usually end up smelling a little smoky when you leave.
author: Shar L.

description: Wouldn't go here by choice. Their food is average and kinda pricey. Been here around 6 times in the past 12 years living near by. They are really packed sometimes and the actual sinning area is bunched in.
author: Keit K.

description:
Never even heard about this place until yesterday when I asked my friend if he wanted to eat after we played basketball.  After we decided we were gonna eat here, we called up a couple of friends and agreed to check this place out.  He told us that he knew the daughter of the owners or something and that it was really good.

He wasn't lying.  Like others have said, the outside makes it look not very pretty at first glance, but once you get inside it's a very comfortable setting.  We got there at around 630PM on a Friday evening and had our party of 4 seated immediately.  Entrees here are served a la carte I believe if you order three or more, then you get free tofu soup! (At least we did).  

All in all, I really enjoyed this place and I am really looking forward to coming back.
author: Joel J.

description: Overall 3.5 stars. I've been wanting to try this place since I've heard that they have good fried chicken but it's been closed everytime I dropped by (didn't realize they're closed Sundays). I tried again on Friday, and they were open! The place was packed. My bf and I got the last table by the door which was chilly, but they had to leave the door open otherwise the place gets too smokey. We ordered the fried chicken which arrived bigger than we expected (bigger plate and bigger pieces). The chicken was a bit dry once I got through the thick deep fried skin to the meat (wish it came with dipping sauce). The dumpling, rice cake, and egg soup was good for warming us up on that cold night; I recommend that over the tofu soup which was bland (we ordered mild spiciness). Since we ordered soup, they also gave us grilled mackerel on the house (I hear if you don't order soup, you get tofu soup on the house). Service was friendly. If I return, I might try the hand-pulled noodles next time.
author: Diana B.

description: I asked the cashier what  "Shin Toe Bul Yi" means and she told me "traditional".  That's funny because a previous Yelper has said it didn't seem very traditional .  Well , whether true or not, this place is crowded and there's a line for good reason.  The food is good, varied menu, pick a favorite and go with it, and it is not too expensive.  The location at 30th and Taraval is OK but the ambience is unique.  We ordered a seafood rice in STONEWARE POT.  I see others have posted a photo of this and I will too.  Also,  a tomato based beef stew whose name escapes me at  the moment but the beef was excellent being shredded and not fatty or bony. My wife says she thought the tomato based soup was not spicy enough but I found it so spicy I had to choke.  (In a good way of course)  I also liked the typical Korean lead in dishes, in little bowls like appetizers and  my favorite is the pickles, and the pickled radish and kim chee, well everything.  And my total favorite which I don't know if it can be ordered separately but came with my seafood rice was a fried fish.  I'm going back to see if I can find this fish on the menu and order double, and also everybody in the place ordered the fried chicken which looked fantastic and not dripping with oil fried but kind of dry fried . We're going back to try it
author: Jerome W.

description:
i gotta say, this place is pretty authentic and the price is decent.  you can tell that the food is good when there's a line outside the door.  we came here on a saturday night and the wait was 30 minutes.  plus parking is pretty hard, i drove around for 20 minutes for a  spot that's 2 blocks away from the restaurant. 

we looked at the menu and the ordered the BBQ rib eye, tofu/beef stew spicy stew, and fried chicken.  I wanted the Kal-bi but they ran out so we ordered the fried chicken because we saw every table have a plate.  It was a very big plate of chicken! and good too! highly recommend it.  It came with a grill fish also (on the house).  We finished everything except for the fried chicken.  

There's only 2 servers so you might have to wait to order and it'd be hard to get their attention.
author: Kapo T.

description: They make really good japche (clear noodles with beef, see the pictures) and spicy sea bass with daikon and sprouts.
author: Tanessa J.

description: If I go to a place more than a few times, I'll give it 5 stars.  This is for sure one of them.  The fried chicken is definitely the thing to order all the other stuff are really good there too.  A lot of place charge for the tofu soup, they give it to you complimentary.  Seafood pancake is really good too, some places and I've tried a few different Korean restaurants, don't cook it all the way through, this place does.  So, it's not all soggy and disgusting.  Chicken gizzards are one of my favorites there and a whole list.  One place you can't go wrong.
author: Peter L.

description: Not the fanciest place, but the food is delicious! Service is great when you go during the slow hours. My bf and I got complimentary fish and pancake-like thing. The kimchee soup is SO good, along with the short ribs. I'm drooling just thinking about their food.
author: sophia l.

description: I love the fact that they spend their money on the food and not the decor. And, any place that has a side order of fried fish and oh so yummy green onion pancakes is a must eat place!  Why is good Korean so hard to find in SF?!   My favorite is the tofu soup; it is warm, spicy (if that's what you like) and very satisfying...  Four stars for always leaving with a happy belly!
author: Ana d.

description: Very disappointing. I believe we had the basic Korean beef, chicken dish. I really can't remember exactly what we had. I guess its because we had a bad experience there. Bugs were flying all over our table, it was very annoying. The only thing I remember was the tea. Any way, I will definitely put this on my black list!!
author: The Black Cat C.

description: This was the first Korean place I ever ate at in the city and 4 years later, I'm still a fan. It's not exactly the most authentic place, but I love their generous portions, friendly staff, and of course it also helps that they give complimentary appetizers as well. The prices are reasonable though and I'd certainly recommend it to friends if they're in the area.
author: Ty L.

description:
my bf's new favorite korean place.  i have to say, i'm a new fan too.

our order:  
seafood pancake - crispy on the outside, gooey on the inside with onion, squid, and egg. yummers!  the sauce they brought out was so red i thought i might scorch my tongue on the spicyness, but it wasn't spicy at all, tangy and perfect cuz i can't eat spicy.  for those who are looking for heat and spice, u might want to ask for hot sauce instead.

soft tofu with beef - the beef was good, not ur usual bland chewy cardboard. it definitely had to do with the fat content of the beef, a good portion of fat to lean beef which i'm sure they also marinated cuz it was pretty damn flavorful for something so thinly sliced.  piping hot and steaming, just the way i like to burn my tongue.

veggie and beef stoneware rice bowl - good flavor, not overly outstanding compare to other korean places, but it was pretty good, u can't go wrong with rice in a HOT stoneware bowl topped with fresh veggies and beef.  the egg on top gave it texture and flavor.

our freebie was the mackeral. it was salty and good, went perfectly with our steamed rice.  

i love all the small dishes, not to spicy so i could eat most of it, not a fan of kimchi so more for the bf.  

we're gonna be back, cuz we just HAVE to try their fried chicken, everyone in the restaurant ordered it except for us, must read yelp before trying any new place so i could have gotten the 411 to order the chicken. next time shin toe, next time.  =)
author: Ames K.

description: Good price, good service, but I got sick from the food so 1 star short of 4.
author: Inigo M.

description: The "KFC" - Korean Fried Chicken is yum! Also had the jap chae and the beef in it tasted like kalbi---mmm mmm.  The tofu stew with seafood was also really tasty.  I love all the pan chan when you order it to go too!  Only thing is they get really busy and sometimes don't want to take your order for take-out...and they're closed on Sundays...
author: Amina B.

description: This place is sooo good!  and with the freebies, you just can't help but come here over and over.  I think the onion pancake is free free..and then they give you like fish or tofu for free also!!!  the free free stuff is definite and the free stuff i think it's up to them.  But even I'm not entirely sure cuz she just popped up with free food and all I could say was "WOW!  REALLY?!  THANK YOU!"  The fried chicken is also a favorite of mine.  The portions are large and the food is tasty!  I think they may even do foot deliveries as I have seen the lady walk out the door and around the corner with a plate of food!  At night though, the wait is pretty long...but I mean if there's people waiting then it must be pretty darn safe to eat at.  Prices are good and the feel of it is very homestyle.
author: LittleBird 8.

description: I can't comment on the food, but I can warn you: even though their site says they close at 9:30pm, they actually stop seating at 8:30pm. It was very disappointing to drive way out in the middle of nowhere to get turned away at 8:30pm when they clearly had tables available.
author: Bryan K.

description: Looks from outside deceiving. Side dishes good never asked if we wanted more. Ordered Kalbi tasty but I am used to korean shortribs. They used English shortribs which the meat is tougher greasier and very fatty. Ordered beef soup very good. Would like to other things on the menu.
author: Poi L.

description: This is one of the most authentic Korean places in San Francisco.  It may not be the cleanest restaurant, but the food is too good to pass up.  They also give out complimentary small side dishes, potato pancakes, and mackerel if you order enough food.  I love the fried chicken wings, seafood tofu soup, and bibambap.  The only negative side is that they are understaffed.  It takes forever for your order to come and the staff often ignores you because they are too busy serving other tables.  But other than that, this place is worth going to because their food is bomb!!
author: Maggie L.

description: Food here is pretty solid . They give you like about 5 side dishes which are decent . My friend got a lunch order of kalbi which was a small porportion but it tasted alright . I ordered a pork & potato in spicy stew which was decent but I didn't like how I had to chew the meat off the bones being the lazy girl I am lol . I also didn't like how the potato weren't cut into small pieces but instead they were in big chunks . I ordered a seafood pancake as well which was kind of bland . Luckily , it came with a fabolous hot sauce . It was kind of sweet and tasted interesting . Looks homemade to me .. makes me wonder how they made it . The sauce was really wonderful . My friend hasn't been to this place for 5 years but for somehow the owner recognizes her and gave us a side of fish . I don't know what kind of fish it was but it was pretty good .
author: Eileen L.

description:
this restaurant has a 'homey' feeling, maybe because it's small and far from 'crowd restaurant place'.
most of the food are quite good..the ajuma quite friendly too.
they often throw you free stuff...
overall it's reasonable, since no korean rest nearby.
author: Suki S.

description: I still like it here but the past couple of times I've been here the fried chicken has been underseasoned. What happened? The first time around I bumped into a friend eating with her friends and she told me the chicken was bland. I figured maybe they were having a bad day. Tried the fried chicken again months later and the chicken was still bland! Have they cut back on the seasoning?
author: Al T.

description: Fried chicken is on top of my wicked weakness list.  This place has EXCELLENT KOREAN FRIED CHICKEN!!!  It is CRISPY, moist, tasty, and CRISPY.  Chicken is deep fried CRISPY and tossed in a sweet, and spicy hot sauce.  My friends and I ordered numerous items but the chicken plastered my taste buds for days.  So, ***** stars for the chicken alone.  The place is small but was packed on a Tuesday night and our waitress had to be reminded of what we were missing from our order.  She was kind about our bitching so no falling stars for her.
author: Nanette L.

description: All I can say is...the fried chicken is the bomb, its soo freakN good, Seafood pancake is great, and i was not disappointed by anything that they serveD!!!
author: william w.

description: Reading the other reviews of "Shiny Ball Toe" (cant remember the real name for the life of me, sorry) you will get the impression that the fried chicken is really good ... they're wrong. ITS FRIGGIN AWESOME!!! Where else are you going to get steaming hot freshly fried chicken with a crispy outer layer with beautiful flecks of what i can only assume are kimchee spices or some other magical Korean magic dust...ooohhhh! Caveat: eat the chicken before its get cold because it does a cinderella thing and turns into a normal bird after. Good Kalbi and Kimchee Chige, and thanks for the free fish girls!
author: Alex C.

description:
one of my family's fave places to eat when it's just the fambam.

it looks like it's in someone's garage and yes, the space is tiny. my dad loveeeeesss their fried chicken although i don't think they're all that hot. but i love their noodles with octopus and the red sauce and the fact that they give alot of those little dishes with your meal. i'm sad they don't give out the onion pancakes anymore as part of the little dishes. 

aghhh just thinking about this is driving me crazy. i'm so glad i'm going home to SF this week so i can eat here.
author: Melanie C.

description: Dare I say, the perfect restaurant. That's right. This place delivered consistent bomb ass food everytime I go there. The service ain't all that but who cares. Everything I order is freaking delicous. The tofu soup is best I ever tasted ever ever. I love the free fish. This place rocks. I only wish they were bigger cuz it's always crowded
author: Edward S.

description: The fried chicken is excellent!  The pancake is excellent!  Wait a minute, is this a Korean restaurant I'm reviewing?  Ok, the other Korean dishes are good too!  The wait is variable, but the food and the waitress makes it worthwhile.  I would probably give this place four stars, but I'll add the extra star for the....ahem...service.
author: H H.

description: My friend Katie took me to this place 3 years ago and I've been going here ever since.  I love the food here so much I took my different groups of friends here for dinner & all continue to come here.  It's a hole-in-the-wall place but the food that comes out of the little tiny kitchen is tasty and satisfying.  I'm not Korean but I brought one of my BFF's who is Korean and she said it tasted like home cooking.  It's super affordable!  They throw in a free dish all the time...usually the tofu soup or the grilled mackerel.   I love the fried chicken.  It has a crunchy batter but moist in the inside.  You can't go wrong with either the beef bulgogi or spicy pork bulgogi.  The seafood pancake actually has a lot of seafood!  The place gets super busy after 7:30 pm.  (Learned that on my first visit.)  My girlfriend and I waited for an hour to sit down and I'm glad that we weren't turned off by the wait because I would of never known how good the food was.   They open a couple of hours for lunch and only in "to go" containers.  But you're ok to eat in.  It's because they do not have servers during the day.
author: Eileen B.

description:
After watching a movie at century 20 (daly city) and taking one look at the ridiculous, snaking line for the new buffet place right next to it, we decided it would be smarter to eat elsewhere.

A friend had just eaten Shin Toe Bul Yi the night before and recommended our group (7 people) to eat there. Being the paranoid person that he is and attempting to get seated more quickly, he decided to put his name down on the waitlist as "Jun Ho Lee," despite the fact that he is 100% Chinese (and apparently 100% idiotic) . Lesson learned: they do not prioritize Korean people before others, and will call your name/speak to you in Korean if you put down a Korean name.

Notwithstanding the initial confusion with the name, we were seated after a fifteen minute wait. The restaurant is quite small and patrons are packed into this place with minimal elbow space. The friend who had eaten here the night before said every table ordered the fried chicken, so we ordered that. Please forgive me for the following butchered description of dishes since I was quite tired and did not really attempt to look at the names of the dishes. We also ordered a beef and potato stew in a clay pot (not sure what the name of the dish was), a pan-fried fish dish, a dish that looked like vegetarian fried rice noodles, and the teriyaki chicken. Honestly, no one said anything positive about the dishes, except for the beef and potato stew. The sauce for that was well-seasoned and had just the right amount of spice. it tasted like it had been stewing for hours. The fish was very mediocre and the noodles were too. However, I have to knock them for the somewhat expensive prices for these two ordinary dishes. The teriyaki chicken on the stone platter was extremely bland. I felt as though I could have made this dish with minimal effort. Though there was a sizable amount of chicken, it should not have cost $13.99. Things here are overpriced.

The fried chicken deserves its own paragraph for sure. It was extremely disappointing. Why is everyone ordering this dish? Have people never had fried chicken before? Better fried chicken can be found at the KFC a few blocks away. In fact, no less than 3 people at the table mentioned KFC with higher regards. It was terribly under-seasoned, perhaps even unseasoned. The batter was dry and floury. After my first bite, I began to think they forgot to bring the sauce. To my amazement, there is in fact no sauce that comes with this dish. This dish killed my spirit and left me craving KFC.

Overall, this meal can only be described as disappointing. The only bright spot in this experience was the pleasantly-smiling Korean lady who wished us a happy new year as we left. God bless her. She was the only one smiling after our meal.
author: Gary L.

description: One of the better Korean restaurant in SF. We order the tofu soup, jap chai, and pork bulogi. Everything is very savory and delicious. The restaurant is small so there will be a wait. I ended up smelly like fried food. This is definitely a family run business which gives it a friendly feel. The portion are pretty good and this is a good place for groups of 6.
author: Ginny M.

description: This place was my first favorite Korean restaurant in the city, then I moved to the richmond and have been going to King Charcoal BBQ on Geary/2nd since it's closer but this place makes a really good kimchi chigae and steamed seabass jjim. I haven't been here in a while [due to the aforementioned King Charcoal] but I think a visit is overdue!
author: kristin e.

description: I give it 5 stars because of overall quality, great food, & cheap prices. you may have a difficult time finding parking, but when you do, you'll be richly rewarded with plenty of appetizers and good Korean entrees.
author: Chris C.

description: This place used to have a sign Chick n Deli on it. They must have kept the deep fryers. I love the fried chicken here. There aren't too many good Korean places in SF but each place has their signature dishes. If you like bulgogi , I would look at the places out in the Richmond area. Order the fried chicken, sea bass & the tofu soup!! Also, all the dishes must be about $1-2 less here in comparison to the Richmond places. Great neighboorhood place
author: Jenny W.

description: Their KFC is so disappointing!! No flavor at all! I don't understand why everyone raved about their KFC, so I guess it was a miss. Their pancake is too greasy and also flavor-less. Their free soup is the only good thing. I'd rather go to Pine on Noriega.
author: Maria H.

description: 3.5 stars.  This restaurant is always super crowded around dinner time.  Our server was one of the two girls doing everything...but unlike Toyose, she was super sweet, provided good service, and did everything quickly!  The food was pretty good...I loved my tofu stew with beef, although I think it could have been spicier.  I asked for spicy, but it seemed pretty mild.  I should say extra super spicy next time.  The flavor of the broth was super delish...I was kind of scared it might be super MSG infused, but surprisingly, I didn't knock out or get a headache like I usually do with MSG.  So either there wasn't much MSG or I was invincible yesterday.  We also ordered  the fried chicken.  It was ok.  Asian version of KFC.  Lots of tables ordered it, so we wanted to try.  My fiancee had the kim chee stone pot rice thing and it was pretty good.  He would have been happier if it was spicier.
author: Cheryl L.

description: Man how many times have I been here.. whenever I'm here with friends we order way too much food. The soup is awesome, but then again I just love soup in general. lol. The pancake is pretty big and I love the spicy bulgogi. Definitely give it a try!
author: Lily K.

description: This place seems to be consistently busy.  We went with my mom and friend and everyone seems to order the Fried Chicken Pieces here.  Not bad but could be a little saltier.  We also got the Steamed Sea Bass and Pork Bul Go Bi (not sure I spelt that right).  Next time, I am trying the Beef Short Ribs.  The house gives you lots of small plates as in the Korean custom and they also give a tofu soup.  The dishes may look red and spicy but they are really not.  Everything was tasty and menu prices are inexpensive.  Good place for a decent priced family dinner.
author: Elaine L.

description: I finally had the chance to try this place out after bookmarking it for so long.  Parking was easy and we only waited a few minutes for a table.  As we sat down, we noticed that almost every table had a plate of fried chicken.  We decided to order that, the pajun, and the sauteed octopus and vegetables.  C wanted the tofu soup too but the waitress warned us that it was too much food and that she was going to give us a small tofu soup on the house.  She was right.  With the panchan, our little table was overflowing.  We quickly dug in and it was pretty good food.  My favorite was the octopus.  It was so tender.  The fried chicken was also a winner.  It was so juicy, had a nice spicy and crunchy batter,  yet was not greasy at all.  I wasn't a huge fan of the pajun though.  It was too doughy for my taste.
author: Pelle Y.

description: 3.5 stars. I kind of liked that this place was way out there. But based on the pictures posted on here, I felt kind of cheated. I went here for lunch, which they do "to-go" only, which really isn't. I appreciated their ghetto water pitchers though. The food was okay and the prices were reasonable.
author: Alex Y.

description: I don't go to many korean restaurants, but from what I've  had before, this is plenty damn good. It helps that a lot of koreans in the neighborhood come here for dinner. Definitely a small really easy to miss kinda place. But when you see lines out the door, you know people are waiting for good food. I typically always get the pork or beef dishes. Damn good. And the little tiny sides are awesome too. Can't beat it, so eat it.
author: Clinton L.

description:
i couldn't believe this place still exist!!!  i used to come here with friends almost every other week to drink and eat some 18 years ago.  it's no frill korean restaurant that serves up cheap korean food.  

i went there last week late at night b/c we were having a problem deciding where to eat.  we decided to go here hoping it still exist and sure enough it was there.  when we walked in around 10pm, the place was pretty packed and noticed there were more chinese than actual korean customers.  

we ordered 3 different dishes and they were all ok...spicy fried chicken, seafood stew, and pork bbq.  i remembered the place as very good and cheap although the price was reasonable i thought the food wasn't anything to write home about.  it was just ok.  

would i come back? yes with little hesitation.
author: donald c.

description: Great when you want good, basic korean food and don't want to get mixed up with all smoke and smell of Brother's -- you can't grill at your table here.  The food is tasty and it's worth it to head way out to the outer Sunset.  It's a funny hole in the wall complete with weird, dusty knicknacks.
author: Jenn S.

description: yummy food.  they always serve little dishes for you and the service is friendly.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Our FAVORITE local korean restaurant. It's tiny, and there's usually a line, but they give you tons of food and it's always great. Everyone we've brought here loves it.
author: vicki c.

description: This is my favorite Korean place.  It is family owned and everything is so homemade.  The kimchi and pickled radish is wonderful.  I like the pork bugolgi and the jeobchoe.  The garlic taste in the jaobchoe is strong and flavorful.  This place is really something.
author: Stevezee C.

description: Great casseroles, tofu soup, korean bbq, seafood pancakes... everything! Weekdays offer great lunch specials that shouldn't be missed out on.
author: Julie L.

description: The fried chicken is pretty good but sometimes its dry. They use to give you a free Korean pancake appetizer but they stopped. The red sauce that comes with the pancake goes very well with the chicken. They do give you a free tofu soup and that always hits the spot on a cold day.
author: Gilbert D.

description: I came here one day with my dad after running some errands since we were in the neighbor and it was recommended by my friend. The atmosphere is really nice even though we had to wait a few minutes for the food arrive. But during lunch time it is pretty nice since the meal comes in a to go box so that if you dont finish it, we can take it with us and finish it later.
author: Maile W.

description:
I called this place to let them know we had a large party (11) and that we would like to come on Saturday night.  She tells me right away, no reservations.  I said "no problem we can come in early when you open, would it be a probelm to seat us"?  Tells me no reservations again, I tell her I am not asking for a reservation just if she can accomodate us if we come in early since I know it is a smaller place.  I'm not sure she understood me so I gave up but I could tell by her phone demeanor, this woman is not customer friendly...

So we make if to the restaurant at 5:15pm, the place is empty except for 2 people in a corner.  I tell the waitress we have a party of 11.  She says I can't seat you until everyone is here.  There is 8 of us already here and the place is completely empty... I am starting to get agitated as I can tell this is the woman I spoke with on the phone the previous day.  She goes over to a table in the corner puts two together and say can you fit here ( she makes a table for 6).  I repeat that we need a table for 11?  I tell her to forget it and we will be eating somewhere else ( we ended up at another Korean restaurant on Noriega with a bill over $200).  Who turns away customers in this economy?

I am usually mild mannered but I would have given this woman a piece of my mind except I was here with my kids and my dad and other assorted family.  

This place could have the best Korean food in the city, but I would never spend a dime here...
author: David L.

description: I came here for lunch and was a bit disappointed. Lunch is with lunch box style so no really service. I had the beef ribs and was disappointed with that. My mom had a seafood plate which was okay but nothing special. I heard this is one of the best Korean place in the city. However, I was just disappointed. But to be fair I have to come again and try the pancakes and fried chicken was seem to be their speciality. So I will have to come again, with a Korean friend to get a better reading on this place.
author: Leon C.

description: after reading all these great reviews I was expecting exceptional flavors but over all, was just commonly good . I am surprised by the A16 Chef recommendation to go and try this place. The onion pancakes were good but not memorable, we didn't try the chicken since their portion are for 4 people and we were only 2. Same for the pancakes, it' for three or four. The Kobe beef was dry, chewy and not appealing to me. I'd  like the fried pot stickers, very delicate flavor.
author: Biemme B.

description: As far as Korean restaurants go, this is verry average. The outside really looks like a dump, but the inside is fine. A-OK.
author: Simon L.

description: This place is way out there, but so worth the haul across town!  All you need is the green onion pancake and the fried chicken.  Rumour has it they dish out free food, and it's totally true!  It doesn't even make sense how much food they give you.   So much great salty, saucey side dish goodness!  And did I mention the fried chicken?  It's money.  I found myself wondering what part of the bird I was eating, but in the end it doesn't matter, it's a great blend of spicy, crispy, juicy and NOT greasy at all.  Get here, and you'll smell good when you leave.
author: Jon S.

description: Awesome food. Awesome Price. The place always smells great. Nice and cozy. Be sure to come ahead of time though! Lines get craaaazy.
author: Jason L.

description:
Very good korean food. Only problem is they close at 9.30 (most korean places are open till late).
We ordered jap chae, green onion pancake, fried chicken bits, dol sot bam and a spicy korean sausage soup. They added a piece of fried fish on the hosue. Everything was quite good. The soup had liver and something that resembled blood sausage in it, and was in a spicy broth. I personally didnt care for it, but my husband and friends loved it. All portion sizes were quite big, and everythig was good. Good service as well.
